questions.text: A physiologist is interested in studying the mechanism of contraction in different muscle cells in the human body, which closely resembles that of a frog. He isolated a small part of muscle from a frog's small intestine, administered different stimuli, and observed multiple twitches. Regardless of the stimulus, he noticed that these muscle cells use actin and myosin to form a cross-bridge to generate force. During this process, calcium level also increases inside the cell. What is the mechanism by which calcium causes contraction in this particular cell type?

choices.text: Calmodulin-dependent myosin light chain kinase activation

questions.solution:
Option D: Calmodulin-dependent myosin light chain kinase activation

  • The intestine contains smooth muscle cells. These have a different mechanism of contraction than striated muscle cells.
  • As soon as a stimulus is applied, it opens L-type voltage-gated Ca2+ channels in the sarcolemma, which causes an influx of Ca2+ from the extracellular space into the smooth muscle cell (Ca2+ is also released from the SR, further increasing the intracellular concentration of Ca2+)
  • Ca2+ binds to calmodulin in the sarcoplasm, leading to activation of calmodulin.
  • Ca2+-calmodulin complex activates myosin light-chain kinase (MLCK).
  • MLCK phosphorylates the light chain head of the myosin filament.
  • ATPase activity in phosphorylated myosin enables cross-bridge formation with actin, resulting in muscle contraction.
  • In this way, smooth muscle cells contract in response to a stimulus.

Option A: Increased cAMP:

  • Unlike cardiac muscle, increased cAMP in smooth muscle causes relaxation.
  • This is because cAMP normally inhibits myosin light chain kinase, the enzyme responsible for phosphorylating smooth muscle myosin and causing contraction.
  • Both increased cAMP and increased cGMP lead to smooth muscle relaxation.

Option B: Calcium combined with troponin

  • Troponin (Tn) is the sarcomeric calcium regulator for striated (skeletal and cardiac) muscle contraction. On binding Ca2+, Tn transmits information via structural changes throughout the actin-tropomyosin filaments, activating myosin ATPase activity and muscle contraction.
  • The intestine contains smooth muscle cells and not striated muscle cells. 

Option C: Increased cGMP

  • Increased cGMP leads to the activation of myosin light chain phosphatase.
  • This enzyme causes dephosphorylation of the regulatory light chain of myosin and hence, leads to the relaxation of the smooth muscle cells.
  • Decreased cGMP can lead to smooth muscle contraction.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male was brought to the emergency after a motor vehicle accident. The by-standers informed the triage that, this young male, fell from his motor cycle and hit his head hard on the pavement. A linear fracture was noted in the area of the junction of frontal, parietal, temporal and sphenoid bones on the x-ray. Which of the following artery is being injured?
questions.solution:
The site which is mentioned in the question (junction of frontal, parietal, temporal and sphenoid bones) is called as ‘pterion’. It is the thinnest part of the bone in this region and is medically relevant due the fact that it is thin and middle meningeal artery courses within the skull deep to this point. Fractures to this site may damage the middle meningeal artery leading to epidural hematoma. Middle meningeal artery is a branch of maxillary artery, which arises from external carotid artery.

Other options:

Choice A- External carotid artery gives rise to facial artery that courses over the mandible anterior to the insertion of the masseter muscle to supply the oral region and nose and the buccal region of the cheeks.

Choice B- Sphenopalantine artery arises from third part of the maxillary artery that supplies most part of the nasal mucosa. Kiesselbach’s plexus, a frequent site of nose bleeds, is formed by the anastomosis of sphenopalantine aretry, ophthalmic artery and facial arteries within the anterior part of the septum.

Choice C - occipital artery arises from the external carotid artery and gives blood supply to scalp and sternocleidomastoids.

questions.text: A 15-month-old female infant with short stature, some clouding of the corneas, coarse facial features, and an enlarged tongue was brought to the pediatrician due to recurrent upper respiratory tract infection. She also appeared to have some hearing loss and other developmental delays. Her blood work shows the presence of some inclusion bodies in neutrophils. The pediatrician suspects the child has a mucopolysaccharidosis. Which of the following condition is she least likely to have?
questions.solution:
• Hunter syndrome is Type II Mucopolysaccharidosis, in which enzyme deficient is Iduronate Sulfatase. This is X-linked recessive, so occurs exclusively in males.
  • Also, there is no corneal clouding in Hunter's disease. As the patient in this question is female and there is some corneal clouding, it is least likely to be a case of Hunter syndrome.

Option A: Hurler Syndrome is very similar to Hunter disease in most of the symptoms but the main difference is the presence of corneal clouding and Riley body inclusion in the neutrophils in this disease.

Options C & D are autosomal recessive and can affect any gender.

questions.text: Scientists from University of Stanford were conducting a study on renal tubular transfer proteins. Study was mainly on a new drug which was to be developed. A healthy subject was volunteered for the experiment. The kidney is considered as the filtration organ of our body. Clearance is the process of removal of waste material filtered and removed in urine. A substance was identified in the lab that it can specifically block the transport of glucose in the proximal renal tubule. If this substance is administered to the healthy individual, glucose clearance can be approximately equal to clearance of which of the following
questions.solution:
No tubular reabsorption secretion or secretion. will be Filtered amount will be amount equal to excreted amount Net tubular reabsorption Excreted amount will be less than filtered amount

Net tubular

Excreted amount more than filtered
  • Glucose is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule and filtered at the glomerulus.
  • Glucose clearance and the GFR value will almost be equal when there is a blockage of sodium coupled, career mediated transport of glucose by proximal tubule.
  • This can be easily calculated by the clearance of inulin.

Option A; PAH can be freely filtered at the glomerulus and is getting secreted into the urine by an acid transporter in the proximal tubule. This is an energy dependent transporter. Filtered load will be lower than the amount of PAH. Renal plasma flow can be calculated by the clearance of PAH. Creatinine is not having that much similarity to PAH.

Option B; Under normal conditions, amino acids are filtered at the glomerulus same as that of glucose and then get reabsorbed at proximal tubule.

Option D; Sodium is a substance which is completely reabsorbed by the nephron, which results in a low amount excretion and a clearance value which will be very much lower than the GFR. Usually filtered sodium which is excreted will be 1%.

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics is not associated with coenzymes?

choices.text: It has a high molecular weight
It combines loosely with enzyme molecules.
Mostly belongs to the vitamin B complex group

questions.solution:
Option A: It has a high molecular weight.

  • Coenzymes aid enzymes in carrying out the catalysis of reactions.
  • These are non-proteinaceous substances that are loosely attached to enzymes as helper molecules.
  • They can be linked to enzymes through ionic, coordinate covalent, or sometimes covalent bonds.
  • Coenzymes contain a group of atoms and do not possess a well-defined tertiary structure like enzymes, so they have low molecular weight.
  • They serve in an enzyme-catalyzed reaction by permitting bond cleavage, accepting and donating electrons, and by transferring methyl groups. For example, a coenzyme thiamine pyrophosphate permits C-C bond cleavage and formation.

Option B: It combines loosely with enzyme molecules.

  • Coenzymes attach loosely with the enzyme molecules such that the enzyme and its coenzyme can be separated easily by dialysis.
  • When the reaction is completed, the coenzyme is released from the apo-enzyme and can bind to another enzyme molecule.

Option C: Mostly belong to the vitamin B complex group.

  • Most coenzymes belong to the Vitamin B Complex group.
  • For example. Thiamine pyrophosphate is a derivative of Vitamin B1, Riboflavin is Vitamin B2, and Pyridoxal phosphate is derivative of Vitamin B6.

Option D: It is heat stable

  • Coenzymes are small organic compounds, unlike enzymes which are fully-folded large proteins with a defined structure. Atoms or groups are linked by strong covalent bonds in coenzymes that provide heat stability to them.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man complains of abdominal pain and muscle fatigue on hospitalization for 2 weeks. His urine biochemical analysis showed high levels of δ-aminolevulinic acid based on which he was initially diagnosed with acute intermittent porphyria. Later, it was found that 70% of the patient's circulating red blood cells contained elevated levels of zinc protoporphyrin. The correct diagnosis is most likely to be:
questions.solution:
Lead inhibits both ferrochelatase (increasing the zinc protoporphyrin) and ALA dehydratase (increasing delta-ALA) as shown in the figure below. The accumulation of ALA and PBG blocks the action of neurotransmitter GABA causing continuous excitation of visceral pain fibers giving rise to symptoms such as abdominal pain, vomiting, hypertension, and tachycardia.

Option a and b: The main symptoms of protoporphyria and congenital erythropoietic porphyria are photosensitivity leading to skin cell damage and scarring.

Option d: Iron deficiency causes microcytic hypochromic anemia with low Hb but without any abdominal pain.

questions.text:
A 11-year-old boy falls down the stairs. A physician examines the radiograph of the boy’s shoulder region (see Figure below).
If the structure indicated by the letter B is fractured, which of the following structures is most likely injured?,
questions.solution: Fracture of the surgical neck of the humerus occurs commonly and damages the axillary nerve and the posterior humeral circumflex artery.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl has nasal discharge and itching of the eyes in the spring every year. An allergist performs a skin test using a mixture of grass pollens. Within a few minutes the girl exhibits a focal redness and swelling at the test site. This response is most likely due to

choices.text: Antigen-antibody complexes being formed in blood vessels in the skin
Activation of neutrophils due to injected antigens
Activation of CD4 helper cells and the resultant generation of specific antibodies
Activation of cytotoxic T lymphocytes to destroy Antigens

questions.solution: Because the person has demonstrated allergic reactions, the initial reaction would be due to an antigen antibody reaction and the activation of the complement system. Influx of neutrophils, activation of T-helper cells, and sensitized lymphocytes would take some time

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to his primary care physician along with his wife. He seems well; however, his wife is concerned that he has become increasingly forgetful with significant changes in his personality. She explains that he forgets conversations and gets lost in familiar places, and now he has also started forgetting the names of his family members. Recently he has started to become more aggressive and impatient. She says that these symptoms started 2 years back and have worsened. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following cell plays a key role in CNS inflammation in this disorder?
questions.solution:
Option B: Microglia

  • Microglial cells are the smallest glial cells in the CNS that are derived from bone marrow monocytes and enter the CNS after birth.
  • They provide a link between cells of the CNS and the immune system.
  • They proliferate and migrate to the site of a CNS injury and phagocytose neuronal debris after injury. Hence, they are the phagocytic scavenger cells of the CNS that are activated in response to tissue damage.
  • The HIV-1 virus targets microglia in the CNS, and these HIV-infected microglial cells fuse to form multinucleated giant cells.
  • Microglia constitute the innate immune system of the central nervous system and are key cellular mediators of neuroinflammatory processes. They are involved in antigen presentation and immune response generating cytokines in neurodegenerative disorders such as Alzheimer's.
  • "Reactive gliosis" refers to the accumulation of enlarged glial cells, notably microglia and astrocytes, which appear immediately after CNS injury.
  • In Neurodegenerative disorders, particularly Alzheimer's disease, the infiltrates of blood-derived mononuclear cells are absent. Senile plaques that accumulate in CNS in Alzheimer's contain amyloid beta protein. This protein is a peptide that forms insoluble and pathological extracellular aggregates that seem to attract microglia, which then phagocytose and degrade amyloid.
  • Chronic microglia activation is an important component of neurodegenerative diseases, and this chronic neuroinflammatory component likely contributes to neuronal dysfunction, injury, and loss in these diseases.
  • The common cause of dementia in the elderly is Alzheimer's, associated with the following altered proteins: ApoE-2, ApoE-4, APP, presenilin-1, and presenilin-2.
  • There is widespread cortical atrophy, especially in the hippocampus, with an accumulation of senile plaques in grey matter containing an extracellular beta-amyloid core and neurofibrillary tangles.

  • It is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by cognitive decline and difficulty completing activities of daily living. Symptoms include impaired ability to remember new pieces of information, Visio-spatial and language deficits, and behavioral and psychological impairments like aggression, irritability, social isolation, and apathy. MRI Brain shows volume loss in the hippocampus and temporal lobe.

Option A: Astrocytes

  • These are the most common glial cell types in CNS derived from neuroectoderm.
  • They are involved in physical support, repair, extracellular K+ buffer and removal of excess neurotransmitters.
  • They act as a glycogen fuel reserve buffer and are a blood-brain barrier component. They are also responsible for reactive gliosis in response to neuronal injury; however, they do not participate in phagocytosis.
  • Astrocytes marker: GFAP (glial fibrillation acidic protein).

Option C: Oligodendrocytes

  • These cells form myelin for axons in CNS and are derived from neuroectoderm. Each of the oligodendrocyte processes can myelinate individual segments of many axons. It is the predominant type of glial cell in white matter.
  •  They are injured in multiple sclerosis, progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) and leukodystrophies.

Option D: Schwann cell

  • They are the supporting cells of the peripheral nervous system and are derived from neural crest cells. They form myelin for axons in the PNS. Each Schwann cell forms myelin for only a single internodal segment of a single axon. Unmyelinated axons in the PNS are enveloped by the cytoplasmic processes of a Schwann cell.
  • They act as phagocytes and remove neuronal debris in the PNS, unlike microglia that cause phagocytosis in CNS after injury. They also promote axonal regeneration and are injured in Guillain-Barré syndrome.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male presents with nocturnal urination, increased urinary frequency, an enlarged and asymmetric prostate on DRE, ultrasound indicating an enlarged prostate, and a PSA level of 17 ng/mL. If prostate cancer is suspected, which lobe of the prostate gland is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Option C: Posterior lobe

LOBES OF PROSTATE GLAND:

The prostate is divided into several lobes.

Anterior Lobe

  • The anterior lobe is used to describe the anterior portion of the gland lying in front of the urethra.
  • It is devoid of glandular tissue formed completely of fibromuscular tissue.

Median Lobe

  • The median lobe is a cone-shaped portion of the gland situated between the two ejaculatory ducts and the urethra.

Lateral Lobes

  • The lateral lobes (right and left lobes) form the main mass of the gland and are continuous posteriorly. The prostatic urethra separates them.

Posterior Lobe

  • The posterior lobe describes the posteromedial part of the lateral lobes that can be palpated through the rectum during a digital rectal exam (DRE).
  • The posterior lobe roughly corresponds to the peripheral zone, the sub-capsular portion of the prostate gland’s posterior aspect surrounding the distal urethra.
  • 70–80% of prostatic cancers originate in this region

 

Option A: Anterior lobe

  • The anterior lobe is used to describe the anterior portion of the gland lying in front of the urethra. It is devoid of glandular tissue, being formed completely of fibromuscular tissue.
  • It is not involved in the cancerous process.​​​​​​​

Option B: Median lobe

  • The median lobe is a cone-shaped portion of the gland situated between the two ejaculatory ducts and the urethra.
  • Median lobe is the site for Benign Prostate Hypertrophy.

Option D: Central zone

  • The central zone surrounds the ejaculatory ducts and is located posterior to the transition zone and the urethra proximal to the verumontanum.
  • It is rarely associated with prostate carcinoma.
  • However, the most common site for prostate carcinoma is the posterior lobe.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy has short stature, coarse facies, stiffening of the joints, and mental retardation. His parents, his 7-year-old brother, and a 9-year-old sister, all are unaffected. She had a family history of a disease with similar progressive symptoms in one of her brothers who died at 16 years of age and in one of her nephews (her sister’s son). The patient’s mother is pregnant. The risk of the fetus having the same disease is:
questions.solution:
The patient’s normal parents (unaffected father and carrier mother), one normal sister (normal daughter), and a normal brother (normal son) indicate an X-linked recessive inheritance according to the chart below.

As the pedigree chart of the mother’s family show no presence of disease in the mother (normal daughter in fig) but in one brother (affected son in fig.) and in nephew from his sister (son of carrier daughter in fig), it again confirms an X linked recessive inheritance pattern.

Coarse facial features are a typical feature of Mucopolysaccharidosis (MPS) and Hunter syndrome has an X-linked recessive pattern.

Given X-linked recessive inheritance, the mother must have the abnormal allele on one of her X chromosomes (she is a carrier) in order for her son and brother to be affected. Her fetus has a 1/2 chance of being a boy and a 1/2 chance of being affected given male sex, resulting in a 1/4 (25%) overall risk of being affected.

questions.text: 68-year Esther is having her regular routine check-up in a gap of 1 month. Esther was overweighed and she has been done some changes to her lifestyle for decreasing weights. Her medical history will reveal us about the diabetes - 20 years and end stage renal disease. Esther was in haemodialysis for the past 5 years. She is a regularly taking insulin injection. She added that her blood sugars were controlled by her dieting plans and exercises. Esther also had hypertension and dyslipedemia. Esther can be at a great risk for which of the following metabolic derangements?
questions.solution:
• Renal osteodystrophy can be caused by ESRD.

  • If it is failed kidney there will be reduced synthesize of active Vitamin D which will also cause for the decreased absorption of calcium from the intestine.

  • Phosphorous retention will be associated with ESRD which will bind with calcium and promote the hypocalcemia.

  • Hypocalcemia along with hyperphosphatemia will promote for the secondary hyperparathyroidism.

  • It will occur by stimulation of parathyroid gland. Osteitis fibrosa cystica is occurred due to the high bone turnover rate seen in hyperparathyroidism.

Option B; In patients with ESRD hypercalcemia cannot be seen usually. In any renal pathology hypercalcemia is usually not seen. It can be seen in people who use excessive use of calcium containing phosphate binders.

Option C; This result from the decreased ability of clearing the inorganic phosphates by the failing kidneys. Increased bone turnover can accelerate the hyperphosphatemia.

Option D: This also not seen in patient with ESRD. Parathyroid gland can be stimulated excessively by combination of hypocalcemia with hyperphosphatemia which will result in secondary hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text:
An infant presented to the OPD with a history of vomiting and malnutrition. Patient has blue eyes, blonde hair & fair skin. On investigation, Guthrie test was found to be positive.
All are true regarding this disease EXCEPT: (AIIMS May 2018)

choices.text: White patch of hair due to tryptophan deficiency

questions.solution:
• This is Phenyl-ketonuria.
  • Guthrie’s bacterial inhibition test is a screening test for phenylketonuria (PKU), used to detect the abnormal presence of phenylalanine metabolites in blood i.e. Phenyl pyruvate, Phenyl alanine & Phenyl-lactate.
  • FeCl3 detects phenyl alanine levels in urine.

WITH REGARDS TO OTHER OPTIONS

In Phenylketonuria, Phenylalanine  is accumulated due to deficiency of enzyme Phenylalanine Hydroxylase.  As a result Phenylalanine is not converted to Tyrosine  and is  responsible for mental retardation in patients. Tyrosine becomes essential in these patients.

questions.text: Which pathway occurs in both the fed and fasting states, activating anabolic and catabolic processes in the body?
questions.solution:
Option A: TCA

  • TCA cycle functions in both oxidative and synthetic processes, i.e., Amphibolic.
  • TCA, and ETC are vital pathways that occur in both fed and fasting states.
  • Besides oxidation of carbon units, the TCA cycle is also involved in the inter-conversion of metabolites arising from transamination and deamination of amino acids and providing substrates for amino acid synthesis by transamination as well as for gluconeogenesis and fatty acid synthesis.
  • TCA, and ETC do not depend on hormones.
  • However, their activity can be either increased or decreased depending on the availability of substrates and abundance of products, respectively. For example, TCA activity is increased in the presence of oxaloacetate and acetyl CoA and decreased in the absence of NAD and FAD. Similarly, ETC activity can be decreased in the absence of oxygen.

Option B: Glycolysis

  • Though a small basal level of glycolysis also occurs in the fasting state, glycolysis is enhanced in the presence of Insulin in the fed state due to the activation of enzymes such as glucokinase that promote the oxidation of glucose to provide energy for various synthetic reactions. But, the best answer is TCA.

Option C: HMP

  • It is an anabolic pathway that occurs in the fed state. It is the main source of NADPH (required for synthesizing lipids) and Ribose 5-P (required for nucleotide synthesis).

Option D: Glycogenesis

  • Glycogenesis (glycogen synthesis) occurs in muscle and liver. It is an anabolic pathway, so the activity of the enzyme of the glycogen synthesis pathway is increased by the release of Insulin in the fed state.

questions.text: A 77-year-old male, has a long history of status epilepticus and as a final treatment, the surgeon opted for neurosurgery and he was put in medically induced coma for surgery. After three months of regular checkup, he came to the hospital and complained of right leg weakness and numbness. Neuro exam showed no eversion of right foot and numbness over the dorsum of his foot and lateral shin. When he walks, he lifts his right foot higher than the left and right foot slaps ground every step. Which of the following nerve is being injured?
questions.solution:
Most commonly injured leg nerve is ‘common peroneal nerve’. sciatic nerve at proximal popliteal fossa divides into tibial nerve and common peroneal nerve. Common peroneal nerve never courses laterally into the anterior compartment of the leg. Blunt trauma (like fibular neck fracture) to the lateral aspect of the leg and external pressure (due to prolonged immobility eg. Hospitalization, surgery or casting) can injure the nerve.

Patients with common peroneal nerve damage present with an equinovarus (plantarflexed and inverted) posture due to paralysis of the peroneus longus brevis muscle (mediate foot eversion), paralysis of the tibialis anterior muscle (mediates dorsiflexion), and paralysis of the extrinsic extensor of the toes. Injury can cause sensation loss at anterolateral leg and dorsum of the foot. Foot drop is the classic gait finding, where the affected toe points the ground as the foot is raised due to inability to dorsiflex. Patient compensates with ‘steppage gait’ where the leg is lifted high off the ground. Due to inability to gently lower the forefoot, the affected foot will often slap the ground (foot slap) with each step.

Even though superficial peroneal nerve (choice C) also innervates the peroneus longus and peroneus brevis muscles in the lateral compartment, the patient’s injury is most likely more proximally located at the common peroneal nerve because of the loss of dorsiflexion.

Choice A - sural nerve is pure sensory nerve which innervates posterolateral leg and lateral foot.

Choice B - tibial nerve injury causes loss of plantarflexion and inversion of the foot

questions.text: A 40-year-old alcoholic was brought to the ER after he had passed out in a bar after his usual drinking. He was prescribed with thiamine injection followed by overnight glucose through IV. The patient was alert and coherent the next morning with normal serum thiamine and his blood glucose was 73 mg/dL (4mM) and was discharged from the hospital. Which of the following enzyme/proteins would have no significant physiologic activity in this patient soon after discharge?
questions.solution:
After an overnight fast (plasma glucose 73 mg/dL), the liver will be stimulated to produce glucose. The activity of Glucokinase, an enzyme of glycolysis, would be insignificant as it requires high glucose concentration to be effective (high Km for glucose) and also due to low insulin.

Option a: Malate dehydrogenase is required for hepatic gluconeogenesis hence will be active.

Option c: GLUT-1 transporter is required for glucose uptake by brain during fasting Hence its activity will be enhanced in the morning due to fasting levels of glucose.

Option d: PFK-1 and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase are enzymes of glycolysis and TCA cycle and are active most of the time in the cells.

questions.text: In a physiology class, a professor explains the importance of different types of pulmonary receptors. He describes the role of Juxtacapillary receptors (J-receptors). Pulmonary J receptor stimulation results in which of the following?

choices.text: Reflex tachypnea followed by apnea and bradycardia
Reflex apnea followed by tachypnea and bradycardia
Reflex tachypnea followed by apnea and tachycardia
Reflex apnea followed by tachypnea and tachycardia

questions.solution:
Option B: Reflex apnea followed by tachypnea and bradycardia

  • Juxtacapillary receptors (J-receptors) are located in the pulmonary interstitium.
  • The J-receptors are the end-organs located on the unmyelinated C-type vagal fibres.
  • J-receptors are stimulated by mechanical or chemical stimulation in the lung interstitium.
  • J receptors may be stimulated in the conditions causing pulmonary congestion, oedema, and some inflammatory states.
  • J receptor stimulation results in reflex apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing (tachypnea); and depression of the cardiovascular function indicated by bradycardia and hypotension.

Option A: Reflex tachypnea followed by apnea and bradycardia

  • Stimulation of J-receptors results in apnea and bradycardia. However, they do not cause reflex tachypnea.

Option C: Reflex tachypnea followed by apnea and tachycardia

  • J-receptors cause reflex apnea. However, reflex tachypnea and tachycardia are not observed by stimulation of J-receptors

Option D: Reflex apnea followed by tachypnea and tachycardia

  • Stimulation of J-receptors results in reflex apnea which is followed by rapid shallow breathing. Tachypnea and tachycardia are not observed.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male came for casual checkup. His only concern was, some vague abdominal discomfort. And further digging up the history, he had bloody stools which he thought it was normal. Colonoscopy was done and it revealed a mass in the descending colon. Surgical removal was planned. During surgery, which of the following artery should be ligated in order to remove the mass?
questions.solution:
The distal 1/3 of the transverse colon, descending colon, sigmoid colon and the rectum are derivatives of the hindgut. Hindgut derivatives receive blood supply from the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA). It is a branch of aorta. All these structures drain into inferior mesenteric vein (IMV) and IMV drains into the splenic vein.

Choice A- external iliac artery- it supplies the lower extremity and the anterior abdominal wall

Choice B- internal iliac artery- it gives rise to the middle rectal artery and the internal iliac artery supplies the portions of the gut.

Choice D- superior mesenteric artery. It supplies the midgut. (from the third part of the duodenum to the proximal 2/3 of the transverse colon)

questions.text: Scientists are having a study on the changes coming in kidney blood flow and glomerular filtration. From the study they came to a conclusion that one of the properties can reduce the renal plasma flow and elevate the filtration fraction. Which of the following property can produce the given effect?
questions.solution:
• Efferent arteriole which is the outgoing artery, if it gets constricted, it will be preventing the blood flow through the kidney.
  • This can lead to the decrease in the renal plasma flow. But here there will be an increase in the hydrostatic pressure of glomerular capillary.
  • This happens due to the backing up by the fluids.
  • Increase in the glomerular hydrostatic pressure or the bowman’s capsule oncotic pressure will lead to increase the GFR.
  • While increase in the capillary oncotic pressure and bowman’s space hydrostatic pressure will decrease GFR.
  • Filtration fraction can be calculated by dividing the GFR by Renal plasma flow.

Option A; Bowman’s space hydrostatic pressure can be increased due to the obstruction in the neck of the bladder which will result in the decrease of the GFR. There will be no effect in the RPF. Obstruction in the neck of bladder can have effect on the filtration fraction which will be decreased due to the decrease in the GFR.

Option B; This can cause a decrease in the hydrostatic pressure of glomerular capillaries which can lead to a decrease in the GFR.

Option C; Constriction of afferent artery which is coming inside, it can cause a decrease in the hydrostatic pressure in the glomerular capillaries which will result in a decreased GFR. There will be a resultant decrease in the renal plasma flow also. The filtration fraction will be remaining unchanged.

questions.text: You were in your weekly family gathering after a very long time. Your uncle who is healthy and has no significant past medical history complains of chronic abdominal pain. All of a sudden, he grabbed his tummy and cried out in pain. You took him to the hospital and there, CT of the abdomen was done (given below). Which of the following, is consistent with the marked structure in the image?

choices.text: A. It joins the splenic vein to form the portal vein
It is formed by the union of the common iliac veins
It gives rise to the right and left renal arteries
It drains through the cystic duct into the common bile duct

questions.solution:
The given abdominal CT image is at the level of the L1 vertebra. The renal arteries originate from the aorta at this level. The inferior (IVC) lies anterior to the right renal artery and to the right of the aorta. The right and left common iliac veins merge together to form the IVC at the level of L4-L5 and drains into the right atrium. IVC drains the deoxygenated blood from the lower extremities, portal system and abdominal and pelvic viscera.

Choice A- the portal vein is formed by the union of the superior mesenteric vein and the splenic vein.

Choice C- the abdominal aorta lies posteromedial to the inferior vena cava within the abdomen. The given image shows the abdominal aorta giving rise to the left and right renal arteries.

Choice D- the cystic duct drains bile into the common bile duct from the gallbladder. In this given image, the gallbladder is not visualized due to its higher anatomical location.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true for metaphysis of bone EXCEPT:

choices.text: It is the strongest part of bone
It is the most vascular part of bone
It is the region favoring hematogenous spread of infection

questions.solution:
• The strongest part of bone is diaphysis (not metaphysis).
  • During growth of bone maximum activity occurs at growth plate.
  • Metaphysis is the most vascular part of bone.

questions.text: Which nerve is blocked in the given diagram

What is the underlying pathophysiological process responsible for short stature, obesity, craniofacial abnormalities, low blood sugar, and low serum IGF-1 levels despite elevated basal serum growth hormone levels?
questions.solution:
Option B: Growth hormone receptor (GHR) insensitivity

Laron Syndrome:

  • Plasma GH is normal or elevated.
  • GH receptors are unresponsive due to loss-of-function mutations of the gene for the receptors.
  • Results in growth hormone insensitivity.
  • Plasma IGF-I is markedly reduced, along with IGFBP-3 (IGF-binding protein-3).

 

Treatment: With the availability of recombinant IGF-1, effective treatment of these children may restore linear growth.

Option A: Growth hormone deficiency

  • Growth hormone deficiency (GHD), also known as dwarfism or pituitary dwarfism, is a condition caused by insufficient amounts of growth hormone in the body.
  • Laron syndrome is differentiated from pituitary dwarfism by elevated basal serum GH due to GHR insensitivity. Serum IGF-1 is low in both conditions.
  • GHD is treated by regular injections of synthetic human growth hormone before growth plates of bones are joined together. Laron syndrome is treated by recombinant human IGF-1 administration.

Option C: Elevated levels of plasma IGF-BP3

  • Plasma IGF-BP3 is markedly reduced along with plasma IGF-1 in Laron syndrome

Option D: Normal levels of plasma IGF-BP3b

  • Plasma IGF-BP3 is markedly reduced along with plasma IGF-1 in Laron syndrome.

questions.text: NOT affected in posterior cerebral artery infarct is:
questions.solution:
- Posterior cerebral artery gives branches to only the midbrain part of brainstem (not pons or medulla oblongata).

- Pons are supplied by branches of basilar artery.

- Midbrain is supplied by branches of posterior cerebral artery and basilar artery.

- Thalamus is supplied by numerous arteries including posterior cerebral artery and posterior communicating artery.

- Posterior cerebral artery supplies the posterior cerebrum, including the occipital visual (striate) cortex.

questions.text: The patient presents to medicine OPD complaining of fever with chills and rigors with inflammation in the unilateral knee joint. On laboratory investigation, ESR is raised, and TLC is also raised.  Which of the following method is used for ESR estimation?
questions.solution:
Option D: Wintrobe method

  • Wintrobe's Method and Westergren's Method are for ESR determination

Wintrobe method:

  • Two main methods are used to measure the ESR: the Westergren method and the Wintrobe Method. Each method produces slightly different results.
  • Most laboratories use the Westergren method.
  • The Wintrobe method is performed similarly, except that the Wintrobe tube is smaller than the Westergren tube and is smaller than the Westergren tube and only 100 mm (about 3.94 in) long.
  • EDTA anticoagulated blood without extra diluent is drawn into the tube, and the rate of fall of red blood cells is measured in millimeters after 1 hour.
  • The shorter column makes this method less sensitive than the Westergren method because the maximal possible abnormal value is lower.
  • However, this method is more practical for demonstration purposes.

Option A: Drabkin's Method

  • Drabkin's method fundamentally measures the molar concentration of the heme prosthetic group in hemoglobin.

Option B: Sahli's Method

  • Sahli's method is also called the acid hematin method of hemoglobin estimation.
  • Hermann Sahli first performed this.
  • Hemoglobin is measured by the hemolysis of red blood cells so that the pigment is released into the plasma.
  • The hemoglobin is converted into acid hematin when treated with 0.1 N HCI.

Option C: Spectrophotometry

  • A non-invasive technique employing light-guide spectrophotometry is described for measuring hemoglobin concentration and oxygenation in human skin.

questions.text: During the surgery (removal of an ovarian mass) there was an excessive bleeding. Among which of the following structure, the surgeon forgot to ligate which caused the excessive bleeding?
questions.solution:
Female gonadal organs are the ovaries, which are located in the pelvis. The ovaries are covered by the mesovarium which extends from the broad ligament of the uterus. The broad ligament surrounds a portion of the suspensory ligament, round ligament of the uterus, ovarian ligament and the uterine tube. The nerves, arteries, veins and the lymphatics supplying the ovary are all delivered by the suspensory ligament of the ovary. The ovarian arteries provide the blood supply to the ovaries which arises from the abdominal aorta bilaterally. The right ovarian vein drains into the inferior vena cava and thew left ovarian vein drains into the left renal vein. The ureters course retroperitoneally in close association with the gonadal vessels.

Other options:

Choice A : it is the region of the broad ligament of the uterus that lies between the uterine tube and the ovary

Choice B : it is also known as cardinal ligament. This extends from the cervix and the lateral fornix of the vagina to the lateral pelvic walls. The uterine artery courses in this tissue.

Choice C- it courses from the uterine pole of the ovary to the body of the uterus. It carries no named blood vessels.

questions.text: The major process of glycogenesis involves polymerization of free glucose on glycogenin primer and subsequent addition of glucose by glycogen synthase and action of branching enzyme. The process of Glyconeogenesis refers to:

choices.text: Synthesis of glycogen from other carbohydrate sources
Synthesis of glycogen from non-carbohydrate sources

questions.solution:
Glyconeogenesis

  • Synthesis of glycogen from non-carbohydrate precursors
  • This pathway is the same as gluconeogenesis, but the last step is different i.e.
    • In glyconeogenesis, glucose-6-Phosphate directly enters glycogen synthesis.
    • So glucose-6-phosphatase step is not required.

Glycogenesis - Synthesis of glycogen from glucose.

Glycogenolysis - Breakdown of glycogen to produce glucose.

Gluconeogenesis - Synthesis of glucose from non-carbohydrate precursors.

questions.text: Which of the following inhibits the release of insulin?
questions.solution:
Option A: Somatostatin

  • Somatostatin, secreted by δ cells of the pancreas, inhibits the other two secretions of the endocrine pancreas - insulin & glucagon. The primary stimulators of somatostatin are glucose, amino acids, and fatty acids.
  • Somatostatin also inhibits the secretion of gastrointestinal hormones such as secretin and gastrin.
  • In the brain, somatostatin regulates the secretion of some pituitary hormones, including thyroid-stimulating hormone TSH, growth hormone GH, and prolactin.

Option B: Glucagon

  • Glucagon is secreted by alpha cells of the pancreas.
  • It raises blood sugar levels during fasting or stress by glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis.
  • Its function is exactly opposite to that of insulin.
  • Its secretion is also inhibited by somatostatin.

Option C: Acetylcholine

  • The parasympathetic nervous system (Vagus/Ach) is a stimulator of insulin secretion.
  • Insulin secretion is inhibited by epinephrine acting via alpha-2 adrenergic receptors.

Option D: Amino acids

  • Amino acids, FFAs, and glucose are the stimulators of insulin secretion.

questions.text: Which of the following is the last region of the ventricle to undergo depolarization?

choices.text: Epicardium of the base of LV
Endocardium of the base of LV

questions.solution:
Option A: Epicardium of the base of LV

  • The above-given case is atrial fibrillation.
  • Most commonly caused by binge drinking.
  • There is an irregularly spaced QRS complex with no discrete P wave.
  • It can lead to stroke.
  • The endocardial surfaces of both ventricles are activated rapidly, and depolarisation spreads from apex to base and from endocardium to epicardium at a slower velocity (≈ 0.3 to 0.4 m/sec).
  • Thus, the last part of the heart to be depolarised is the epicardium of the base of the LV.
  • In addition, the apical and central epicardial regions of both ventricles are activated somewhat earlier than their respective basal regions.
  • The last portions of the ventricles to be excited are the pulmonary CONUS, posterior basal epicardial regions, and a small zone in the basal portion of the interventricular septum.

Option B: Endocardium of the base of LV

  • The innermost layer of the heart is the endocardium. It is a thin, smooth, and glistening membrane.
  • It is formed by a single layer of endothelial cells lining the inner surface of the heart.
  • Endocardium continues as endothelium of the blood vessels.

Option C: Apical epicardium

  • The depolarisation starts from the left ventricle to the right ventricle.
  • The depolarisation also starts from the endocardium to the epicardium
  • So the base of the epicardium will be the last part to depolarise.

Option D: Apical endocardium

  • The depolarisation starts from the endocardium to the epicardium of the base of the ventricles.
  • So the base of the endocardium depolarises first, and the base of the epicardium depolarises at last.

It is a slow enlarging painless swelling. Radio imaging studies were done. Working diagnosis of a branchial cyst in the left inferior parathyroid gland was established. Which of the following pharyngeal pouches gives rise to the parathyroid gland?

B Second pouch Epithelial lining of the palantine tonsil

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy experienced episodes where he develops patches of skin rashes that go away in a week to 10 days. A pediatrician told the boy’s parents to give him niacin the next time this occurred along with a high-protein diet. The rash resolved in a day or two when they did this. Based on the given data, the probable condition that the child has is:
questions.solution:
Hartnup disease (also known as "pellagra-like dermatosis" or "Hartnup disorder") is an autosomal recessive metabolic disorder affecting the absorption & reabsorption of nonpolar amino acids (particularly tryptophan) due to defectiveneutral amino acid transporter SLC6A19. As a result, massive amino aciduria occurs (mainly tryptophan in urine). Soluble carrier family (SLC) proteins are transmembrane proteins involved in facilitated diffusion and secondary active transport.

Tryptophan is used to synthesize serotonin, melatonin, and niacin. The deficiency of niacin leads to pellagra.

Option a: Cystinuria is a different transport defect that will not allow cystine to be absorbed from the diet, or removed from the urine and returned to the blood in the kidney (which can give rise to kidney stones).

Option c: Ornithine translocase deficiency, also called hyperornithinemia-hyperammonemia-homocitrullinuria (HHH) syndrome, is a rare autosomal recessive, urea cycle transporter defect, which causes ammonia to accumulate in the blood.

Option d: Alkaptonuria is due to a defect in homogentisic acid oxidase. The urine of the patient turns black on exposure to air due to enzyme homogentisic acid oxidase Homogentisic acid gets polymerized in the body forming alkapton bodies, which further gets accumulated in cartilages (nose, ear pinna, intervertebral disc). The connective tissue has bluish-black color and the patient develops arthralgia & arthritis.

questions.text: A student researcher is trying to decipher the path of a biochemical reactions that take place in the liver using labelled isotopes.When he supplies nitrogen isotope (14N) labelled glutamate to cultured hepatocytes he finds that the label is first showing up in the oxaloacetate and finally in aspartate after some time. Which of the following substances is most likely involved in this reaction?
questions.solution:
The glutamate is undergoing transamination in which labelled NH3 group is getting transferred to oxaloacetate and then finally to aspartate in a transamination reaction as shown in figure below. In a transamination reaction, amino group is transferred to the α-keto acid from one amino acid, converting the α-keto acid into an amino acid.

Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) in the form of pyridoxal phosphate is a required cofactor for the transaminases as well as decarboxylases in amino acid metabolism.

Option B: Many dehydrogenases use NAD+ and NADP+, formed from vitamin B3 (niacin). Deficiency of niacin causes pellagra characterized by 4 Ds: dermatitis, dementia, diarrhea, and, if untreated, death.

Option A & D: Riboflavin (vitamin B2) as FMN and FAD and Thiamine (vitamin B1) as TPP are used as cofactors of important dehydrogenases such as α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, and pyruvate dehydrogenase in carbohydrate metabolism.

questions.text: A medical student is observing the contraction of skeletal muscle. He notices that each time he administers a stimulus, the muscle contracts for a short time until it relaxes. Upon increasing the frequency of the stimulus, the frequency of these contractions increases until a frequency is reached at which the muscle shows sustained contraction and does not relax. What is the underlying mechanism behind this kind of contraction?

choices.text: Failure of Ca++ removal from the sarcoplasm
Increased activity of sarcoplasmic Ca++ ATPase

questions.solution:
Option B: Failure of Ca++ removal from the sarcoplasm

  • This type of sustained forceful contraction of a muscle is called tetanic contraction.
  • A tetanic is a sustained muscle contraction evoked when the motor nerve that innervates a skeletal muscle emits action potentials at a very high rate.
  • During this state, a motor unit has been maximally stimulated by its motor neuron and remains that way for some time.
  • This occurs when multiple impulses stimulate a muscle's motor unit at a sufficiently high frequency.
  • Each stimulus causes a twitch. If stimuli are delivered at a high frequency, the twitches will overlap, resulting in tetanic contraction.
  • With each stimulus, there is a release of Ca++ from the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) into the sarcoplasm.
  • This Ca++ should be pumped back into the SR for the muscle to relax, which fails to

Option A: Recruitment phenomenon

  • The recruitment phenomenon is a simple means of increasing the force of contraction of a muscle to recruit more muscle fibers.
  • Because all the muscle fibers within a motor unit are activated simultaneously, a muscle recruits more muscle fibers by recruiting more motor units.
  • Increasing the number of motor units will not lead to a tetanic contraction.
  • It will lead to a stronger and more forceful contraction.

Option C: Summation of the stimuli

  • Summation means adding together the individual twitch contractions to increase the intensity of overall muscle contraction.
  • It will also lead to a stronger contraction but not a tetanic contraction.

Option D: Increased activity of sarcoplasmic Ca++ ATPase

  • Increased activity of sarcoplasmic endoplasmic reticulum Ca++ ATPase (SERCA) leads to a decrease in sarcoplasmic Ca++
  • It leads to the transfer of sarcoplasmic Ca++ into the SR
  • This leads to the relaxation of the muscle
  • Once a stimulus comes, it leads to a stronger contraction of the muscle due to the release of already stored Ca++ stores in the SR.

questions.text: A 2-year-old unimmunized child present to a primary health center with fever since 5 days. Mother also give a history of rash starting behind ear- pinna a day before coming to OPD. On examination, child is having running nose and congested eyes. Most probable diagnosis is:-
questions.solution:
MEASLES:-

  • Incubation period: 10 – 14 days
  • Causative agents: RNA paramyxovirus
  • Sources of infection: cases (carriers are not known to occur)
  • Period of communicability :4 days before & 5 days after the appearance of rash (Rash: Retro – auricular origin)
  • Measles has no second attacks (life long immunity seen)
  • Pathognomic clinical feature of measles: Koplik spots (on buccal mucosa opposite lower 2nd molar)
  • Other clinical features: Coryza, fever, Red eye, Cough
  • MC complication of measles in young children: Otitis media.

questions.text: Identify the type of fracture in below image:
questions.solution:
Option A: Hinge fracture

  • A fracture of the base of the skull occurs that completely splits it, creating a hinge (‘nodding face’ sign); frequently occurs with side impacts.
  • It is sometimes referred to as ‘motorcyclists fracture’.
  • The most common form is the one that extends from the petrous bony ridge through sella turcica to the lateral end of the contralateral petrous ridge.

Option B: Ring fracture

  • Associated with fall from height.
  • Fracture lines run around the foramen magnum like a ring.
  • Due to a fracture of the posterior cranial fossa.

Option C: Comminuted

  • Comminuted fracture/spider web fracture: Multiple fracture lines intersecting each other.
  • The bone breaks into pieces that may collide or split and get displaced, like a spider's web or mosaic when there is no fragment displacement.

Option D: Gutter fracture

  • Caused by an oblique bullet tangentially travelling to the skull.
  • Aka glancing bullet.
  • Bullet doesn't enter the skull. It just grooves the skull and doesn't produce a gutter-like fracture.

questions.text: A group of pharmacists is studying different types of antagonism in the laboratory. While studying, they found that 2 different drugs act on 2 different sites in the same cell, and their response is opposite to each other. This drug reaction may be seen in which type of antagonism?
questions.solution:
Option B: Physiological antagonism

  • Two different chemicals acting on different sites of the same cell and resulting in opposite responses in their pharmacological effect is termed physiological antagonism.
  • Example: Histamine acting on H1 receptors causes bronchoconstriction, while adrenaline acting on beta 2 receptors causes bronchodilation.
  • Here, histamine and adrenaline are 2 different drugs that act on 2 different sites (H1 and beta 2 receptors).
  • Both these receptors are present on bronchial smooth muscles but produce an opposite response in their pharmacological effect.

Option A: Chemical antagonism

  • Chemical antagonism occurs when drugs interact chemically in solution, they create an inactive product that lowers the plasma concentration of the free drug.

Option C: Competitive antagonism

  • Here, an agonist and antagonist drug compete to bind the same site on a receptor.
  • Example: Naloxone is a competitive antagonist at all opioid receptors.

Option D: Reversible antagonism

  • Here, a reversible antagonist binds to a receptor non-covalently and can be displaced.
  • Example: Atropine is a reversible competitive antagonist at the muscarinic receptor.

questions.text: A 6 years old child presents to the pediatric OPD with the complaints of high-grade intermittent fever for 10 days associated with erythematous, non-pruritic rash. There is a H/O of myalgia and arthralgia for 4 days. After 7 days, it was noticed that there was central clearing in the rash present on the cheek giving it a slapped cheek appearance. Which virus is responsible for this condition?

choices.text: Non enveloped, linear double stranded DNA.
Non enveloped double stranded circular DNA.
Non enveloped linear single stranded DNA.
Enveloped, single linear double stranded DNA.

questions.solution:
• C) Non-enveloped linear single stranded DNA – Parvovirus causes erythema infectiosum, pure cell red cell aplasia and transient aplastic crisis in patients of sickle cell anemia.
  • Erythema infectiosum is characterized by rash on face which shows slapped cheek appearance.
  • Transient aplastic crisis is characterized by reticulocytopenia, absence of erythroid precursors in bone marrow.
  • Hydrops-fetalis – parvovirus B19 causes 10% to 15% of all cases of non-immune hydrops-fetalis. Parvo B19 DNA can be detected by PCR.

Other options:

A) Non enveloped, linear double stranded DNA - Adenovirus is a non-enveloped virus and has space vehicle appearance.

B) Non enveloped double stranded circular DNA – Human papilloma virus typically infects squamous epithelium and mucous membrane and produces benign and malignant lesions.

D) Enveloped, single linear double stranded DNA – pox virus is the largest virus. It is brick shaped. It is the only DNA virus which replicates in the cytoplasm. It is divided into 4 genre – Orthopox, Parapox, Molluscipox, Yatapox virus.

questions.text: A 45 year old female presented with severe shooting pain on touching the face, chewing, speaking and brushing of teeth. Which of the following drug should be given for the treatment?
questions.solution: Based on the symptoms it is evident that this patient is suffering from trigeminal neuralgia. The drug of choice for trigeminal neuralgia is Carbamazepine .

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with type 2 diabetes mellitus is prescribed pioglitazone. After 2 weeks, there is still no improvement in glycemic control. You counsel the patient that this drug takes time to show effects. Which of the following mechanism of action will you tell the patient to alleviate her concerns?
questions.solution:
Thiazolidinediones (TZDs) like pioglitazone and rosiglitazone are insulin sensitizers and decrease glucose levels by decreasing insulin resistance.

Mechanism of action involves binding of TZDs to peroxisome proliferator activated receptor gamma (PPAR- gamma), a type of nuclear receptor that regulate gene expression after ligand binding and involved in lipid and glucose metabolism. When TZDs bind to PPAR- gamma, receptor undergoes a conformational change and another co activator attaches to it. This complex then binds to transcriptional regulatory sequence of genes involved in glucose and lipid metabolism in a process called transactivation.

The most common gene regulated by PPAR- gamma is adiponectin, a cytokine secreted by fat tissues. Increase in adiponectin levels decrease insulin resistance. Its levels are low in diabetes type 2, and treatment with TZDs increases its levels.

Alteration in gene transcription and protein production takes few days to weeks and thus it takes time for TZDs to show their effects.

Choice A: carbohydrates are absorbed as monosaccharides in intestine. Alpha glucosidase inhibitors (acarbose and miglitol) decrease the enzyme activity of disaccharides found in the plasma membrane of the intestinal brush border. This inhibits disaccharides breakdown and thus decrease carbohydrate absorption.

Choice B: receptor downregulation can be induced by high dose of insulin. This downregulation will result in insulin resistance and hyperglycemia.

Choice C: metformin decreases enzyme activity in gluconeogenesis, decreasing significant decrease in hepatic glucose production.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to his primary care provider complaining of pain and swelling on his right big toe over the past 2 days. Physical examination reveals a reddish, swollen toe with marked tenderness. He denies any history of pharyngitis or a headache. He admits that he drinks alcohol every day and smokes occasionally with friend. He has a history of hypertension for which he takes furosemide tablets. Given the scenario, which of the following is most likely to be found in this patient?

choices.text: Negatively birefringent crystals in the joint
Positively birefringent crystals in the joint

questions.solution:
• In this scenario, the patient most likely has gout.
  • His symptoms (pain and swelling in first metatarsophalangeal joint)and history (taking furosemide tablets, alcohol and lamb consumption) are suggestive of gout.
  • Negatively birefringent urate crystals in the joints are seen in patients with gout.
  • Gout is a type of inflammatory arthritis caused by deposition of urate crystals in the joint.
  • Serum uric acid levels are elevated in patients with gout.
  • First metatarsophalangeal joint is the most common site of an acute gout attack.
  • Risk factors for gout include diet rich in red meat (like beef, lamb and pork), overweight, sea food, medications (such as low-dose aspirin, thiazides, furosemide and cyclosporine) and alcohol consumption.

Incorrect answers

Option A- Pannus formation is associated with rheumatoid arthritis. The symptoms and clinical findings are suggestive of gout.

Option C- Fractures with bony consolidations are associated with Charcot joint. The patient’s history and symptoms are consistent with gout

Option D- Positively birefringent crystals in the joint are found in pseudo gout. In gout negatively birefringent urate crystal are seen.

questions.text: Which of the following is the national level system that provides annual national as well state level reliable estimates of fertility and mortality? (AIIMS 2003, 2005)
questions.solution: Civil registration is continuous and Census is once in ten years. SRS is done annually and measures vital event rates likes birth rate and death rate. It also provides data for other measures of fertility and mortality including total fertility, infant and child mortality rate. It is based on a dual record system.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant female in her 1st trimester presented to the OPD with fever, chills, night sweats, swollen glands and fatigue. On serological examination she was found to be HIV positive. Which of the following is the Next line of management in this condition?

choices.text: Start ART now, continue throughout pregnancy and till 6 weeks after delivery
Start ART now, continue throughout pregnancy and till lifelong
Start ART after First trimester, continue throughout pregnancy and till 6 weeks after delivery
Start ART after First trimester, continue throughout pregnancy and till lifelong

questions.solution:
Start ART now, continue throughout pregnancy and till lifelong

Current guidelines:

  • ART should be started at any CD4 count
    • Any age
    • Any clinical staging
    • Any & all population
  • Preferred first line drugs in adults is Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir.
  • Newborn of HIV +ve mother should be given Zidovudine + Lamivudine + Raltegravir.
  • In HIV +ve pregnant female, start ART As soon as possible, throughout pregnancy & lifelong.
  • To prevent mother to child transmission of HIV, Nevirapine is Drug of choice.

Learning Objective

  • ART should be started at any CD4 count Any age, Any clinical staging, Any & all population.

questions.text: If the fetus is born dead at 5 months, the signs of which one of the following is not identifiable during autopsy?
questions.solution:
Option C: Adipocere

  • Adipocere is not seen in fetuses less than 7 months.

Option A: Putrefaction

  • Internal organs show autolytic decomposition, but the lungs and uterus remain unchanged for a long time.
  • Putrefaction is characterized by an unpleasant odor, greenish discoloration of skin and formation of foul-smelling gases. Rarely, the fetus may show adipocere formation.

Option B: Mummification

  • Mummification: It results from a deficient supply of blood or scanty liquor amnii. The fetus is dried up and shriveled in ≥2 weeks.

Option D: Maceration

  • Maceration: It occurs when the dead child remains in the uterus for about 3–4 days surrounded with liquor amnii with the exclusion of air.

questions.text: An adult male of 38 years is suffering from pulmonary tuberculosis. On testing, it was found that acid fast bacilli isolates are resistant to some antimycobacterial drugs. Ethambutol was started in treatment. What should be tested periodically in such patient?
questions.solution:
Ethambutol is used in treatment of tuberculosis infection both M. tuberculosis and atypical mycobacterial infections. Neuritis is most common side effect manifesting as decreased visual acuity, central scotoma, or colour blindness. Neuritis may be reversible with stoppage of the drug.

Choice B: hepatic toxicity occurs with isoniazid, rifampicin, or pyrazinamide. Therefore, liver function tests are to be monitored.

Choice C: aminoglycoside antibiotics or vancomycin when used for long period can cause ototoxicity. This occurs because of damage to eighth cranial nerve, and results in vertigo, tinnitus and deafness. Along with ototoxicity, aminoglycosides can cause nephrotoxicity. Rarely, these drugs can also cause neuromuscular blockade.

Choice D: chloramphenicol can cause aplastic anemia and dapsone can lead to agranulocytosis. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole can cause megaloblastic anemia as it is folate antagonist.

questions.text: A married couple legally divorces. The woman delivers a child a few months after the divorce. According to the relevant sections of Indian law, the child will be considered legitimate if born within how many days of the dissolution of the marriage?
questions.solution:
Option C: 280 days

  • Legitimate child: A person who is born during the continuance of a legal marriage or within 280 days after the dissolution of the marriage by divorce or death of the husband and the mother remaining unmarried (Sec. 112 IEA).

questions.text: A 60-year-old man came to the hospital complaining of severe pain, swelling and redness at the metatarsophalangeal joint of his left big toe. He has BMI of 34 with history of hypertension. Which of the following drug could be the cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient is showing signs and symptoms of acute gout. As patient is hypertensive, he might be taking thiazide diuretics (chlorthalidone) and long term use of thiazides can cause increase in blood urate levels.

Thiazide diuretics inhibit NaCl transport in the DCT. Most serious adverse effects of thiazides include extracellular volume depletion,hypotension, hypokalemia, hyponatremia, hypochloremia, metabolic alkalosis, hypomagnesemia, hypercalcemia, and hyperuricemia. Because of their tendency to cause hyperuricemia, they can precipitate an acute attack of gout as seen in this patient. Simple review of medication will relieve symptoms of this patient.

A - Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker

B - Lisinopril is an ACE inhibitor

C - Telmisartan is an ARB

(Except chlorthalidone, rest of the drugs have no effect on serum uric acid levels)

questions.text: A 50-year-old business man was admitted to the ICU with the complaints of fever, shortness of breath, and loss of smell for 3 days. After 24 hours he was tachypneic (30/min) with decreased O2 saturation (SPO2-75%) and required emergency intubation. Chest X-ray showed bilateral consolidation and HR-CT showed ground glass appearance. Lab investigations revealed elevated PCT, D-dimer, and ferritin levels. The mechanism of viral entry is by

choices.text: Attachment of the virus with the co-receptor CXCR4 molecule present on T-lymphocytes.
Spike protein(S) binds to angiotensin converting enzyme 2(ACE 2 receptor) on the human cell.
Viral entry into host cells is mediated by binding to CD155 receptors
Binding to host cell intracellular adhesion molecule-1(ICAM-1)

questions.solution:
• The coronavirus spike protein (S) binds to angiotensin converting enzyme 2(ACE 2 receptor) on the human cell.
  • The coronavirus genome is comprised of ∼30000 nucleotides. It encodes four structural proteins, Nucleocapsid (N) protein, Membrane (M) protein, Spike (S) protein and Envelop I protein and several non-structural proteins (nsp).
  • The mechanism of viral entry and replication and RNA packing in the human cell is mapped in Figure 1.
  • The coronavirus spike (S) protein attaches to angiotensin converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) receptors that is found on the surface of many human cells, including those in the lungs allowing virus entry.

Other options:

Choice A – HIV enters the target cell by binding it’s gp120 to the CD 4 receptor to the CD4 receptor on the host cell. A second co-receptor needed for the fusion of HIV is a chemokine receptor which acts by binding to gp120.CXCR4 molecules present on T lymphocyte. CCR5 molecules present on cells of macrophage lineage.

Choice C – Poliovirus is transmitted by feco-oral route. Viral entry into the host cell is mediated by binding to CD155 receptor present on the host cell.

Choice D – Rhinoviruses which cause common cold utilize host cell intracellular adhesion molecule-1(ICAM-1) as receptor.

questions.text:
Match the following types of learning:
Types of learning Association

A. Skills


II. Affective learning
B. Knowledge
