choices.text: I – B, II – A, III – C
I – B, II – C, III – A
I – A, II – C, III – B
I – A, II – B, III – C

questions.solution:
Option B: I – B, II – C, III – A

Learning:

  • Learning is any relatively permanent change in behaviour that occurs as a result of practice or experience.
  • It means acquiring something new - new knowledge, new techniques, new skills, new fears, and new experiences.
  • Types of learning:
Types of learning Associations
Cognitive learning Knowledge
Affective learning Attitudes
Psychomotor learning Skills

Other options are incorrect

questions.text: A Female health worker has to teach women in Urban slum about ORS preparation. Best method will be
questions.solution:
Demonstration  → Is a carefully planned presentation where idea is to show ‘ how to perform’ a skill/procedure

Two principle  -

1. Seeing is believing                                   

2.  learning by doing

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with purpuric skin lesions, abdominal pain, intestinal bleeding, and arthralgias. He was delivered via a spontaneous vaginal delivery and has achieved all the developmental milestones appropriately. The immunofluorescence picture given below demonstrates IgA deposition in the mesangium. Which of the following is the most likely working diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Henoch Schönlein purpura (HSP)

  • Childhood syndrome is most common between 3-8 years of age.
  • It can also occur in adults, in whom renal manifestations are more severe.
  • Consists of purpuric skin lesions, abdominal pain and intestinal bleeding, arthralgias, and renal abnormalities.
  • M/E -Renal lesions vary from mild focal mesangial proliferation to diffuse mesangial or endocapillary proliferation to crescentic glomerulonephritis.

Option A: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)

  • Nephrotic syndrome and concomitant sclerosis of some localized segments of the glomeruli are its defining features.
  • It can be idiopathic or develop as a result of the following conditions:
  • Sickle cell disease, heroin usage, obesity, and HIV.

Option B: Minimal change disease (MCD)

  • In children, it is the most frequent cause of nephrotic syndrome.
  • The condition may be idiopathic or have a trigger, such as:
  • Immunization
  • Infection

Option C: Alport syndrome

  • The following are characteristics of Alport syndrome:
  • Errors in the gene that codes for the type IV collagen α5 chain.
  • The clinical signs include kidney, ear, and eye-related abnormalities.
  • The BM's distinctive basket-weave appearance.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman admitted with right lower lobe pneumonia subsequently develop lactic acidosis and hypotension. Norepinephrine IV drip is started, but after few hours, the antecubital vein used for infusion blanches and the surrounding tissue becomes hard, cold and pale. Which of the following agents if injected locally will be most beneficial?
questions.solution:
The signs of norepinephrine extravasation are blanching of the vein in which norepinephrine (NE) is infused and induration and pallor of the surrounding tissue. The norepinephrine leaks and causes intense alpha 1 receptor mediated vasoconstriction which can lead to local tissue necrosis. Phentolamine mesylate is an alpha 1 receptor blocker and counteracts the effects of alpha 1 receptor mediated vasoconstriction of NE. Such necrosis can be prevented by infiltration of 10 – 15 ml of normal saline containing 5 – 10 mg of phentolamine mesylate. The antidote is given using a fine hypodermic needle and must be administered within 12 hours of extravasation to be effective.

Choice A: calcium gluconate is administered in severe hypocalcemia and would not lead to the desired effects of vasodilation.

Choice C: lidocaine can relax vascular smooth muscle via Na+ current mediated action potentials but tend to be less effective in ischemic, acidotic tissues. The most direct and effective treatment for this patient remains an alpha blocker, phentolamine.

Choice D: heparin does not cause significant vasodilation and is indicated in arterial thrombosis.

questions.text: Being an intern, you were asked to carry the urgent blood sample from ICU. While handing over the sample to your strict microbiologist professor, you contaminated the sterile endoscope kept over there. Now the microbiologist questioned which of the following is used for its sterilization?
questions.solution:
Formaldehyde: It is best used for:

  • Preservation of anatomical specimen
  • Formaldehyde gas is used for fumigation of closed areas such as operation theatres
  • Preparation of toxoid from toxin. It is toxic, irritant and corrosive to metals.

Ethylene oxide:

  • It is a colourless liquid used for gaseous sterilization.
  • It is active against all kinds of bacteria, spores, and viruses.
  • It kills all types of microorganisms by inhibiting proteins and nucleic acids.
  • It is both microbicidal and sporicidal.
  • It is a highly effective sterilizing agent because it rapidly penetrates packing materials, including plastic wraps.
  • It is used to sterilize disposable plastic Petri dishes, sutures, syringes, heart-lung machine, respirators, and dental equipment

Glutaraldehyde

  • It is less toxic, less irritant and less corrosive, hence is best used to sterilize endoscopes and cystoscopes.
  • It is used as 2% concentration (2% cidex) for 20 min.
  • It has to be activated by alkalinisation before use. Once activated, it remains active only for 14 days.

Gamma rays used for:

  • Disposable plastics, e.g. rubber or plastic syringes, infusion sets and catheters.
  • Catgut sutures, bone and tissue grafts and adhesive dressings, antibiotics and hormones.

questions.text: In a woman using an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) an intrauterine pregnancy occurs and the IUCD threads are visible. What is the reason to recommend the removal of the device?

choices.text: To prevent the risk of subsequent septic abortion and preterm labor
To prevent congenital abnormality in the newborn

questions.solution:
Option A: To prevent the risk of subsequent septic abortion and preterm labor

  • However, there may be an increased risk of infection and preterm labor.
  • Hence, it is recommended to remove the device.

Option B: To prevent congenital abnormality in the newborn

  • There is no teratogenic risk with a retained IUCD.

Option C: To prevent post-partum hemorrhage

  • There is no risk of hemorrhage.
  • In Ectopic pregnancies are dangerous because of the high risk of rupture and hemorrhage. If ectopic pregnancy occurs, the risks for the patient include severe pain, infection, and even death.

Option D: To prevent perforation

  • In the early stage of pregnancy, there is no risk of perforation until the misplacement of the IUD noted

questions.text: A 40-year-old man has committed suicide by consuming some chemical he was able to procure from the paint-making factory he works at. The doctor notices the garlicky odor from the tissues and decided to preserve the hair for further investigation. Poisoning with which one of the following requires preservation of the hair?
questions.solution:
Option A: Arsenic

  • Hair: Arsenic > 75 µg% is suggestive of poisoning.
  • GI symptoms of Arsenic: Sweetish metallic taste, nausea, persistent vomiting, burning in mouth and throat, and difficulty in swallowing, garlic odor in breath, intense thirst, pain in esophagus and abdomen, purging accompanied by tenesmus, pain and irritation about the anus.
  • Initially, defecation is frequent and involuntary, dark-colored, but later it become colorless, odorless and watery resembling rice-water.

Option B/C/D: Manganese/ Phosphorous/ Alcohol

  • Preservation of hair is not required in the above given poisons.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male comes to his primary care physician because of difficulty in breathing. He says that he experiences tightness in the chest. The patient has experienced similar episodes in the past. The patient has a productive cough. His past medical history is significant forhypertension. The patient admits that he smokes 1 pack of cigarette every day. His temperature is 98.6 F, pulse is 104/min and respirations are 24/min.The chest x-ray shows hyperinflation of the lungs. Physical examination reveals excess mucous production and bilateral expiratory wheezing. Microscopic examination of the sputum sample is performed (shown in fig(i)). Given the scenario, which of following is most likely associated with the pathogenesis of this disease?
questions.solution:
• This patient exhibits signs and symptoms of asthma. Hyperinflation of the lungs on chest x-ray and Charcot Leyden crystals on sputum sample are suggestive of asthma.
  • Asthma is a chronic inflammatory condition of the airways.
  • Asthma is a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction. Leukotriene D4 is associated with asthma. · Leukotrienes induce bronchoconstriction, increased secretion of mucus and airflow obstruction.
  • The common causes of asthma include exercise, infection, airborne allergens (like mold spores, dust mites and pollen), air pollutants and cold air.
  • The histopathological findings in patient with asthma include- Curshmann’s spirals, Charcot Leyden crystals, hypertrophy of bronchial smooth muscles and submucosal glands and thickened reticular basement membrane.
  • Figure demonstrates a sputum sample with Charcot Leyden crystals.

Option A- Interferon gamma is not associated with the pathogenesis of asthma. The excessive release of Interferon gamma is associated with the pathogenesis of several autoimmune and inflammatory diseases.

Option B- Alpha 1 antitrypsin is a protein produced by liver. Its function is to protect the lungs from elastase. Alpha anti trypsin is not associated with the pathogenesis of this disease.

Option D- Elastase is associated with the pathogenesis of panacinar emphysema. In this scenario, the clinical findings are suggestive of asthma

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl, Jane, is brought to the hospital because of nausea, vomiting and dizziness associated with mild abdominal pain and headache. Her temperature is normal, respirations 21/min, blood pressure 108/63 and pulse 110/min. Her lung sounds are normal on auscultation. She is lethargic and sleepy. Her Father informs the doctor that he suspects his daughter has exposed to carbon tetrachloride (a dry-cleaning agent) as he found her near an opened can of carbon tetrachloride. Which of the following is mostly affected due to carbon tetrachloride consumption?
questions.solution:
• The girl has consumed carbon tetrachloride. Carbon tetrachloride is a dry-cleaning agent.
  • Carbon tetrachloride is a hepatotoxic agent.
  • Free radical injury to hepatocytes are caused by carbon tetrachloride.
  • Free Radicals are molecules that have an unpaired electron. Free radicals are highly unstable and causes damage to cell membrane and DNA.
  • Carbon tetrachloride can produce free radicals. Carbon tetrachloride can cause serious damages to liver by forming reactive free radicals.
  • Therefore, immediate liver function tests are advised for patients who are exposed to carbon tetrachloride.
  • Prolonged exposure to carbon tetrachloride leads to fatty liver or steatosis.

Option A-Carbon tetrachloride mainly causes damage to liver, kidney and central nervous system. Carbon tetrachloride usually don’t affect the lung parenchyma. Chemotherapeutic drugs (such as busulfan and carmustine) can adversely affect the lung parenchyma.

Option C-Free Radicals usually don’t affect bone marrow. Several chemotherapeutic drugs suppress the bone marrow

Option D- Carbon tetrachloride usually causes damage to liver, kidney and central nervous system. Carbon tetrachloride usually don’t affect myocardium.

questions.text: A 54 year old patient presented with jaundice( raised direct bilirubin) and presence of pANCA antibody. Liver biopsy shows circumferential onion skin fibrosis around duct as shown in the diagram. What is your diagnosis:
questions.solution: The smaller ducts, however, often have little inflammation and show a striking circumferential “onion skin” fibrosis around an increasingly atrophic duct lumen eventually leading to obliteration by a “tombstone” scar.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presented with complaint of severe chest pain in the emergency room. He gives history of taking 2 antacid tablets at home but there was no relief. On examination his blood pressure was 168/112 mmHg and pulse rate was 98/ min. ECG was done which revealed ST segment depression in lead II, III and aVF. A drug was started as part of his treatment. Which of the following substances does this drug binds in patient’s blood to start action?
questions.solution:
This is a case of myocardial infarction and the most likely drug given to this patient is enoxaparin. Enoxaparin is a low molecular weight heparin that acts by activating Antithrombin III. Antithrombin III binds to factor Xa and inhibits it. Factor Xa is responsible for converting prothrombin to thrombin. Thus, inhibition of factor Xa occurs by Antithrombin III and thrombus formation stops, resulting in anticoagulant effects.

Choice A: tissue plasminogen activator (t- PA) converts plasminogen to plasmin that further causes degradation of fibrin. This causes break down of clots. The t-PA binds to plasminogen only in presence of fibrin, so this effect is clot specific.

Choice C: thrombolytic agents like streptokinase and urokinase binds to plasminogen and cleaves it to form plasmin. This causes breakage of clots.

Choice D : prothrombin or factor II is Vitamin K dependent factor. Warfarin depletes factor II, VII, IX and X

Choice E: protein C and S are vitamin K dependent molecules with antithrombotic properties. These molecules have short half lives in blood and are depleted first during start of warfarin treatment. This causes transient procoagulant state. Therefore, patients need to be treated with enoxaparin or heparin first when warfarin therapy started.

questions.text: Programmed cell death is usually initiated by mitochondrial pathway and death receptor pathway. The component which have a common role in both processes is-
questions.solution:
• The component which has a common role in both intrinsic and extrinsic pathway of apoptosis is caspase.
  • Extrinsic pathway (also known as death receptor pathways) of apoptosis is activated by receptor –ligand interactions.
  • The intrinsic pathway (also known as mitochondrial pathway) of apoptosis can be activated by various exogenous or endogenous stimuli (like free radicals, toxins, DNA damage) which give rise to certain intracellular signals that can act directly on the targets present within the cells.
  • Apoptosis is an active process that needs energy from ATP hydrolysis. Apoptosis and necrosis may take place concurrently, independently. Unlike apoptosis, necrosis is a passive, degradative process. Apoptosis can be induced by low doses of stimuli. Higher doses of the same stimulus may induce necrosis.
  • Caspases are proteolytic enzymes which have a major role in apoptosis. Caspase can act as inflammatory mediator. They also have a role in the maintenance of T-cells and tissue differentiation/regeneration

Option A: Bax is a pro-apoptotic factor which is a member of Bcl-2 family. Bax is involved in the intrinsic pathway of apoptosis

Option C : Fasligand is transmembrane protein. Binding of Fasligand to death receptor initiates extrinsic pathway of apoptosis

Option D : CD95 is a surface receptor. CD95 is also known as Fas receptor. Extrinsic pathway is initiated when Fas ligand binds to CD95 receptor.

questions.text: In the given image; what does 'Z' denote?
questions.solution:
• 'Z' denotes AUC
  • AUC tells about the extent of absorption of the drug.
  • T max tells about the time to reach maximum concentration, i.e. rate of absorption.
  • C max is the maximum concentration of a drug obtained after giving a particular dose.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presented with hypertension due to renal artery involvement and ANCA  negative, histological examination of the vessel is shown in the diagram. What is your diagnosis:
questions.solution: In PAN there is transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with a mixed infiltrate of neutrophils, eosinophils, and mononuclear cells, frequently accompanied by fibrinoid necrosis

questions.text:
A suraksha clinic is providing STD kits free of cost. Match the following pre-packed Sexually transmitted infections STD Kits with their respective colour coding's?

questions.text: A 57-year-old patient present with throbbing headache on one side associated with partial loss of Vision and clinical investigation revealed raised ESR. After Conservative therapy biopsy was taken from the lesion ( shown in diagram). What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Giant cell arteritis

  • Involved arterial segments develop intimal thickening(with occasional thromboses) that reduces the luminal diameter.
  • Classic lesions exhibit medial granulomatous inflammation centered  on  the  internal  elastic  lamina  that  produce  elastic lamina fragmentation; 
  • There is an infiltrate of T cells  (CD4+>CD8+)and macrophages.
  • Although multinucleated giant cells are seen in approximately 75% of adequately biopsied specimens.

questions.text: A patient of prinzmetal’s angina is started on isosorbide mononitrate. What is the mechanism of action of nitrates in this condition?

choices.text: Increased left ventricular end diastolic volume

questions.solution:
Prinzmetal’s angina is due to spasm of main coronary artery.

Treatment is by dilatation of coronary artery.

Endothelium normally generates NO, but here we are giving nitrates for generation of NO.

Mechanism of action of nitrates:

  • Preload reduction >> Afterload reduction
  • Redistribution of coronary flow in the arterial tree action may cause favorable redistribution of blood flow to ischaemic areas in angina patients.

questions.text: A 55-year-old cave explorer visits the physician OPD with the complaints of chills, non-productive cough, and skin lesions for 5 days. He gives a history of travel to a bird sanctuary in South America 15 days back. Chest X-ray reveals patchy infiltrate with hilar lymphadenopathy. Histopathological examination of lymph nodes revealed tiny oval yeast cells within macrophages. Fungal culture after week showed mycelial growth. Lactophenol Cotton Blue mount revealed tuberculate conidia with thick walls and finger like projections. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D.

Histoplasmosis:

  • Caused by dimorphic fungi Histoplasma capsulatum.
  • Occurs worldwide but endemic in USA.

Lab diagnosis: Histopathological examination reveals tiny oval yeast cells with narrow based budding present inside the macrophages.

Culture: Gold standard diagnostic method

  • As it is a dimorphic fungus, it is seen in two forms
  • At 37*c it is seen as yeast form i.e. creamy white colonies.
  • At 25*c it is seen as white to buff brown colonies and has two conidia (1) Tuberculate macroconidia with finger like projections, (2) Microconidia are small and smooth walled.

Others:

Option A

  • Paracoccidiodomycosis: culture on SDA
  • At 25*c – mycelium form.
  • At 37*c – yeast form appearance, resembles mickey mouse or pilot wheel.

Option B

  • Coccidioidomycosis: culture on SDA
  • Grows as a mould at both 25*c and 37*c.
  • Forms spherules at 37*c.

Option C:

  • Blastomycosis – growth on SDA
  • At 25*c – mycelium with small pear-shaped conidia.
  • At 37*c – mould to yeast conversion occurs.

questions.text: A 42-year-old obese female presented to the rural PHC. Which of the following is the appropriate statistical test to find out whether obesity is a significant risk factor for breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Option D: Wilcoxon’s signed rank test

  • The Wilcoxon signed-rank test is a non-parametric statistical hypothesis test used either to test the location of a population based on a sample of data, or to compare the locations of two populations using two matched samples.
  • The one-sample version serves a purpose similar to that of the one-sample Student's t-test. 
  • For two matched samples, it is a paired difference test like the paired Student's t-test (also known as the "t-test for matched pairs" or "t-test for dependent samples"). 

Other options

Option A: Student’s paired ‘t’ test

  • Paired Student’s t-test: Comparing means (+ SD) in paired data (in the same group of individuals before and after an intervention).

Option B: Student’s unpaired ‘t’ test

  • Unpaired Student’s t-test: Comparing means (+ SD) in two different groups of individuals.

Option C: Chi-square test

  • CHI-SQUARE TEST is used to test the significance of the association between 2 or more qualitative characteristics.
  • Obesity and Breast cancer are qualitative variables.
  • This option is incorrect as 2 groups required

questions.text: Histopathological diagram of lesion showing characteristic intracytoplasmic viral inclusion bodies of which virus?
questions.solution:
• Molluscum contagiosum may affect any area of the skin but is most common on the trunk, arms, and legs.
• The diagnosis of molluscum contagiosum is clinical based on the characteristic appearance of dome-shaped ,pearly papules with an umblicated center.
• The papules are 1 to 5 mm in diameter, and the central waxy core of papules contains cells with cytoplasmic viral inclusions bodies.
• These ellipsoid inclusions are seen in stratum corneum/granulosum layers of skin and are called "molluscum bodies".

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presented with difficulty in breathing and rashes after ingestion sea food. He has shown similar reaction in the past following consumption of the same food items. Which of the following hypersensitivity reaction do you relate with this?
questions.solution:
• Type 1 Hypersensitivity seen in, Allergy (sea food, Peanuts)
  • Type 1 Hypersensitivity might be associated with Anaphylaxis which is treated with Adrenaline (Drug of choice) 0.5 ml (conc -1:1000) Intramuscularly.
  • Type 2 Hypersensitivity is antibody mediated.
  • Type 4 Hypersensitivity is associated with delayed type hypersensitivity and CD 8 T cell activation.

questions.text: Specific, preplanned activity in a Health program is known as
questions.solution:
Objective : is planned en – point of all activities

  • Is precise AND ‘specific’
  • Is either achieved not achieved
  • Is concerned with the problem itself
  • Target : A discrete activity which helps measure the extent of attainment of objective ; Is a ‘concept of degree of achievement ’
  • Goal : ‘ Ultimate desired state ’ toward which objective and resources are directed ; shows ‘all or none phenomenon ’
  • Impact : Is an expression of the positive effects of a programme, services or the institution on the overall health development and on related social and economic development

questions.text: The following test, used for the Screening of a common cancer is
questions.solution:
Pap smear is screening test for cervical cancer. And Ayer’s Spatula it is a secondary level prevention

  • Diagnosis is confirm by Colposcopic punch biopsy

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presented to the emergency with complaints of fever and painful muscle stiffness since yesterday after sustaining an injury at the roadside. He was unable to swallow anything. The patient had a locked jaw, hypertonic muscles, and brisk deep tendon reflexes on physical examination. After half an hour, he developed a seizure while remaining in detention. He is admitted, and further evaluation reveals a gram stain of the causative organism, shown in the image below. Which of the following is an important part of management in this case?

choices.text: Tight stitches without any wound debridement

questions.solution:
Option B: Intramuscular tetanus immunoglobulin

  • The scenario mentioned above shows tetanus, and the drumstick appearance of Clostridium tetani in the image confirms the diagnosis.
  • Tetanus immunoglobulin is given to prevent the progression of the disease.
  • It neutralizes tetanospasmin, which causes muscle spasms
  •  The recommended dose of tetanus immunoglobulin is 250 IU if ≤24 hours after the injury and 500 IU if >24 hours after the injury.
  • A primary series of tetanus-containing vaccines with boosters every 10 years is needed for long-lasting protection.
  • Clostridium tetani is a gram-positive, spore-forming rod, a common soil bacteria. It causes tetanus through tetanospasmin and tetanolysin. Tetanoplasmin acts by blocking the release of Glycine and GABA at motor nerve endings. This causes a spasm of muscles.
  • Tetanus has no cure. Treatment is supportive while the disease runs its course. The patient is admitted to ICU set up.
  • Wound debridement is done to prevent the further growth of bacteria.
  • An anti-toxin is given intramuscularly to neutralize the circulating toxin
  • Antibiotics and sedatives are also given.

Option A: Hyperbaric oxygen

  • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy increases the amount of oxygen your blood can carry.
  • It has no role in the treatment of tetanus.
  • However, it treats CO poisoning, cyanide poisoning, gas gangrene, and decompression sickness.

Option C: Amphotericin B

  • Amphotericin B is an anti-fungal medication.
  • In tetanus, antibiotics are used.
  • Metronidazole is an antibiotic used in the treatment of various infections.
  • Metronidazole 500mg IV every 6 to 8 hours is the treatment of choice for tetanus.
  • It prevents the local proliferation of C. Tetani.

Option D: Tight stitches without any wound debridement

  • Wound debridement is done to prevent the further growth of bacteria.
  • If debridement is indicated, it should be undertaken only after stabilizing the patient. The current recommendation is to excise at least 2 cm of normal viable-appearing tissue around the wound margins.

questions.text: The body of the 63-year-old man who was a known case of adenocarcinoma of the stomach has been sent for an autopsy. He had been diagnosed with cancer after an esophagogastroduodenoscopy was done 3 years ago. The forensic doctor will now examine the stomach after performing which of the following procedures?
questions.solution:
Option A: Double ligation

  • Since the stomach is connected both to the esophagus and duodenum so double ligature along the greater curvature of the stomach is usually done.

Option B: Single ligation

  • Since the stomach is connected both to the esophagus and duodenum, single ligation is not useful here.

Option C: Cut open

  • Since the stomach is connected both to the esophagus and duodenum, the cut open technique is not usually done to take the stomach.

Option D: Triple ligation

  • Since the stomach is connected both to the esophagus and duodenum, triple ligation is not useful here.

questions.text: A 45-year-old HIV positive male who is a resident of Canada visits the local hospital with the C/O fever associated with cough for 15 days. He did not respond to treatment with antibiotics and was negative for tuberculosis. Lung biopsy was performed and the patient was diagnosed to be suffering from blastomycosis. Amphotericin B infusion was prescribed as therapy. Which of the following is the best measure to be taken prior to catheter insertion?
questions.solution:
Hand hygiene is the first step to be performed before any procedure. This helps in eliminating the transient flora.

Bacteria recovered from the hands can be divided into two categories

  1. Transient flora - Transient flora is not part of normal flora and colonizes the superficial layer of the skin. It is acquired by HCWs during direct contact with patient or contaminated environmental surfaces.
  2. Resident Flora - Resident flora consists of microorganisms living under the superficial cells of stratum corneum.

Steps of hand hygiene

Other options-

A) Disinfect skin with 2% chlorhexidine-Skin must be disinfected with a single-use sterile applicator containing a solution of 2% chlorhexidine in 70% isopropyl alcohol and the site is allowed to dry before catheter insertion.

B) Use sterile, semi-permeable transparent dressing-This gives the advantage of allowing inspection of site without the removal of dressing. This dressing should be changed every 7 days.

C) Use of antimicrobial coated catheter-In adults, peripheral venous catheter sites should be changed every 96 hours to minimize the risk of phlebitis. It is also minimized by using antibiotic coated catheters.

WHO 5 MomentsforHand Hygiene

  1. Before touching a patient,
  2. Before clean/aseptic procedures,
  3. After body fluid exposure/risk,
  4. After touching a patient, and.
  5. After touching patient surroundings.

questions.text: A 64-year-old male is brought to the emergency department complaining of pain in the left knee. The patient informs the physician that he has severe pain in the left knee for the last three days. On examination, the left knee is swollen and has tenderness to palpation. The patient denies any trauma to the knee. He admits that he smokes 2 packs of cigarettes every day and drinks occasionally with friends. An X ray of the left knee reveals chondrocalcinosis. Synovial fluid analysis is performed and the results are shown in Figure. Which of the following is most likely the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
• This patient with severe pain and swelling in the joints most likely has calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease.
  • Calcium pyrophosphate deposition is also known as pseudogout. In patients with pseudogout, synovial fluid analysis shows positive birefringent rhomboid shaped crystals.
  • Pseudogout is a type of arthritis that is caused by the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate dehydrate crystals.
  • The most commonly affected joint in patients with pseudogout is knee joint.
  • The signs and symptoms of this disease include severe joint pain, swollen and tender joint.
  • X-ray of the affected joint may show chondrocalcinosis.
  • Chondrocalcinosis is a condition that is characterized by deposition of calcium within the joint cartilage.
  • Negatively birefringent crystals are associated with gout whereas pseudogout has positively birefringent crystals on joint aspiration.
  • FIGURE demonstrates positively birefringent rhomboid shaped crystals under polarized light.

Option B- Positively birefringent rhomboid shaped crystals are not expected in patients with osteoarthritis. The clinical findings are consistent with pseudogout.

Option C- In patients with rheumatoid arthritis, the plain radiograph may show periarticular bony erosions. Positively birefringent rhomboid shaped crystals are not expected in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

Option D- In patients with gout, negatively birefringent crystals are found on joint aspiration.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male paddy field worker presents to the physician with complaints of fever, abdominal pain, chills, muscle ache, jaundice and vomiting for 5 days. He gives a history of no other abnormalities. He has no history of any chronic illnesses. He is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. The patient was sent to the laboratory for sample testing, and the microbiologist found the causative organism, as shown in the image below. Which of the following organism is involved in the patient's pathology?
questions.solution:
Option B: Leptospira

  • This is a case of leptospirosis in which the patient presents with complaints of fever, abdominal pain, chills, muscle ache, jaundice and vomiting for 5 days.
  • Leptospirosis is an infection caused by corkscrew-shaped bacteria called Leptospira.
  • Associated with:
    • R → Rat urine
    • R → Rice [Paddy fieldworkers]
    • R → Rainy water
  • Leptospira interrogates → causes Weil’s disease (Ictero Haemorrhagic fever)

Culture media :

  • EMOJI
  • Fletcher
  • Kortakoff
  • Dark ground microscopy for Spirochetes:

Option A: Treponema pallidum

  • Treponema pallidum appears as slender, spirally coiled bacilli with a tapering end.
  • It is one of the leading causes of syphilis worldwide.
  • It is usually transmitted via sexual intercourse.

Option C: Borrelia

  • Borrelia appears tightly coiled and thin.
  • Relapsing fever is a recurrent fever caused by Borrelia recurrentis.

Option D: Brucella

  • Brucella is a gram-negative coccobacillus, zoonotic.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presented to the clinic with a complaint of urinary incontinence. He was started on a new drug Mirabegron which is a beta 3 receptor agonist approved for use against incontinence. All of the following is true regarding Mirabegron EXCEPT:

choices.text: It increases the incidence of urinary tract infections

questions.solution:
Mirabegronis a β3 adrenergic receptor agonist approved for use against incontinence. Activation of this receptor in the bladder leads to detrusor muscle relaxation and increased bladder capacity. This action prevents voiding and provides relief for those with an overactive bladder and urinary incontinence.

Side effects include increased blood pressure, increased incidence of urinary tract infection, and headache. Mirabegron is also a moderate CYP2D6 inhibitor, so care must be taken when prescribing with other drugs metabolized by CYP2D6, such as digoxin, metoprolol, and desipramine.

A Mirabegronis can cause rise in blood pressure

B It is associated with increase in incidence of urinary tract infection

C It is associated with adverse effect of headache

D It is a CYP2D6 inhibitor

questions.text: A 26-year-old patient presented with proteinuria, hematuria. PAS stain of renal biopsy demonstrates characteristic histological findings of which disease:
questions.solution: The histologic picture, however, is dominated by distinctive crescents. Crescents are formed by proliferation of parietal cells and by migration of monocytes and macrophages into the urinary space. Neutrophils and lymphocytes may be present. The crescents may obliterate the urinary space and compress the glomerular tuft. Fibrin strands are frequently prominent between the cellular layers in the crescents.

questions.text: A 50-year-old businessman was admitted to the ICU with complaints of fever, shortness of breath, and loss of smell for 3 days. After 24 hours he was tachypneic (30/min) with decreased O2 saturation (SPO2-75%) and required emergency intubation. Chest X-ray showed bilateral consolidation and HR-CT showed ground-glass appearance. which of the following antibody participates in specific immunity to this respiratory viral disease?
questions.solution:
• It is the major immunoglobulin in milk, saliva, tears, mucosal secretions, sweat, gastric fluid, and colostrum
  • Therefore, it is the main antibody against those organisms which cause infection through mucosal lining (respiratory tract, GI tract etc.)

questions.text: A woman died in her room. Her room was unlocked. Her alcohol levels were 150 mg%. The image is shown below. On neck dissection, there was a contusion present. What is the cause of the death?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Throttling:

  • On neck dissection, there was a contusion present which can also be seen in the given picture; suggestive of throttling or manual strangulation.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Smothering:

  • Smothering: Death from mechanical occlusion of the mouth and nose, excluded.

Option C - Cafe coronary:

  • Café coronary: Sudden and unexpected death occurring during a meal due to accidental occlusion of the airway by food.
  • No signs of airway obstruction are given in the question moreover contusion is present over the neck which cannot be explained by café coronary, so excluded.

Option D - Alcohol intoxication:

  • She is under alcohol intoxication but the level is not sufficient to cause death.
  • Moreover, contusion present over the neck cannot be explained by alcohol intoxication, so excluded.

questions.text: A 17-year-old is brought to hospital after his parents noticed unusual behavior in their child. His parents informed that the boy used to be very calm and quiet. But for the last 2 months he has been very aggressive and irritated. The boy lashes out at his parents most of the days. His parents noticed that the boy finds it difficult to swallow food. The physician notices mild tremor in the patient. The patient’s movement appears slow and rigid. The patient is found to have cirrhosis. The patient is anemic and have low serum ceruloplasmin levels. Based on the findings the which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient with neuropsychiatric symptoms, dysphagia, anemia, low serum ceruloplasmin levels and tremors is most likely to have Wilson disease.
  • Wilson disease is a rare genetic disorder of copper metabolism. It is an autosomal recessive disorder in which excessive amounts of copper accumulates in various organs such as liver brain and eye.
  • .The copper deposits in the eye resulting in the formation of Keyser Fleischer ring. Wilson Disease is generally treated with copper chelating agents like penicillamine and trientine.

Option A- Reye syndrome is a rare disorder mainly seen in children. It is a serious condition that cause severe damage to brain and liver

Option B-Congenital hepatic fibrosis is a rare disorder that affects liver. It is usually present at birth

Option C-Primary sclerosing cholangitis is chronic disease that affects bile ducts. Ulcerative colitis is seen in most of the patients with this disease.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the urology department with the C/O hematuria and flank pain for 10 days. Pelvic CT scan showed diffuse asymmetrical wall thickening and calcification of urinary bladder. Blood investigations showed eosinophilia without anemia. Cystoscopy showed “sandy patches appearance”. Urine microscopy revealed the presence of non-operculated terminal spined eggs in urine. Which animal is most likely source of infection?
questions.solution:
• Snail – Schistosomes are known blood flukes as they live in the vascular system of humans. Adult worm lives in the venous plexuses of definitive host i.e. human or animals. Snails are the intermediate host.
  • Schistosomes Definitive host-Man and other animals
  • Intermediate host (various genera of snail)

Distribution

African schistosomes

  • Schistosoma haematobium – Definitive host- Man, monkey, chimpanzee, Intermediate host-Bulinus
  • Schistosoma mansoni – Definitive host- Man, monkey, chimpanzee and dog, Intermediate host -Biomphalaria (Snail)
  • Schistosoma intercalatum –Definitive Host-Man, Intermediate host-Bulinus

Asian schistosomes

  • Schistosoma japonicum – Definitive host -Man, dog, cat and rodent, Intermediate host -Oncomelania
  • Schistosomamalayensis – Definitive host- Man and rodent, Intermediate host- Robertsiella
  • Schistosoma mekongi- Definitive host- Man and dog, Intermediate host- Neotricula.
  • Drug of choice for treatment of schistosomiasis is praziquantel.

Other options:

A) Dog – Echinococcus causes hydatid disease in man. Echinococcus granulosus is also called as dog tapeworm. Its life cycle passes through two hosts i.e. definitive host – dogs and other canine animals. Intermediate host – sheep and another herbivore. Man is the accidental host.

C) Cat – Toxoplasmagondii is an obligate intracellular parasite. Life cycle involves two hosts. Definitive host – cat and other felines. Intermediate host – man and other mammals.

D) Aquatic plants – Fasciolopsis buski is also known as giant intestinal fluke. It completes its life cycle in definitive host pig or man and 2 intermediate hosts- 1st is a snail and 2nd are aquatic plants.

questions.text: 56 years old diabetic patients has chronic renal failure, and is undergoing hemodialysis. Which of the following amyloid most likely to get deposited?
questions.solution:
• Commonest reason for Chronic kidney disease in India & Globally is Diabetes Mellitus.
  • Earlier machines, which are used for Hemodialysis, are not able to filter Beta 2 Microglobulin, therefore gradually the level of Beta 2 Microglobulin will increase in blood and are likely to be get deposited in the form of Amyloid.
  • AA is associated with secondary Amyloidosis which are associated with Chronic inflammatory condition/chronic infections and Hodgkin, Renal cancers.
  • A Beta deposition is seen in an individual with Alzheimer’s disease
  • A Cal (Calcitonin) is seen in patients with Medullary Thyroid Cancer which arises from Parafollicular cells

Elevated levels of Calcitonin is seen.

Calcitonin is tumor marker for Medullary Thyroid cancer.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presents to the emergency department with the chief complaint of dysuria, nausea and vomiting for the past two days and have been progressively worsening. She is diabetic and hypertensive as well. On physical examination, she is notable for left-sided costovertebral angle tenderness. Lab investigations demonstrates bacteriuria and pyuria and elevated differential count. The patient is admitted to the hospital and started on IV antibiotics. 3 days later her urine culture results found positive to K. pneumoniae. What type of growth could have been seen in culture plate?

choices.text: Green metallic sheen on EMB agar
Red pigment production on synthetic media
Large mucoid capsule and viscous colonies

questions.solution:
• Large mucoid capsule and viscous colonies is the characteristics growth of K. pneumoniae.
  • Women with diabetes have a two- to threefold higher rate of ASB and UTI than women without diabetes
  • Increased duration of diabetes and the use of insulin rather than oral medication are associated with an elevated risk of UTI among women with diabetes.
  • Poor bladder function, obstruction in urinary flow, and incomplete voiding are additional factors commonly found in patients with diabetes that increase the risk of UTI.

Choice A: Green metallic sheen on EMB agar. This type of colony is seen in E. coli and it is the most common cause of UTI.

Choice B: Red pigment production on synthetic media is the characteristics of Serratia marcescens

Choice C: “Swarming” appearance on agar is seen by the growth of proteus mirabilis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old chronic smoker male presented complaints of left-sided facial swelling for the past 4 years. On examination, a marble-sized firm and non-tender mass is noticed beneath his left ear. A diagnosis is made by biopsy, and the mass is eventually excised. Which of the following is this patient's most likely benign parotid gland disease?

choices.text: Glandular hypertrophy, secondary to vitamin A deficiency

questions.solution:
Option D: Papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum

  • This 60-year-old male, who has a 40-pack-year history of smoking, presented with a marble-sized mass beneath his left ear. This diagnosis is consistent with papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum, also known as Warthin's tumour.
  • Warthin's tumour, called Adenolymphoma or papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum, is the second most common benign salivary gland tumour (after pleomorphic adenoma). It represents 10-15% of the total salivary gland neoplasms.
  • They are commonly seen between the fifth and seventh decades of life.
  • It has an apparent male predilection for their occurrence. 
  • Histologically, it is composed of an oncotic epithelium and a lymphoid stroma.
  • It consists of an encapsulated mass containing numerous irregular cystic spaces lined by bilayered oncotic epithelium growing in the cystic spaces as papillary projections.
  • The underlying stroma separating the oncotic epithelium is typically a large lymphoid matrix with germinal centres.
  • Warthin's tumour and oncocytoma are the two tumours that show a 'hot spot' on the Tc-99m pertechnetate scan. It is because of the high mitochondrial content within the oncocytes.
  • Treatment is superficial parotidectomy, although they can be enucleated without danger of recurrence.

Option A: Glandular hypertrophy, secondary to vitamin A deficiency

  • Parotid gland hypertrophy can occur during malnutrition due to vitamin A deficiency. It is a reversible condition that returns to normal after adequate nutrient intake. There is no history of malnutrition in this patient.

Option B: Cystic dilation

  • Sialectasis is the cystic dilatation of the parotid duct. It is associated with ascending infections and gland destruction.

Option C: Mikulicz’s disease

  • It is an autoimmune disorder of bilateral salivary and lacrimal glands, resulting in infiltration of the glands with round cells.

questions.text: A patient came to eye emergency in AIIMS and gives a history of lime soda falling into his eyes during whitewash. All of the following would be a part of his immediate management EXCEPT:

choices.text: Irrigation of both eyes with copious amounts of normal saline
Thorough slit-lamp examination and fundus evaluation on presentation
Removal of chuna particles by double eversion of upper eyelids

questions.solution:
Thorough slit lamp examination and fundus evaluation is not needed in an emergency condition like Alkali injury to eye that is more dangerous than acid injury. Also the corneal edema would make it difficult to do fundus examination of these patients

•Acid cause precipitation of proteins thus penetration is poor.

•Alkali penetrate ocular tissue more, damage is mainly by collagenolysis.

•Examination should be very rapid and treatment should be started as soon as possible by consulting ophthalmologist

Management

•Immediate:

•Thorough washing of eye with saline or water for at least 30 min.

•Assessment of injury with history and examination.

•Fundus examination & thorough slit lamp examination is not necessary at this moment.

• Limbal stem cell damage and extent of epithelial defect that is seen by detailed slit lamp examination can be done at later stage on follow up

•Removal of chuna particles by double eversion of upper eyelids to remove the offending particles.

•Acute:

•Topical antibiotics

•Topical cycloplegic

•Na-citrate (10%)

•Na-ascorbate (10%)

•Artificial tears

•Topical steroids

questions.text: An obstetrician while performing a vaginal delivery encounters excessive blood loss in third stage even after infusion of oxytocin, so she inserts 4 tablets of a certain drug rectally, while performing a uterine massage. This drug has also been found to be effective in all of the following conditions, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
The drug referred here is misoprostol (PGE1) used rectally for prevention and treatment of post-partum hemorrhage

Misoprostal :

  • Is used for induction of abortion in the early pregnancy for medically induced abortions in doses ranging from 400 to 800 mcgs, then also in the second trimester where abortion with prostaglandins is the mode of choice in doses from 200 to 400 mcgs.
  • Also, misoprostol is an efficient way to induce labour even with doses ranging from 25 to 50 mcgs.
  • In cases of PPH, misoprostol given orally or rectally is an excellent mode of reducing bleeding might as well be used as the most effective drug for PPH.
  • Misoprostol will act when there are prostaglandin receptors and these are more in number when there is a pregnancy in the uterus. In menorrhagia this is not an effective drug and the vasodilator action may in fact worsen the bleeding.

questions.text: A 15 years old Male presented with history of fever since 2 days, unable to swallow the food with muffled voice. On examination it is noted right tonsil is shifted to midline. What is the diagnosis:
questions.solution:
if tonsil is enlarged / hypertrophied and reaching midline and soft palate is moved on other side it is a case of quincy

if tonsil itself is pushed to the midline it is a case of parapharyngeal abscess

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient was unable to carry out any physical activity without discomfort. Had symptoms at rest. If any physical activity is undertaken, discomfort is increased. His NYHA grade of dyspnea is?
questions.solution:
New York Heart Association (NYHA) grading system

Class I No limitation of physical activity. Ordinary physical activity does not cause undue fatigue, palpitation or dyspnoea.
Class II Slight limitation of physical activity. Comfortable at rest but ordinary physical activity results in fatigue, palpitation or dyspnoea.
Class III Marked limitation of physical activity. Comfortable at rest but less than ordinary activity results in fatigue, palpitation or dyspnoea.
Class IV Unable to carry out any physical activity without discomfort. Symptoms at rest. If any physical activity in undertaken, discomfort is increased

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman presented with a painful and redness left breast with nipple retraction and a palpable central hardening mass in the left breast. Left axillary lymph nodes were also palpable. The patient was a cigarette smoker and had a previous mastitis episode of the left breast. The initial sonogram revealed a hypoechoic left retro-areolar lesion with thick liquid content and thickening of the areolar cutaneous planes. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Zuska’s Disease (Recurrent Periductal Mastitis)

  • Condition of recurrent retroareolar infections and abscess.
Symptoms Breast pain/lump, nipple discharge, and areolar pain/lump.
Clinicalfindings Palpable breast mass, tenderness, erythema, warmth, breast swelling, skin thickening, and/or axillary lymphadenopathy.
  • Smoking has been implicated as a risk factor.
  • Managed symptomatically by antibiotics with incision and drainage procedure.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents to a reproductive specialist with his wife due to the inability to conceive after 2 years of trying with his 25-year-old wife. He says that he is having a healthy life style without any significant past medical history, surgeries, or medications. On examination he is well appearing without abnormal features. He has a high-pitched voice, absent facial hair, is 6 feet 2 inches tall, and has a BMI of 21 kg/m^2. On genitourinary exam, he has bilaterally descended testicles without varicoceles, and testicular volume is found to be 9cc bilaterally. He has a stretched penile length of 6cm. A detailed hormonal investigation was done and it is significant for low LH, FSH, and testosterone. What do you is the most likely cause of his infertility?
questions.solution:
By the above history and clinical examination the patient is more likely to have Kallmann syndrome. It results from defective hypothalamic gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) synthesis and is associated with delayed puberty and pronounced hypogonadal features, including micropenis, probably the result of low testosterone levels during infancy. Apart from reproductive features other non reproductive features are also present such as renal agenesis ,hearing impairment ,dental abnormalities ,eye movement abnormalities ,poor balance,cleft lip and anosmia.

Kallmann syndrome and other causes of congenital GnRH deficiency are characterized by low luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels and low concentrations of sex steroids (testosterone or estradiol).

Repetitive GnRH administration restores normal pituitary gonadotropin responses, pointing to a hypothalamic defect in these patients.Long-term treatment of males with human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) or testosterone restores pubertal development and secondary sex characteristics.

questions.text: 65yrs old male complains of lump on right side lower back associated with blood in urine, weight loss, and night sweats. On investigation, it was diagnosed to be Renal cell carcinoma 8cm involving abdominal lymph nodes but no distant metastasis. What should be the most appropriate management of this patient?
questions.solution:
• Renal cell cancer is not responsive to radiation and chemotherapy
  • Radical nephrectomy should be done for localized renal cancer
  • Radical Nephrectomy should be done in this patient as the nodes that are suspected of having metastatic disease are just because they are showing reactive inflammation.

questions.text:
An infant is brought with inspiratory stridor, increasing during effort & relieving on placing child prone.
Laryngoscopy reveals following finding:

All of the following things about the above disease are true except:
questions.solution:
This history and image are giving an idea about Laryngomalacia. Laryngomalacia (congenital laryngeal stridor) it is most common congenital abnormality of the larynx.

In laryngomalacia child is born with soft cartilage (laryngeal cartilage). There is excessive flaccidity of supraglottic larynx which is sucked in during inspiration producing stridor and sometimes cyanosis. Stridor is increase on crying but subsides on placing the child in prone position, cry is normal.

The condition manifests at birth or soon after, and usually disappears by 2 years of age.
Direct laryngoscopy shows elongated epiglottis, curled upon itself (Omega shaped epiglottis), floppy aryepiglottic folds and prominent arytenoids. Flexible laryngoscope is very useful to make diagnosis.

Mostly treatment is conservative. Tracheostomy may be required for some cases of severe respiratory obstruction.

Barking cough – is seen in Acute laryngo-tracheo bronchitis (CROUP)

Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat P. L. Dhingra Shruti Dhingra 7th edition Page no 333

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to emergency department with a sudden onset of fever and rash. He did not have such rashes before. He also complaints of joint pain and it keeps getting worsened. He has a past medical history of diabeties and hypertension. He was recently started on pantoprazole for acid reflux approximately 10 days ago. His vitals are stable. Routine laboratory tests reveal a serum creatinine of 3.6 mg/dL and eosinophilia. Urine studies showed white blood cell casts and hematuria. what is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: This is case of acute interstitial nephritis ( AIN ) .Its an acute inflammation of the kidney characterized by cellular and fluid exudation in the interstitial tissue, accompanied by, but not dependent on, degeneration of the epithelium; the exudation is not purulent in character, and the lesions may be both diffuse and focal. The classic presentation of AIN, namely, fever,rash, peripheral eosinophilia, and occurring after 7–10 days of treatment with methicillin or another β-lactam antibiotic, is the exception rather than the rule. More often, patients are found incidentally to have a rising serum creatinine or present with symptoms attributable to acute renal failure. It is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction and T-cell-mediated attack on tubular cells. It is usually a drug-induced hypersensitivity in majority of cases. It typically developed between 1 week to 9 months. The drugs usually are diuretics especially sulfa ones, NSAIDs ,Penicillins , cephalosporins Proton pump inhibitors and rifampicin. The symptoms are usually fever ,minimal hematuria, flank pain ,rash which is maculopapular and arthralgias. In lab findings there will be eosinophilia and increased creatine. Treatment will be discontinuing the inciting drug for all drug-induced hypersensitivity cases. Glucocorticoids is used only if creatinine continues to rise after stopping drugs

questions.text: Zara is a 35-year-old salesgirl. She is now 10 weeks pregnant with her second child. While doing a self-breast examination she notices a persistent painless lump in her right breast. She consulted a gynecologist to get checked. On clinical examination, the left breast has a single mobile mass without evidence of skin changes or lymphadenopathy in the neck or axilla. An ultrasound was done which demonstrated a solid, 1 cm mass in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. For further investigation, a core needle biopsy was done which showed invasive ductal carcinoma. Which among the following is the most appropriate management option for this patient?

choices.text: Administration of radiation in the third trimester followed by modified radical mastectomy after delivery of the baby
Termination of the pregnancy followed by a modified radical mastectomy
Total mastectomy with sentinel lymph node biopsy

questions.solution:
The patient is a candidate for immediate surgery. Since there is no point in delaying the surgery as general anesthesia or non-abdominal surgery does not pose any risk on pregnancy.

Option A: Radiation is contraindicated in all three trimesters of pregnancy.

Option B: Termination of pregnancy is no longer recommended as a management option to achieve therapy without harming the baby as it has not proved to be improving survival.

Option C: Sentinel lymph node biopsy is not recommended in pregnant women because radioactivity may harm the fetus.

questions.text: What is the risk of using the contraceptive form a female purchased over the counter considering her heart condition, which is categorized as Category-4 in the WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria for contraceptive use?

choices.text: She can use it if no other contraceptive fulfills her requirement
It is meant only for a particular heart condition

questions.solution:
Option B: She should not use it

 

  • This patient has this contraceptive in category 4 for her heart condition, which means this particular contraceptive must absolutely NOT be used.

WHO: MEC: Medical Eligibility Criteria for Contraceptive Use

MEC categories for contraceptive eligibility

1. A condition for which there is no restriction for the use of the contraceptive method

2. A condition where the advantages of using the method generally outweigh the theoretical or proven risks

3. A condition where the theoretical or proven risk usually outweigh the advantages of using the method

4. A condition which represents an unacceptable health risk if the contraceptive method is used

 

Categories 1 and 4 are self-explanatory

Category 1 denotes indications and category 4 indicates absolute contraindications;

Categories 2 and 3 indicate relative contraindications)

Option A : She can safely use it

  • Category 1 is the contraceptive that she can safely use.

Option C : She can use it if no other contraceptive fulfils her requirement

  • Category 3 are contraceptives which can be used very rarely when no other contraceptive suits the patient, and using contraceptive is a necessity.

Option D : It is meant only for the particular heart condition

  • Category 4 does not imply that the contraceptive can be used only for that particular condition. There is no such category.

questions.text:
Match the following




1. Winter shunt
2. Quackel shunt
3. Barry shunt
4.Sacher shunt
5. Grayhack shunt


a) Shunt between Corpora cavernosa and Saphenous vein
b) Shunt between Corpora cavernosa and corpora spongiosum
c) Shunt between Corpora cavernosa and dorsal vein
d) Shunt between Corpora cavernosa and glans
questions.solution: The Grayhack shunt is surgical shunt between Corpora cavernosa and Saphenous vein for the treatment of Ischemic Priapism.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to you with complaints of intermittent dysuria, mild lower abdominal pain, difficulty in voiding and painful ejaculation. He says that his symptoms last for 3 months. There is no notable weight loss or bloody stools. His past medical history is notable for diabetes and hypertension. On examination, he is mildly uncomfortable. On per rectal examination the prostate is mildly tender, with normal size, texture, and contour. Urinalysis was done which revealed trace leukocyte esterase. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Based on the history and clinical presentation this patient presents with chronic prostatitis. Prostatitis includes both infectious and noninfectious abnormalities of the prostate gland. Infections can be acute or chronic, are almost always bacterial in nature, and are far less common than the non-infectious entity chronic pelvic pain syndrome (formerly known as chronic prostatitis).

Chronic bacterial prostatitis presents more insidiously as recurrent episodes of cystitis, sometimes with associated pelvic and perineal pain. Men who present with recurrent cystitis should be evaluated for a prostatic focus as well as urinary retention. The clinical syndrome described can overlap with other conditions such as benign prostatic hypertrophy (BPH), prostate cancer, and chronic bacterial prostatitis. BPH typically has a predominance of voiding symptoms rather than dysuria. Therefore the mainstay of treatment for chronic prostatitis is alpha blockers and antibiotics.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female who was a known case of chronic kidney disease posted for renal transplantation under general anesthesia. Neuraxial opioid with Inj.Fentanyl was given for intraoperative and postoperative analgesia. The most common side effect of fentanyl expected in this patient would be
questions.solution:
Pruritus is the most common side effect with neuraxial opioids. It may be generalized but is more likely to be localized to the face, neck or upper thorax.

Most side effects are dose-dependent and may be more common if the opioid is administered intrathecally.

Epidural opioids enhance the analgesic effects of epidural local anesthetics without prolonging the motor block. The combination of local anesthetic and opioid reduces the dose related adverse effects of each drug independently. The analgesic benefits of neuraxial opioids must be balanced against the dose dependent side effects .Epidural opioids can also be used alone in patients with hemodynamic instability .Lipophilic opioids such as sufentanil are found in lower concentrations in CSF than hydrophilic opioids such as morphine and hydromorphine and are readily absorbed in systemic circulation. This is the principle analgesic mechanism.

Intrathecal opioids exert direct analgesic effect on spinal cord and nerves or prolong the duration of sensory and motor blockade. Intrathecal hydrophilic opioids have greater risk of late respiratory depression which is a most serious complication. Nausea, vomiting, pruritus and urinary retention are other side effects.

The pruritis is self limiting,the severity diminishes in the first hour.For moderate to severe pruritis,Nalbuphine 2.5 mg and repeat dose in 10-15 minutes if no improvement.The advantage of nalbuphine is that it is less likely to reverse analgesic effects of neuraxial opioids.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida presents to the physician for a routine antenatal check-up at 20 weeks. On examination fundal height corresponds to 16 weeks. Ultrasound examination reveals fetal parameters corresponding to 20 weeks, amniotic fluid index of 4 cms, fundal placenta with bilateral fetal renal agenesis. Which of the following is the likely adverse fetal outcome in this patient?
questions.solution:
This is a case of early onset oligohydramnios with bilateral renal agenesis. A complication of this is the Potter’s syndrome which develops due to pulmonary hypoplasia secondary to oligohydramnios and renal agenesis.

Renal agenesis of the fetus causes oligohydramnios prior to midpregnancy due to lack of fetal urine formation, which is a major contributor of amniotic fluid at early gestation. When oligohydramnios is severe enough to cause deformations in morphogenesis of baby, it leads to Potter’s sequence. Alveolar sacs of the fetal lungs also fail to develop properly due to lack of amniotic fluid. Pulmonary hypoplasia causes severe respiratory distress in the newborn and is the most common cause of death in these babies.

The sequence

Features :

questions.text: A newly married couple wanted to go to a genetic counsellor before starting their family. They were advised by their doctor friend as there was a h/o β-thalassemia in paternal family. They explain their case to the counsellor and they were advised to adopt a child instead of planning one. The counsellor explained them that how different mutations in the same genetic locus can cause similar or identical phenotype. About what is she trying to explain to the couple?
questions.solution:
Allelic heterogeneity Different mutations in the same genetic locus can cause an identical or similar phenotype. eg- different mutations of the β-globin locus- β-thalassemia
Phenotypic Heterogeneity When more than one phenotype is caused by allelic mutations e.g. Identical mutations in the FGFR2 gene- Crouzon syndrome or Pfeiffer syndrome
Locus or Non-allelic Heterogeneity Similar disease phenotype results from mutations at different genetic loci. eg- osteogenesis imperfecta- mutations in COL1A1 or COL 1A2: located on different chromosomes

questions.text: A 34-year-old multigravida, with previous normal vaginal delivery presents at 33 weeks 4 days gestation with complains of pain abdomen. There is no vaginal leaking or bleeding and she is perceiving adequate fetal movements. On examination she has intermittent uterine contractions with good fetal heart tracing. Vaginal examination reveals intact membranes with 2 cm dilatation. Pharmacotherapy to prevent neonatal adverse effects by delaying delivery in this case, will have which of the following mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Patient has presented in preterm labour at < 34 weeks duration. Since patient is not in active labour, tocolytics may be used to delay preterm birth to improve neonatal survival by allowing transfer of patient to a tertiary care centre and allowing time for administration and action of antenatal steroids for fetal lung maturity.

Pretermlabour is defined as occurrence of labour (uterine contractions associated with cervical dilatation) before term. Early preterm is labour before 34 weeks and late preterm is labour between 34 and 36 weeks.

Management of preterm labour

  • Antenatal steroids : given for fetal lung maturity and for prevention of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome. Inj betamethasone 12 mg IM 2 doses, 24 hours apart or Inj dexamethasone 6 mg IM 4 doses, 6 hourly.
  • Antibiotics : given when there is associated ruptured membranes for prevention of chorioamnionitis and for group B streptococcus prophylaxis.
  • Tocolytics : these act only in latent phase of labour. Main purpose of tocolysis is for buying time for administration and action of antenatal steroids. Various drugs used are
Class Drugs Features
Beta agonists Salbutamol, TerbutalineRitodrine, Isoxsuprine
  • Side effects: tachycardia, pulmonary edema, hyperglycemia, hypotension
  • Contraindications: cardiac disease, uncontrolled diabetes
Calcium channel blockers Nifedipine
  • Drug of choice
  • Safer
Calcium antagonist MgSO4
  • Neuroprotective
  • Drug of choice for cardiac patients
  • Least incidence of pulmonary edema
  • Side effect: neonatal hypotonia
PG synthetase inhibitor Indomethacin
  • Not to be given beyond 32 weeks, risk of PDA in baby
  • Specific role: preterm in polyhydramnios
Oxytocin antagonist Atosiban No proven reduction in neonatal morbidity
Progesterone
  • Safest
  • More for prophylaxis than treatment
Nitric oxide donor NTG patches Not commonly used

Tocolytics are contraindicated in

  • Active labour
  • Chorioamnionitis
  • > 34 weeks gestation
  • When maternal of fetal indications for delivery are present such as abruption, fetal distress, fetal anomalies, pre-eclampsia etc.

questions.text: A 55-year old man sustains numerous injuries involving the abdomen and lower extremities. During the intra and postoperative periods, he is resuscitated with 10 L of Ringer’s lactate and 2 U of packed red blood cells (RBC). After initial improvement, he has severe dyspnea on the second postoperative day. The most useful initial diagnostic test is which of the following?

choices.text: Insertion of a central venous line

questions.solution: The patient has acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Measurement of ABGs provides initial evaluation of pulmonary function in terms of oxygenation and ventilation. ECG is valuable for diagnosing myocardial ischemia or cardiac arrhythmias. Ventilation perfusion scanning is used for diagnosing pulmonary embolism. A central venous line provides information regarding the volume status of the patient, which may be low to normal in ARDS.

questions.text: In a community, lots of children with short duration fever and swelling of parotid region was reported over a period of 3 – 4 weeks. A clinical diagnosis of mumps is supported by which of the following lab investigations:
questions.solution:
• When mumps is highly prevalent, the diagnosis could be made on the basis of a history of exposure to mumps infection, an appropriate incubation period (16 – 18 days), and development of typical clinical findings. ·
  • Confirmation of the presence of parotitis could be made with demonstration of an elevated serum amylase value.
  • Leukopenia with a relative lymphocytosis is also present.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to your hospital with the chief complaint of swelling in extremities for the past one month. She says that nowadays she gets fatigued more easily and has been gaining weight. Her vitals are within normal limits. On Physical examination she found to have lower extremity pitting edema. Lab values are significant for hypoalbuminemia, hyperlipidemia and urinalysis demonstrates 4+ protein. Kidney biopsy on that patient reveals scaring of glomerulus. Which of the following is most likely be the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution: FSGS refers to a pattern of renal injury characterized by segmental glomerular scars. The pathogenesis of FSGS is probably multifactorial. Possible mechanisms include a T cell–mediated circulating permeability factor, increased soluble urokinase receptor levels, TGF-β–mediated cellular proliferation and matrix synthesis, and podocyte abnormalities associated with genetic mutations. The pathologic changes of FSGS are most prominent in glomeruli located at the corticomedullary junction. In addition to focal and segmental scarring, other variants have been described, including cellular lesions with endocapillary hypercellularity and heavy proteinuria. FSGS can present with hematuria, hypertension, any level of proteinuria, or renal insufficiency. There is no role for steroids or other immunosuppressive agents in secondary FSGS.

questions.text: A married, 33-year-old man was admitted to the hospital, complaining of recurrent sleepwalking episodes. Sleepwalking had recommenced two to three nights a week, two years before the patient sought medical assistance. Dream recovery involved a great amount of water draining from the wall, causing the patient to desperately move and protect objects from the imminent threat of flood. At times, he would try to “catch” something out of the window, usually exposing himself to the risk of falling. However, episodes would not occur on Sundays or during vacations out-of-town. This condition of Somnambulism is mostly seen in which age group?
questions.solution:
Somnambulism

  • Sleep walking, seen in stage 4 and 3 of NREM sleep.
  • It is mostly seen in children and is mostly prevalent in ages 4 to 8 years.

HOW TO REMEMBER: Most parasomnias occur in stage 3+4. Most of them occur during 4-8 years of age.

questions.text: A 35-year-old primigravida presents at 8 weeks of gestation. She has a history of type I diabetes and is very concerned regarding the possible risks this may have on her fetus. You recommend that the patient undergo all of the following tests because of her diabetes, EXCEPT:

choices.text: Maternal serum AFP test at about 16–18 weeks
Fetal surveillance with contraction stress tests starting at 28 weeks

questions.solution: Fetuses of women with overt diabetes are at increased risk of having spina bifida; therefore, patients should be counselled appropriately regarding obtaining a test for maternal serum a-fetoprotein to screen for neural tube defects. Fetal echocardiography is recommended because infants of diabetic mothers have an increased risk of heart anomalies, including transposition of the great vessels, ventricular septal defects, and atrial septal defects. Performance of serial 24-h urine samples will document absence of nephropathy by measuring protein and creatinine clearance. In the third trimester, ultrasounds should be performed to evaluate both excessive and insufficient fetal growth as well as amniotic fluid levels. Beginning at 32??"34 weeks of gestation, a program of weekly or twice-weekly fetal surveillance is usually commenced to document fetal well-being. Testing protocols utilize NST and biophysical profiles. Since contraction stress testing involves using oxytocin to cause uterine contractions, this is not usually used as a first-line surveillance test. It is almost outdated in modern-day obstetrics.

questions.text: Tyler is a 15-year-old male who is currently living at home with his mother and younger sister. His mother describes Tyler as “always being an odd child” who had significant difficulty relating to his peers. As a child, he would spend a great deal of time alone involved in role-playing. She said that social situations always provoke great anxiety in Tyler and he is extremely socially inept. Since childhood, Tyler has been interested in paranormal experiences and has magical thinkings. His mother reports that his interest goes beyond mere curiosity that would be “normal for someone of his age”. Which type of personality disorder does he belong to?
questions.solution:
• Odd behavior including odd speech, mannerism, and magical thinking is seen in Schizotypal personality disorder.
  • This disorder is a part of Cluster A Personality disorder.
  • Schizotypal PD also has a strange way of communication and decompensate in periods of stress.
  • Other types of cluster A personality disorder are Paranoid PD and Schizoid PD.
  • Cluster B PD has four types- Histrionic PD, Narcissistic PD, Antisocial PD, and Borderline PD.
  • Cluster C PD has three types- Avoidant PD, Dependent PD, Obsessive-Compulsive PD

How to remember:

OC- Odd and eCcenteric

E - Emotional

AN - ANxious

  • schizo-"TYPal" : imagine a TYPe-writer. It is used to write fantasy and magical stories

In ICD-10, Schiztypal personality disorder is included in Schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders group with code F21

questions.text: A 21-year-old came to dermatology OPD with complaints of hypopigmented spots for 2 months on the upper chest, back, upper shoulder, and upper arms along with an infected abraded wound. On Examination, Hypopigmented spots with fine scales were noted. 10% KOH mount showed spaghetti and meatball appearance. Which of the following drug is ineffective in the treatment of a given condition:
questions.solution:
Griseofulvin has no role in the treatment of tinea versicolor.

Griseofulvin is used systemically for dermatophytes (Microsporum infection). It is ineffective topically.

Treatment of Tinea/ Pityriasis Versicolor
Systemic (oral) Local (Shampoo/cream)
New treatment Old Treatment

1. Ketocoazole

2. Itraconazole

1. Micoconazole

2. Econazole

3.Ketoconazole

4. Clotrimazole

1. Whitfield's ointment (3% salicylic acid and 6% Benzoic acid)

2. Selenium disulfide

3. Sodium Thiosulphate

questions.text:
Consider the following statements and choose the correct answer?
Statement 1:-Fluid restriction and not medication is the best for management of asymptomatic hyponatremia with serum Sodium less than 120 mEq/L, in patients of cirrhosis with oedema.
Statement 2 :- Conivaptan decreases B.P. and increases risk of variceal bleeding and so relatively contraindicated in cirrhotics with hyponatremia.

choices.text: Statement 1 is wrong and Statement 2 is correct
Statement 1 is correct and Statement 2 is wrong

questions.solution:
Fluid restriction and not medication is the best for management of asymptomatic hyponatremia with serum sodium less than 120 mEq/L and in patients of cirrhosis with edema.

Asymptomatic hyponatremia will respond to fluid restriction.

Symptomatic hyponatremia with neurological implications must be corrected at a rate of 4-8mEq/L over 24hours with 3% Hypertonic saline
Conivaptan decreases B.P. and increases risk of variceal bleeding and so relatively contraindicated in cirrhotics with hyponatremia

Conivaptan acts on V IA and V2 receptors. V IA stimulation is associated with vasoconstrictive, mitogenic, and possibly platelet aggregative effects. Conivaptan causes inhibition of VIA receptors and is beneficial for patients with CHF with concomitanthypertension and atherosclerotic disease.

In contrast, the very same effects derived from V IA inhibition can be harmful for hypotensive patients or cirrhotic patients with dilated splanchnic beds and variceal bleeds.

Further dilatation of the splanchnic bed and interference with platelet aggregation by V IA inhibition could exacerbate variceal bleeding.

questions.text: A 27-year-old multigravida presents to the physician for a routine antenatal check-up. Her general and systemic examination are normal and an ultrasound suggests a 9 weeks live intrauterine pregnancy. She complains of one or two episodes of vomiting daily with nausea after consuming her meals and is concerned about the same as she never had vomiting in her first pregnancy and has always consumed a balanced healthy diet without any digestive problems prior to pregnancy. Which of the following is most likely associated with the patient’s condition?

choices.text: A normal expected rise in b-HCG

questions.solution:
This patient has presented with normal nausea and vomiting of pregnancy which is due to a rise in b-HCG.

Nausea and vomiting of pregnancy

  • Due to a rise in b-HCG levels. The severity also increases and decreases along with HCG in the body. Nausea and vomiting are thus higher in cases of molar pregnancy and twins which are associated with higher HCG and lower in failing/ aborting pregnancies where HCG is falling.
  • Usually continue till 14-16 weeks, but may persist beyond, in some women. Symptoms are variably present throughout the day
  • Remedies : avoiding oily spicy foods, small frequent meals
  • Medications : doxylamine + vitamin B6, may require anti-emetics

Hyperemesis gravidarum

  • A severe form of vomiting in pregnancy which is unresponsive to simple dietary modifications and antiemetics and is severe enough to cause weight loss, dehydration, alkalosis and hypokalemia is termed as hyperemesis gravidarum.
  • Risk factors include pregnancy states associated with higher levels of HCG such as multiple pregnancy, molar gestation, hyperthyroidism as well as a past or family history, young age and first pregnancy. Hyperemesis is however a diagnosis of exclusion and all causes of vomiting should be ruled out.
  • Complications include weight loss, ketosis, hepatic dysfunction, electrolyte imbalance (hyponatremia, hypokalemia), acidosis (starvation), alkalosis (loss of gastric HCl), dehydration, oliguria, renal dysfunction and even coagulopathy.

questions.text:
(A) True or (B) False
1. For Parathyroid adenoma - Tc99m Sestamibi scan used (previously thallium subtraction study is done)
2. Pancreatic carcinoma - Selenium-methionine scan used
3. Bone metastasis - Tc99m- Pertechnate scan used
4. Meckel’s diverticulum - Tc99m- MDP scan used
questions.solution:
• Parathyroid adenoma: Tc99m Sestamibi scan used (previously thallium subtraction study is done)
  • Pancreatic carcinoma: Selenium-methionine scan used
