  • Bone metastasis: Tc99m- MDP scan used
  • Meckel’s diverticulum: Tc99m- Pertechnate scan used

questions.text: A 37 yrs old woman came to your hospital with complaints of headache and vomitting for the past 6 months. MRI Brain revealed inferior descent of the cerebellar tonsils below the level of the foramen magnum. Which of the following could be the possible complication in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Foraminal brain herniation leads to compression of the medulla leading to respiratory arrest.
  • Third nerve palsy causing ipsilateral pupillary dilatation and contralateral hemiplegia occurs in uncal (midbrain) herniation
  • Locked in state occurs due to a lesion of ventral pons.
  • Contralateral hemiplegia occurs with compression of ipsilateral cerebral peduncle of midbrain.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the ER due to abdominal pain and bilious vomiting. He gets the pain when he takes his meal. He has never had similar symptoms before. The patient had sustained injury with handlebar of the bicycle 3 days back. His vital signs are normal. Abdominal examination shows tenderness in the epigastric area. Bowel sounds heard. USG does not demonstrate free intraperitoneal fluid. Plain abdominal radiograph shows dilated stomach with scanty distal gas. Laboratory results are as follows Hb 12.8 g/dL Leukocytes 9000/mm. Total bilirubin 1.4 mg/dL, Amylase 87 U/L. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
• Duodenal hematomas (DHs) most commonly occur following blunt abdominal trauma (BAT) They are more commonly seen in children due to thinner abdominal wall musculature. DH commonly occurs when a blunt force rapidly compresses the duodenum against the vertebral column.
  • Following trauma, blood collects between the submucosal and muscular layers of the duodenum causing partial or complete obstruction. Patients with DH due to BAT may initially have only symptoms of abdominal wall trauma, which may improve before subsequent clinical deterioration as the DH expands Patients classically present 24-36 hours after the initial event with epigastric pain and vomiting due to failure to pass gastric contents beyond the obstructing hematoma. Diagnosis is confirmed with CT imaging of the abdomen. Most DHs will resolve in 1-2 weeks.
  • Management involves decompression by nasogastric tube and, in many patients, parenteral nutrition. Surgery or percutaneous drainage may be considered to evacuate the hematoma if nonoperative management fails.

Option B: Liver laceration is one of the most common complications of BAT However, this patient's lack of right upper quadrant tenderness, lack of intraperitoneal free fluid, hemodynamic stability, and normal blood counts make a liver laceration less likely

Option C: The pancreas is infrequently injured during BAT, but occasionally patients can develop pancreatic pseudocysts subacutely (days to weeks) after an event with nausea, vomiting, weight loss, and a palpable abdominal mass. It would be unlikely for a pancreatic pseudocyst to develop within 2 days

Option D: Pyloric stenosis classically presents with nausea, vomiting, and poor feeding in a 1-month-old infant It would be an extremely rare presentation in a preadolescent child.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady presents to the emergency department due to sudden severe bilateral loss of vision, more so on the right side, and with no light perception. The rest of the examination, including pupillary reflexes, fundus, and optokinetic nystagmus, is normal. She could approximate the tips of her index fingers with the right eye closed but not with the left eye closed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Functional visual loss

  • Functional visual loss is vision loss without any organic cause.
  • They can be divided into three categories:
  • Somatoform disorders
  • Factitious disorders
  • Malingering
  • Appropriate history and physical exam would help in ruling out any organic cause
  • Accommodation, pupillary light reflex, and optokinetic test are normal.
  • A person with functional blindness cannot touch the tips of the index fingers together, while those with an organic cause of vision loss can.
  • Normal visual evoked potentials will confirm the presence of a functional cause.

Option A: Optic neuritis

  • Optic neuritis is characterised by acute unilateral painful vision loss due to an inflammatory and demyelinating disease of the optic nerve.
  • It is usually seen in multiple sclerosis.
  • Signs and symptoms include impaired vision, colour vision, dark adaptation, relative afferent pupillary defect, fundus normal or papilledema, and visual evoked response showing decreased amplitude.
  • A normal pupillary reflex makes optic neuritis less likely in this patient.

Option B: Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy

  • Anterior ischemic Optic Neuropathy (AION) refers to ischemia of the optic nerve head from blockage of the short posterior ciliary arteries.
  • It is of two types: arteritic and non-arteritic.
  • Signs and symptoms may include marked vision loss, relative afferent pupillary defect, optic disc swelling and pallor, cotton wool spots, and splinter hemorrhages.
  • A normal pupillary reflex and normal fundus examination make AION less likely in this patient.

Option C: CMV retinitis

  • Cytomegalovirus retinitis usually occurs in immunosuppressed patients (AIDS patients, long-term immunosuppression following organ transplantation).
  • Fundoscopic examination shows yellow-white exudates with perivascular sheathing and retinal hemorrhages, giving it a pizza pie appearance.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to the physician, 15 days after a missed period. A urine pregnancy test done is positive. She has no complains at present except for mild nausea and breast tenderness. Ultrasound shows an intrauterine live pregnancy of 6 weeks. Which of the following is an appropriate investigation to be obtained at this time?
questions.solution:
This patient is in her first trimester of pregnancy. Out of the given options, testing for sexually transmitted diseases is appropriate at this time.

At the first prenatal visit in the first trimester, following are to be obtained

History

  • Complete history about details of conception, symptoms if any
  • Obstetric history: previous pregnancies antenatal, intranatal and postnatal course
  • Past and personal history: chronic medical or surgical illnesses, drugs, allergies, addictions, contraception
  • Family history

Examination

  • Complete general physical examination and systemic examination including blood pressure, maternal weight
  • Obstetric examination: abdominal and pelvic

Investigations

  • Complete blood counts
  • Blood and Rh type
  • Paps smear
  • Urine microscopy and culture
  • STD screening: HIV (opt-out approach), hepatitis B, syphilis serology
  • Rubella serology
  • Early obstetric scan

questions.text: A senior consultant visits all patients for a round in labour room. All women are in latent phase of labour. All of the following four patients have been admitted in labour, however the consultant immediately sends one of these for a casarean section :

choices.text: Primigravida with type IV placenta previa, not currently bleeding
Primigravida with Breech presentation with anaemia

questions.solution:
Option A : Type IV placenta previa is total obstruction of the OS and hence C.S is the only method of termination. Since patient is in labour, an emergency LSCS is indicated even if patient is not currently bleeding.

Indications for LSCS

  • Cephalopelvic disproportion or contracted pelvis
  • Placenta previa
  • Fetal hypoxia
  • Previous cesarean : >=2, previous classical cesarean, previous hysterotomy
  • Pelvic tumors
  • Active genital herpes
  • Transverse lie, complicated breech, non cephalic presenting twin
  • Uterine rupture
  • Scarred uterus such as previous myomectomy, unification surgery
  • Other medical or surgical complications necessitating surgery

Option B : Primigravida with breech presentation is a relative contraindication to vaginal delivery. Absolute indications for cesarean in breech presentation are:

  • Footling breech
  • Breech with extended head
  • Complicated breech such as twin, previous cesarean etc
  • Any of the above mentioned obstetric indications

Option C : A previous LSCS is not an absolute indication as such for cesarean. Repeat cesarean is indicated in

  • Previous classical, T shaped, hysterotomy
  • Cephalopelvic disproportion
  • Previous >= 2LSCS
  • Previous uterine rupture
  • Malpresentation
  • Obstetric indications
  • Non consenting patient
  • Lack of facilities for Em LSCS round the clock

Option D : Face presentation can deliver normally if mentum is anterior and pelvis is adequate.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with primary infertility presents with irregular and painless menstrual cycles. She is started on a drug that acts by antagonising estrogenic negative feedback on hypothalamus. Which of the following is true about this drug?

choices.text: Significantly increases sperm counts in oligospermic men
1-2% increase in rate of twin pregnancy

questions.solution:
Clomiphene citrate

  • Trans enclomiphene 62%: anti-estrogenic
  • Cis zuclomiphene citrate 38% : mildly estrogenic
    • This Primarily acts at the receptor in Hypothalamus rather than the Ovarian and Pituitary axis. Blockade increases the stimulus to the pituitary to produce more FSH.
    • Antagonises the beneficial actions of estrogens on the endometrium and hence a supplementation of estrogen is required in patients on higher doses of clomiphene for ovulation induction
    • 6-12% increase in rate of twins
    • Oligospermia relief is not the best benefit of Clomiphene…statistically, because roughly 10-15% only are benefited with this in oligospermia reversal.

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child was brought to Pediatric's OPD by the parents with missing testes on the left scrotal sac. The child was of full-term delivery without any complications. On examination, the child's physical parameters were as per his age. Systemic examination was unremarkable. On local examination, it was found that the left scrotal sac was empty as testes were not palpable. All the blood investigations were within normal limits. The child underwent ultrasound (US) study which revealed an empty left scrotal sac with another well-defined testis-like hypoechoic structure seen in the left inguinal region. To maximize fertility potential, orchidopexy for the patient should be done before:
questions.solution:
Cryptorchidism is a condition in which one testis or both testes fail to descend into the scrotum before birth. Upto 30% of preterm infants and 3% of full term infants can present with cryptorchidism. Some undescended testes eventually descend by 1 year of age but they are unlikely to descend after this time.

When the testicle is not present within the scrotum, it is subjected to a higher temperature resulting in decreased spermatogenesis. Changes in undescended testis include atrophy of Leydig cells, decrease in tubular diameter and impaired spermatogenesis. They occur as early as 6 months of age

It is now recommended that the undescended testicle be surgically repositioned by 1 year of age to optimise spermatogenesis.

questions.text: A female baby born at term to O -ve mother with Coombs +ve at delivery. Baby weighed 2.8 kgs at birth and haemoglobin is 16 g/dL and TSB is 5 mg/dL. He passed a black stool within the first 24 hours of life and his temp was 97.7°F. After 5 days, infant’s weight reduced by 60 gms, his axillary temperature reduced to 95°F and he is jaundiced upto the chest. Parents also told about yellow, seedy stool. Lab investigations show hemoglobin is now 14.4 g/dL, and his TSB is 14 mg/dL. The change in which of the following parameters is of most concern for you as a paediatrician?
questions.solution:
• In a normal infant, Temperature should not change.
  • Temperature instability in a term infant is frequently a sign of serious infection.
  • There is loss of body weight of 1.5% to 2% per day initially in a normal newborn infant as excessive fluid is excreted.
  • The hematocrit falls as an adaptation to an environment of higher oxygen.
  • Infants usually have several meconium stools during the first day or two of life, changing to soft yellow stools after 1 to 2 days of life.
  • As the hematocrit falls, there is a corresponding increase in serum bilirubin that peaks around 3 to 5 days of life.

questions.text: Emma is a 54-year-old woman. She is a teacher working in a primary school. She presents to the clinic with weight loss and persistent rash to her lower abdomen and perineum. After further investigations, she is diagnosed with necrolytic migrating erythema. Additional workups were done which demonstrates anemia, diabetes mellitus, and a large mass in the tail of the pancreas. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of a tumor in the tail of the pancreas along with a rash in the lower abdomen called necrolytic migrating erythema is most consistent with a glucagonoma. Glucagonoma is an alpha islet cell tumor that causes a syndrome of characteristic rash, diabetes mellitus, weight loss, anemia, and elevated levels of circulating glucagon. Surgical excision with a distal pancreatectomy is the treatment.

Option B: Insulinoma is the tumor of beta islet cells. Elevated levels of insulin are seen in the blood. It does not cause necrolytic migrating erythema.

Option C: Gastrinoma is the tumor of the gastrin secreting cells. It does not cause necrolytic migrating erythema.

Option D: Somatostatinoma is the tumor of the somatostatin secreting cells.

questions.text: A pediatrician is doing Ballard score in a new born baby in a tertiary care hospital. While doing heel to ear test, found that there is no pinna and external ear opening on one side and informed ENT surgeon. what will be the management?
questions.solution:
• This is a case of anotia and external auditory canal atresia.
  • Anotia – absent pinna

Rx

  • Pinnaplasty with rib/ costal cartilage
  • Usually done at 5-7 years of age

EAC atresia

  • Defect in 1st arch

Rx

  • Canaloplasty

U/L atresia + anotia

Rx-

  • Pinnaplasty followed by canaloplasty

B/Latresia + anotia

Rx

  • BAHA (bone anchored hearing aid)
  • Titanium screw has Osseo-integration property
  • Requires 2.5- 3mm bone thickness achieved around 5 years of age
  • Before prescribed age, treatment can be done with soft band hearing aid

Anotia

questions.text:
Below mentioned signs and conditions are seen in a syndrome/disease caused by mutation in WFS1 gene which are?

Diabetes mellitus
Optic Atrophy
Retrobulbar neuritis
Sensorineural Deafness
questions.solution:
Types of diabetes mellitus

Type 1 A Immune mediated Diabetes mellitus (insulinopenia)
Type 1 B Idiopathic mediated Diabetes mellitus (insulinopenia)
Type 2 Due to insulin resistance
MODY Maturity Onset Diabetes in Young
LADA Latent Autoimmune Diabetes in Adults
MIDD Maternally Inherited Diabetes and Deafness
Wolfram syndrome

Diabetes insipidus, Diabetes mellitus, optic atrophy and deafness

(Mnemonic)

DIDMOAD

  • DI - Diabetes insipidus
  • DM - Diabetes mellitus
  • OA - Optic Atrophy
  • D - Sensorineural Deafness
Note :
In diabetes mellitus type 2 → ↑ FPG is due to ↑ hepatic glucose output

questions.text: A 47 yr old woman presents with Fibroid uterus & surgeon performs a hysterectomy for a large uterine fibroid. It was a difficult surgery as there were pelvic adhesions and the fibroid was large, distorting normal pelvic anatomy. As the patient is shifted for post-operative care, the surgeon instructs his resident to watch for expected complications. All of these are relevant instructions, EXCEPT?

choices.text: Watch for decreased urine output, due to bladder or ureteric injury
Watch for frequency and incontinence of urine after catheter removal, due to bladder hypertonia
Watch for tachycardia/hypotension/falling hemoglobin, due to internal hemorrhage
Watch for abdominal distension/vomiting due to bowel injury

questions.solution:
Complications of Hysterectomy, risk of complications is higher in patients with difficult surgery and associated complications and co-morbidities

  • Hemorrhage: bleeding in drain, abdominal distension, tachycardia, hypotension, fall in hemoglobin
  • Wound Infection: fever, discharge from incision
  • Cuff Cellulitis: pain, fever discahrge
  • Bladder Hypotonia (NOT hypertonia) : urinary retention
  • Stress urinary incontinence: involuntary leak
  • Prolapse of vault: late complication, mass descending from vagina
  • Cuff dehiscence: discharge pv Uretric/ Bladder: abdominal distension, decreased urine output, fluid from abdominal drain
  • Bowel injury: abdominal distension, vomiting, constipation

questions.text: A 17-year-old female patient, post road traffic accident, presented to the hospital 18 days after the incident with a left leg injury with the sustained open comminuted left distal tibia and fibula fracture repaired by orthopedic team and skin and soft tissue loss at the same spot. On examination post-traumatic vertical defect at the posterior aspect of the distal part of the left leg and distal part of the gastrocnemius muscle, with pus discharge was noted. Wound swabs for culture and sensitivity showed growth of pseudomonas. Negative Pressure Wound Therapy (NPWT), was applied. All the following are true about NPWT except?

choices.text: Necrotic tissue with eschar in the wound is a contraindication to its use

questions.solution:
Negative pressure wound therapy:

  • Enhances wound healing by the removal of fluid collecting in it.
  • Suction pressure -75 to -125 mmHg
  • Gives good granulation tissue
  • Can be used intermittently or continuously
  • Contraindications:
    • Malignancy,
    • Untreated osteomyelitis,
    • Necrotic eschar

questions.text: A 28-year-old nulliparous woman presents to the physician with complaints of irregular cycles for 2 weeks. She also complains of milk discharge from bilateral breasts. She doesn't have any offspring. The patient is vitally stable, and other physical examinations are unremarkable. The clinician orders serum prolactin levels which turns out to be 250 ng/mL. Which of the following is the next most appropriate step in management of tis patient?

choices.text: No intervention required as levels are normal

questions.solution:
Option A : MRI pituitary

  • A Prolactin level of 200 ng/mL or more suggests hyperprolactinemia and requires further evaluation by MRI to rule out pituitary macroadenoma.
  • A microadenoma is often visualized using MRI. Usually, the serum prolactin level is below 200ng/mL (4000mU/L) in patients with microadenomas. A macroadenoma that secretes prolactin is usually associated with a serum prolactin level of more than 200ng/mL (4000mU/L). It is important to identify macroadenomas as they require surgery.
  • Normal Prolactin levels are 5-27 ng/mL throughout the cycle. However, physiological disturbances, pharmacological agents, or markedly compromised renal function may cause elevations in prolactin levels and transient elevations may occur with acute stress or painful stimuli. The most common cause of elevated prolactin levels is likely pharmacological agents, most patients using anti-psychotic agents or other drugs with anti-dopaminergic properties exhibit raised prolactin levels.
  • Elevations in prolactin may cause amenorrhea or galactorrhea. Amenorrhea without galactorrhea is associated with hyperprolactinemia in approximately 15% of women. In patients with both galactorrhea and amenorrhea, approximately two-thirds will have hyperprolactinemia; of those, approximately one-third will have a pituitary adenoma.
  • In more than one-third of women with hyperprolactinemia, a radiologic abnormality consistent with a microadenoma (<1 cm) is found.

Option B : USG breasts

  • USG breasts have no role unless an underlying breast pathology is suspected, here the diagnosis of hyperprolactinemia is already made.

Option C : Bromocriptine

  • Bromocriptine is used to treat hyperprolactinemia, however in this case with very high prolactin levels, an MRI must be done first to find out the cause. Microadenomas usually resolve with dopamine agonists like bromocriptine, however macroadenomas may require surgery.

Option D : No intervention required as levels are normal

  • There is increased prolactin levels, further investigation and treatment is warranted here.

questions.text:
Which of the following statement(s) is/are true concerning the role of antibiotics in wound care?
A. Systemic antibiotics are indicated for all open wounds
B. Topical antibiotics are highly efficacious than systemic antibiotics in controlling infection
C. An indication for systemic antibiotic administration is a granulation tissue bacterial count > 105 organisms/gram of tissue
D. Silver sulfadiazine is useful only for the management of burns
E. Antibiotic treatment of acute wounds must be based on organisms suspected to be found within the infected wound and the patient’s overall immune status
questions.solution:
• The role of antibiotics in wound care is controversial.
  • All open wounds are colonized with bacteria.
  • Only when surrounding tissue is invaded (cellulitis) are systemic antibiotics clearly indicated.
  • Antibiotics may also be useful in other situations such as when granulation tissue has a high bacterial count (> 105 organisms/gram tissue), or in the case of reduced resistance to bacteria such as in a diabetic foot ulcer.
  • The routine use of systemic antibiotics for chronic wounds should be avoided to reduce the development of resistant bacterial strains within the wound.
  • Topical ointments are frequently used
    • The topical vehicle may help keep the wound moist and the bacterial count in the wound may be lowered as the result.
  • Silver sulfadiazine,
    • Use- burn care, chronic wounds.
    • broad spectrum of activity,
    • lack of relevant drug-resistant plasmids in bacteria,
    • low cost
  • Systemic antibiotics given are broad spectrum (not specific )thus at risk of developing resistance while use of topical antibiotic based on culture would be specific for the microbe

The role of antibiotics in wound care is controversial

Antibiotics should be used only when there is an obvious wound infection. Most wounds are contaminated or colonised with bacteria. The presence of a host response constitutes an infection and justifies the use of antibiotics. Signs of infection to look for include erythema, cellulitis, swelling and purulent discharge. As the organisms proliferate to high wound counts (>105organisms per gram of tissue) they may penetrate into viable tissue, invade blood vessels and cause a systemic infection . This is an indication for antibiotic administration. Indiscriminate use of antibiotics should be avoided to prevent the emergence of multidrug resistant bacteria

Antibiotic treatment of acute wounds must be based on organisms suspected to be found within the infected wound and the patient’s overall immune status

When a single specific organism is suspected, treatment may be commenced using a single antibiotic

Conversely, when multiple organisms are suspected, as with enteric contamination or when a person’s immune function is impaired by diabetes, chronic disease or medication, treatment should commence with a broad spectrum antibiotic or several agents in combination

Antibiotics can also be delivered topically as part of irrigations or dressings although their efficacy is questionable

Silver sulfadiazine

  • Silver sulfadiazine is the most commonly used topical antibiotic
  • Broad antibacterial spectrum and hence in addition to treatment of burn wounds , it is also used in the treatment of other chronic wounds
  • Primarily used as prophylaxis against burn wound infections rather than treatment of existing infections
  • Inexpensive, easily applied and has soothing qualities
  • Painless on application
  • Fair to poor eschar penetration
  • It is not significantly absorbed systemically and thus has no metabolic side effects
  • Mild inhibition of epithelialization
  • May leave black tattoos from silver ion
  • Transient leukopenia may develop in 3 to 5 days which resolves spontaneously
  • Destroys skin grafts and is contraindicated on burns or donor sites in proximity to newly grafted areas
  • True allergic reactions to the sulfa component of silver sulfadiazine are rare, and at-risk patients can have a small test patch applied to identify a burning sensation or rash

questions.text: A primigravida at 28 weeks of gestation presents with a BP of 160/110 mmHg, proteinuria of 350 mg/day and lower limb edema. Ultrasound reveals a single intrauterine growth retarded fetus with decreased diastolic flow in umbilical arteries. Which of the following pathological change is most likely responsible for these findings?

choices.text: Deficient trophoblast invasion of spiral arteries of placenta
Excessive production of human placental lactogen
Non disjunction of chromosomes during fertilization

questions.solution:
This is a case of pre-eclampsia complicated with IUGR. The major pathophysiology involves incomplete invasion of spiral arteries of placenta by extravillous trophoblast.

Normal pregnancy is characterised by invasion of spiral arterioles (muscularis and endothelium) by extravillous trophoblast. This converts these vessels into dilated low resistance vessels and improves uteroplacental blood flow. Absence or deficiency of this invasion leads to small calibre high resistance vasculature leading to endothelial injury and vasospasm causing hypertension, proteinuria and other systemic complications of pre-eclampsia.

Pathophysiology of pre-eclampsia

.

questions.text: A 33-year-old female presents to the physician with foul smelling vaginal discharge. She is multiparous, sexually active and not using any contraception. On a speculum examination, there is yellowish mucopurulent discharge exuding from endocervix and cervical ectopy. She complains of having had similar episode one month back for which she was given oral antibiotic treatment. Pelvic USG shows normal findings. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?

choices.text: Fluconazole for 3 doses, every third day
Contact tracing and treatment of both partners
Suppressive therapy with long term cephalosporins

questions.solution:
The patient here has presented with a recurrent episode of cervicitis. An important cause of recurrence of cervicitis is the failure to treat the partner. Two important causative organisms are Chlamydia trachomatis and Nesseria gonorrhoeae.

Clinical presentation

  • Discharge : mucopurulent yellowish discharge, is some cases can be seen exuding from endocervix
  • Cervical edema and hypertrophy
  • Cervical ectopy
  • Friable cervix : bleeds easily on touch
  • May be associated with symptoms of urethritis, bartholinitis, proctitis.

Complications

  • Ascending infection : PID, endometritis, salpingitis
  • Septicemia : fever, meningitis, endocarditis, tenosynovitis, polyarthralgia
  • Perihepatitis : adhesions with anterior abdominal wall called Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome.
  • Long term : infertility, ectopic pregnancy, chronic pelvic pain

Treatment : involves treatment of both partners

Chlamydia trachomatis : regimes

  • Azithromycin 1 gm single dose
  • Doxycyline : 100 mg BD x 7 days
  • Erythromycin : 500 mg BD x 7 days
  • Ofloxacin : 200 mg BD x 7 days

Nesseria gonorrhoeae

  • Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM single dose + azithromycin 1 gm oral single dose
  • Cefexime 400 mg single dose + azithromycin 1 gm oral single dose

Single dose ceftriaxone (250mg IM) along with azithromycin 1 gm (single dose) for both partners, treats both organisms

questions.text: A child with seizures and a history of mental retardation is brought to the clinic by his parents. Clinical examination reveals multiple hypopigmented macules. MRI shows a brain lesion, which is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Tuberous sclerosis

  • Tuberous sclerosis (Bourneville disease) is an autosomal dominant condition, and two genetic loci have been identified: TSC1 (chromosome 9) encoding hamartin and TSC2 (chromosome 16) encoding tuberin. The hallmark is hamartomas in many systems.
  • The classic triad of clinical features comprises
    • Learning disability (mental retardation)
    • Epilepsy
    • Skin lesions
  • Skin changes include pale oval hypomelanotic (ash leaf) macules that occur in early childhood; yellowish/pink papules in the mid-face on the nasolabial folds, cheek, and chin (angiofibromas, adenoma sebaceum) occurring in adolescence; periungual and subungual fibromas and connective tissue nevi (shagreen patches often on the lower back)
  • The patient frequently requires anticonvulsants for seizures.

Option B: Neurofibromatosis

  • Widened neural foramina are frequently seen in Neurofibromatosis.
  • Tumours develop on nerve tissue as a result of a group of genetic diseases called neurofibromatosis. Anywhere in the nervous system, including the brain, spinal cord, and nerves, these tumours can form.
  • Neurofibromatosis comes in three different forms: schwannomatosis, neurofibromatosis 1 (NF1), and neurofibromatosis 2 (NF2).
  • NF1 is a kind of Neurofibromatosis and it is dependent on the individual genes involved. NF1 is a gene that can be found on chromosome 17.

Option C: Sturge Weber syndrome

  • An upper eyelid and forehead birthmark with a port-wine stain on one side of the face are signs of Sturge-Weber syndrome, a neurological condition.
  • Three main characteristics of Sturge-Weber syndrome are an abnormality of the brain termed a leptomeningeal angioma, a red or pink birthmark known as a port-wine birthmark, and elevated eye pressure (glaucoma).
  • Sturge-Weber syndrome is a congenital condition that sometimes affects the eyes, the nervous system, and the skin. It is not lethal, but there is no cure. Sturge-Weber is an incurable, chronic illness.

Option D: Linear epidermal nevus syndrome

  • A congenital neurocutaneous condition known as linear epidermal nevus syndrome causes linear epidermal nevi along with severe involvement of the neurological, ophthalmologic, and skeletal systems.
  • The majority of epidermal nevus syndromes are assumed to be brought on by postzygotic mutations or gene changes that take place early in the embryonic phase following fertilization.
  • People who are affected have cells that have both the normal and aberrant copies of this gene (mosaic pattern).
  • Epidermal nevi have been treated using surgical excision, dermabrasion, cryosurgery, electrosurgery, laser surgery, and electrosurgery. Surgery is only used to remove minor lesions because excision always leaves a scar.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency because of a non tender mass felt on his right side of abdomen. Physical examination reveals a nontender right abdominal mass His temperature is 37.1°C, BP of 98/68 mmHg, PR 120/min, RR 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Abdominal exam demonstrates a palpable mass limited to the right side of the abdomen. Renal USG shows a heterogeneous mass originating from the right kidney. CT of the abdomen is shown. Which of the following pathologic descriptions represents the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: A mutation of the PKD1 gene on chromosome 16
Malignant proliferation of primitive neural crest cells
Malignant transformation of renal tubular cells

questions.solution:
• The patient has a painless abdominal mass originating from the kidney.
  • Wilms tumor is the most common solid renal tumor of childhood.
  • Wilms tumor is often first noticed because of abdominal swelling or a mass in the kidney that can be felt upon physical examination.
  • Some affected children have abdominal pain, fever, a low number of red blood cells (anemia), blood in the urine (hematuria), or high blood pressure (hypertension).
  • Other signs of Wilms tumor can include loss of appetite, weight loss, nausea, vomiting, and tiredness (lethargy).
  • The tumors do not usually cross the midline.
  • The most common site of metastasis is the lungs. Wilms tumor is rarely seen in adults.
  • Changes in any of several genes are involved in the formation of Wilms tumor
  • Wilms tumor is often associated with mutations in the WT1 gene, CTNNB1 gene, or AMER1 gene.
  • These genes provide instructions for making proteins that regulate gene activity and promote the growth and division (proliferation) of cells. A significant minority of cases is associated with other syndromes, such as the Wilms tumor,?aniridia,?genitourinary anomalies, and intellectual disability (WAGR) syndrome. Wilms tumor originate from residual metanephric blastema.

questions.text: A 45-year-old multiparous woman presents to the physician with excessive menstrual bleeding with dysmenorrhea associated with backache since a year which has been progressively worsening. On examination, there is no discharge, uterus appears diffusely enlarged and there is no adnexal or uterine tenderness. Ultrasound shows loss on endomyometrial interface. Which of the following is the most definitive management?
questions.solution:
History and examination findings are suggestive of adenomyosis.

Adenomyosis is benign but invasive growth of the endometrium into the muscular layer of the uterus. The patients are usually multiparous, around the age of 40 years.

  • Menorrhagia and progressively increasing dysmenorrhea.
  • Pelvic discomfort, backache and dyspareunia.
  • Clinical examination: symmetrical enlargement of uterus if adenomyosis is diffuse but if it is localized the enlargement is asymmetrical. uterus is enlarged but seldom more than a ’14 weeks’ pregnant size uterus.
  • Progesterones can be used for relief but the definitive treatment is Hysterectomy.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of COPD presents to the emergency room with a two-day history of worsening shortness of breath which came on following a recent viral infection. In the emergency room, his oxygen saturation is 88% on room air. He is working hard to breathe and is only speaking in short sentences. The patient was intubated and connected to a mechanical ventilator. Which of the following is not weaning mode of ventilation?
questions.solution:
Weaning is the gradual discontinuation of the ventilator. The modes which encourage the patient's breathing can only be used as a weaning mode.

Control Mode Ventilation is not the weaning mode.

Mechanical criteria for Discontinuing Mechanical Ventilation

Inspiratory pressure <−25 cm H2O
Tidal volume >5 mL/kg
Vital capacity >10 mL/kg
Minute ventilation <10 mL
Rapid shallow breathing index <100

questions.text: 3. A 16-year-old male patient named john presents to the clinic with the chief compliant of lower abdominal pain for last two months. He states that the pain is a dull with the pain scale of 3/10 in severity and gets worsen on standing . The pain is relieved when he lies down. The patient did not had any recent trauma nor he is sexually active. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical exam it is noted that his left testicle is enlarged and tender to palpation. ultrasound was ordered which revealed a image as shown below. What will be the consequence of this condition if left untreated?
questions.solution:
This is a case of varicocele. A varicocele is an abnormal enlargement of the pampiniform venous plexus in the scrotum. It is the most common surgically correctable cause of male sub fertility. It occurs 90% on the left side of the testes due to the fact that the left gonadal vein drain directly into the left renal vein. It usually presents with swelling and discomfort in the scrotal region. On palpation it feels like a bag of worms. It has the complication of atrophy of testis in adolescent males and it also leads to the suspicion of renal cell carcinoma in elderly .

The investigation of choice is doppler but the gold standard is venography.

It is classified into 3 grades:

Grade 1 : palpable during valsalva

Grade 2 : palpable at rest

Grade 3 : visible and palpable

Treatment includes high inguinal ligation ( near deep ring ) of pampiniform plexus, microvascular sub inguinal ligation of pampiniform plexus and palomos operation.

Atrophy of testis in adolescent males occurs in varicocele if left untreated.

questions.text: Which of the following is based on this measurement?
questions.solution:
• The picture depicts measurement of head circumference.         
  • Among the given options, Kanawati index is based on this measurement. It is calculated as Mid-arm circumference/head circumference (cm).          
  • Normal value is 0.32 – 0.33 ·        
  • In Severely malnourished children, the value is <0.25

questions.text: A 27-year-old primigravida presents for a regular antenatal check up. She is perceiving her fetal movement well but is tired of all the aches and pains, bloating and unrest and wishes to quickly get back to her normal self. She hopes to go in labour soon or be induced for delivery, however the clinician advices against delivery now and explains to her that this may cause breathing and feeding problems for her baby. What is the probable period of gestation in this case?
questions.solution:
Complications associated with premature delivery include feeding and respiratory difficulty in the newborn. Fetus is said to be preterm when delivered before 37 completed weeks of gestation. Quickening starts at 18-20 weeks, and since the woman in the question is perceiving fetal movements, it is likely later than 20 weeks.

Quickening : first perception of fetal movement by the mother

  • Primigravida : 18-20 weeks
  • Multigravida : 16-18 weeks

Term and preterm

  • Preterm : < 37 weeks (early preterm : < 34 weeks, late preterm : 34-37 weeks)
  • Term : 37 – 41 weeks (early term : 37-39 weeks, term 39-41 weeks)

Neonatal complications of preterm birth (prematurity)

  • Respiratory distress syndrome : This can be prevented by administration of antenatal steroids to mother
  • Hypothermia
  • Hypoglycaemia
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Intra-ventricular haemorrhage
  • Increased susceptibility to sepsis, necrotising enterocolitis
  • Feeding difficulties.
  • Retinopathy of prematurity

Tests for pulmonary maturation

  • L:S ratio > 2.3 :1 (Lecithin/sphingomyelin ratio) is suggestive of lung maturity ·
  • Presence of Phosphatidyl Glycerol in amniotic fluid
  • Shake test , Foam Stability index and Tap test: assess presence of fat in amniotic fluid, addition of saponifying agents forms bubbles
  • Nile blue sulfate test

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to the physician with complaints of dry cough and worsening shortness of breath with exertion for the past 6 months. He used to be an active smoker for the past 5 years. Upon examination, there were multiple 1.5- to 2-cm nontender lymph nodes in the axillae. His serum calcium concentration was also raised. His physician made a diagnosis of Sarcoidosis involving multiple systems. His CT-Chest images are given below. Which of the following is the most common cause of sudden death in such patients?
questions.solution:
Option C: Arrhythmias

  • This is a case of Sarcoidosis in which the patient presents with complaints of dry cough and worsening shortness of breath with exertion for the past 6 months.
  • Cardiac involvement occurs initially with inflammation and granuloma formation followed by scarring.
  • The initial inflammation can lead to triggered ventricular arrhythmias with subsequent scarring resulting in the substrate for reentrant monomorphic ventricular tachycardia.
  • Echocardiographic abnormalities are quite variable and non-specific; interventricular thinning mostly involves bases and is typically involved in Sarcoidosis.

Other cardiac manifestations of Sarcoidosis include

  • A.V. Block
  • Restrictive cardiomyopathy
  • Pericardial effusion
  • Sudden cardiac death
  • An overall most common cause of death in Sarcoidosis - Respiratory Failure.

Option A: Pneumonia

  • Sarcoidosis is often associated with dyspnea, shortness of breath, and chest pain.
  • But it does not cause sudden death in patients.

Option B: Cor-pulmonale

  • Right heart failure is also called Cor-pulmonale
  • It rarely happens in Sarcoidosis
  • Cor pulmonale is often provoked by the invasion of the walls of pulmonary vessels by sarcoid granulomas.​​​​​​​

Option D: Liver failure

  • In 30% of cases sarcoidosis causes hepatomegaly and hepatic granulomas.
  • Almost 70% of patients have epithelioid non-caseating granulomas seen on liver biopsy.
  • Most cases involving the liver are asymptomatic and do not require any treatment.

questions.text: Mrs. X, a 20-year-old married lady, presented to the psychiatric department for consultation. After her marriage, she was used to enjoy sex for 5 to 6 hours daily. The couple enjoyed their sex daily, even on the days of menstruation. For the last one year, her husband stopped daily intercourses, as well as the duration of the intercourses, was also decreased below 1 hour. Subsequently, the lady felt disturbances and used to demand sex more time as well as orgasms daily. She used to consume pornography, masturbate and started extramarital relationships for sexual activity. She enjoys her persistent thoughts, fantasies regarding sex; however, she became frustrated when she was not getting the expected duration and expected number of orgasms. She asked her husband to divorce her as he was not being able to have intercourses for 5 to 6 hours daily. This condition is known as
questions.solution:
• Excessive sexual desire in females is known as nymphomania.
  • Satyriasis is the condition of excessive sexual desire in males
  • Tribadism/Lesbianism - sexual intercourse between two female partners.
  • Sadism - Type of sexual perversion in which person obtain sexual gratification by beating/assaulting/humiliating other partner. DSM-5 defines sexual sadism as the recurrent & intense sexual arousal from the physical and psychological suffering of another person. Minimum duration required for diagnosis is 6 months (DSM-5).

questions.text: An 18 yrs old, male was brought in with complaints of overeating, increased weight gain having BMI of 41.6 kg/m2 and noted to have mental retardation. He was diagnosed of having adult onset diabetes mellitus. Which of the following endocrine disorder best describes the above clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
Prader willi occurs due to deletion of paternal copies of imprinted SNRPN gene and NECDIN gene on chromosome 15q. It presents with:

  • Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism
  • Diabetes mellitus(adult onset)
  • Hyperphagia
  • Obesity
  • Muscle hypotonia
  • Mental retardation

questions.text: The eye's lens is a biconvex, relatively acellular, optically transparent intraocular structure that, with the cornea, transmits light to the retina with minimal light scattering. The lens can modify the shape, so that image of the object is focused on the retina. From which of the following embryologic structures is the lens derived?
questions.solution:
Option A: Surface ectoderm

  • The surface ectoderm gives rise to the lens, corneal epithelium, and lacrimal glands.

Embryonic layers

Structures derived

Surface ectoderm
  • The crystalline lens
  • Epithelium of the cornea
  • Epithelium of the conjunctiva
  • Lacrimal gland
  • Epithelium of eyelids and its derivatives viz., cilia, tarsal glands, and conjunctival glands.
  • Epithelium lining the lacrimal apparatus.

Neural ectoderm
  • Retina with its pigment epithelium
  • Epithelial layers of the ciliary body
  • Epithelial layers of the iris
  • Sphincter and dilator pupillae muscles
  • Optic nerve (neuroglia and nervous elements only)
  • Melanocytes
  • Secondary vitreous
  • Ciliary zonules (tertiary vitreous)

Associated paraxial mesenchyme
  • The choroid, iris, ciliary vessels, central retinal artery, and other blood vessels.
  • Primary vitreous
  • Substantia propria, Descemet's membrane, and endothelium of the cornea
  • The sclera
  • Stroma of iris
  • Ciliary muscle
  • Sheaths of the optic nerve
  • Extraocular muscles
  • Fat, ligaments, and other connective tissue structures of the orbit

Option B: Neural ectoderm

  • Neuroectoderm gives rise to the optic nerve, epithelium of the iris and ciliary body and sphincter and dilator muscles of the Iris.

Option C: Paraxial mesenchyme

  • The choroid, iris, ciliary vessels, central retinal artery, and other blood vessels.
  • Primary vitreous
  • Substantia propria, Descemet's membrane, and endothelium of the cornea
  • The sclera
  • Stroma of Iris
  • Ciliary muscle
  • Sheaths of the optic nerve
  • Extraocular muscles
  • Fat, ligaments and other connective tissue structures of the orbit

Option D: Neural crest cells

Give rise to:

  • The stroma of the cornea and choroid
  • Corneal endothelium
  • The sclera (except the temporal part)
  • Melanocyte
  • Corneal keratocytes
  • Ciliary muscles
  • Ciliary ganglion
  • Stroma of Iris
  • Choroid
  • Trabecular meshwork

questions.text: A 35-year-old mother of two has moderate psoriasis. She tells you that her mother had a similar condition 3 years ago and was successfully treated with the agent Acitretin. She was started on systemic steroids. After stopping the treatment, the patient developed generalized pustules all over the body. The cause is most likely to be:
questions.solution:
Patient of psoriasis on withdrawal of systemic steroids leads to:

  1. Pustular Psoriasis:
  • Multiple sterile pustules develop on whole body (including palms & soles)
    • k/a sterile as there is no infection, only infiltration present.
  • If generalized k/a Von Zumbusch disease.
  • Other provocating factors include
    • Infection,
    • Pregnancy and
    • Hypocalcemia associated with hypoparathyroidism.

2) Erythrodermic psoriasis : >90% body surface area shows redness/inflamed or/- scaling Systemic steroids are contraindicated in psoriasis as on withdrawal, it causes pustular psoriasis except in pregnancy where they are the drug of choice

Indications of Systemic steroids in Psoriasis
  1. Impetigo Herpetiformis
  2. Acute erythrodermic psoriasis
  3. Acute generalized pustular psoriasis
  4. Unstable Psoriasis
  5. Severe cases of Psoriatic arthritis

questions.text: Identify the ECG given in the figure below.
questions.solution:
The ECG shows the presence of variable heart rate due to the presence of irregularly irregular RR interval. The P waves in the ECG are not seen and QRS complex is normal duration. These point to the presence of atrial fibrillation.

Arrhythmia ECG pointers ECG appearance
Choice A Sinus rhythm P wave followed by normal duration qRS and concordant T wave.
Choice B PSVT Hidden P waves Narrow qRS Regular RR interval ST depression
Choice C Atrial fibrillation Absent P waves Narrow qRS irregular RR interval
Choice D Ventricular fibrillation Twitching with undulations seen on baseline ECG

questions.text: A patient of age 55 presented with the complaint of watery eyes, sensitivity to light and pain in the eyes. Later on, he is diagnosed with corneal dystrophy. Which of the following statements are true about macular  corneal dystrophy?

choices.text: Abnormal stromal deposits of mucopolysaccharides which stain positive with Alcian blue
Opacities are present throughout the cornea, with clear spaces in between

questions.solution:
Macular corneal dystrophy is a rare genetic disorder that affects the cornea of the eye. Let's review the statements:

Option A. Autosomal dominant inheritance - Incorrect. Macular corneal dystrophy is typically inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, which means that two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) are needed for the disease to manifest.

Option B. Laser therapy can be done - Correct. Laser therapy, specifically phototherapeutic keratectomy (PTK), can be used to treat some of the symptoms associated with macular corneal dystrophy, such as reducing the corneal opacities and improving vision.

Option C. Abnormal stromal deposits of mucopolysaccharides which stain positive with Alcian blue - Incorrect. Macular corneal dystrophy is characterized by the abnormal accumulation of mucopolysaccharides in the corneal stroma. These deposits typically stain negative with Alcian blue.

Option D. Opacities are present throughout the cornea, with clear spaces in between - Incorrect. In macular corneal dystrophy, the corneal opacities are typically not evenly distributed throughout the cornea with clear spaces in between. Instead, there is a progressive accumulation of opacities, primarily in the central and mid-peripheral cornea, leading to visual impairment.
