B is done to test for DDH
A is test for superolateral dislocation
A is done for reduction of the dislocated hip

questions.solution:
Barlow test

  • It is done to test for DDH.
  • The infant is supine with the knees fully flexed and the hip at 90 degrees of flexion.
  • The thigh is grasped and the hip is slowly adducted to 45 degrees while applying downward and lateral pressure.
  • This test is positive when the joint is dislocatable and a clunk is heard.

Ortolani's test indicates the reduction of the dislocated hip.

Allis or Galeazzi test for superolateral dislocation

  • Knee of normal side is higher than the knee of affected side

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman with 21 weeks of gestation came to gynecology OPD for an antenatal checkup. The doctor decided to check the cardiac valve motion and fetal heart rate of the baby. Which mode of ultrasound is used in this case?
questions.solution:
• M-Mode Ultrasound is Motion mode and is used to evaluate Fetal Heart Rate and Cardiac Valve movement and echocardiography. Also used for detection of pneumothorax.
  • A Mode Ultrasound is Amplitude Mode for measuring Axial length of Eyeball and orbital biometry (A scan in Opthalmology is the A Mode Ultrasound)
  • B Mode Ultrasound is most commonly used mode. It is Brightness mode for routine Ultrasound.
  • M Mode used in antenatal scan to calculate feral heart rate.

questions.text: A 30-year-old mother of three children who had no history of mental illness before gave birth to her third child 4 weeks ago. Her pregnancy and labor had been uneventful & as she had delivered baby boy at the general hospital within the city. For the last one week, family and friends noticed a change in her overall mood. She was no longer cheerful and was constantly feeling tired. She had lost interest in her daily and community activities. She became irritable & agitated and was having difficulty sleeping. She became more religious and talked about god and evil obsessively. She also stated that she started to hear God talking to her and that she would need to sacrifice her baby to cleanse the sins of her family.
questions.solution:
Post-partum psychosis – usually in first 2-3 weeks of post-partum (onset should be <6 weeks postpartum)

  • characterized by the mother’s depression, delusions, and thoughts of harming either herself or her infant
  • It may involve the idea that the baby is dead or defective. Patients may deny the birth and express thoughts of being unmarried, virginal, persecuted, or perverse
  • Some patients may attempt to kill the child to spare it from future suffering.
Post-partum blues - women experience a brief episode of irritability, muddled thinking, tearfulness, and lability of mood, which is particularly characteristic
Post-partum depression - Tiredness, irritability, and anxiety are often more prominent than depressive mood and there may be prominent phobic symptoms.

HOW TO REMEMBER: postpartum: blues=mood is affected; depression=neglect of self; psychosis= neglect of others(mostly baby)

questions.text: Wartenberg's sign refers to the slightly greater abduction of the fifth digit, due to paralysis of the abducting palmar interosseous muscle and unopposed action of the radial innervated extensor muscles. The nerve damage that causes this sign is injured in which of the following fracture?
questions.solution:
• Wartenberg's sign is a neurological sign consisting of involuntary abduction of the fifth (little) finger, caused by unopposed action of the extensor digiti minimi.
  • This commonly results from weakness of some of the ulnar nerve innervated intrinsic hand muscles -in particular the palmar interosseous muscle to the little finger- caused by damage to their nerve supply (denervation).
  • Fracture medial epicondyle humerus may be associated with ulnar nerve injury.

Other signs of ulnar nerve involvement:

  • ulnar nerve palsy results in paralysis of the intrinsic muscles (adductor pollicis, deep head FPB, interossei, and lumbricals 4 and 5)
  • weakened grasp
    • from loss of MP joint flexion power
  • weak pinch
    • from loss of thumb adduction
  • Froment sign
    • IP flexion compensating for the loss of thumb adduction when attempting to hold a piece of paper
    • loss of MCP flexion and adduction by adductor pollicis (ulnar n.)
    • compensatory IP hyperflexion by FPL (Anterior Interosseous Nerve)
  • Jeane's sign
    • a compensatory thumb MCP hyperextension and thumb adduction by EPL (radial n.)
    • compensates for the loss of IP extension and thumb adduction by adductor pollicis (ulna n.)

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man comes to the ENT outpatient department complaining of progressive hearing loss. He also complained of having difficulty hearing loud sounds. The doctor has checked the acoustic reflex through tympanometry to assess his conductive hearing. Which of the following statement is incorrect regarding the Acoustic Reflex?


	It helps in enhancing the sound conduction in the middle ear
	It is a protective reflex against loud sounds.
	It helps in masking the sound waves
	It is a unilateral reflex
	Whenever there are sounds more significant than 50dB, it is activated
questions.solution:
Option C: Only 1,3,4,5

In all the statements above, only statement 2 is correct; remaining all the statements are incorrect regarding acoustic reflex.

  • Whenever there is a loud sound 70-100 dB above a person's hearing threshold, the Stapedial reflex gets activated and protects the inner ear from noise trauma.
  • It is a bilateral reflex. (The neuronal circuitry of the reflex crosses over to the other side, and therefore the reflex can be checked by both ipsilateral and contralateral stimuli delivered to one ear).
  • Stapedius muscle contraction is responsible for the stapedial reflex, which moves the stapes about 50 microns, increases the hardness of the ossicular chain, and can attenuate the sound transmission to the inner ear by as much as 30dB.
  • It is believed that the most important utility of measuring the stapedial reflex is to screen for auditory neuropathy spectrum disorder (ANSD) in case of hearing/listening problems with preserved otoacoustic emissions.
  • Tympanometry can be used to measure the acoustic stapedial reflex threshold.

Option A: Only 1, 2, 4, 5

In this option, all the statements are incorrect except statement 2

  • It is a protective reflex against loud sounds.
  • The rest of the statements are incorrect that it doesn’t help to enhance the sound conduction in the middle ear.
  • It is bilateral.
  • It is activated whenever sounds greater than 70-100dB.

Option B: All are incorrect

  • In the statements given above regarding the stapedial reflex, all the statements are incorrect, except it is a protective reflex against loud sounds.
  • The rest of the statements are incorrect.

Option D: Only 1

  • Not only is statement 1 incorrect other statements are also incorrect except 2, as this reflex is a protective reflex against loud sounds.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman presents in the hospital with complaints of painful joints in the hands. She also complained of morning stiffness associated with a decrease in the intensity of the pain after physical activity. On examination, a decrease in the range of movement and a weakening in hand grip and strength along with trigger fingers were noticed. Which of the following would be the earliest radiological change in such patients?
questions.solution:
Option C: Periarticular osteopenia

  • Painful small joints of hands with morning stiffness and trigger finger are classic features suggestive of Rheumatoid Arthritis.
  • Periarticular osteopenia is one of the earliest manifestations of RA, which can be observed on an x-ray.
  • Rheumatoid arthritis's clinical features include
  • Early morning joint stiffness that lasts more than 01 hours and eases with physical activity.
  • The earliest involved joints are the small joints of the hands and feet.
  • Wrist, metacarpophalangeal,(MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints are primarily involved in RA.
  • Distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint may or may not be involved due to co-existing osteoarthritis.
  • Joint involvement will always be in a symmetrical pattern.
  • The introduction of disease-modifying therapies has revolutionized the management of rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
  • Radiological features of RA
    • Evidence of soft tissue swelling and joint effusion
    • Symmetrical involvement
    • Juxta-articular osteopenia (within weeks)
    • Loss of articular cartilage and bone erosions (after months)
    • Narrowing of joint space
    • Articular destruction and joint deformity, e.g. subluxation of atlantoaxial and cervical joints
    • Lack of hypertrophic bone changes (sclerosis or osteophyte)

Option A: Decreased joint space

  • The decrease in bone mass is called osteopenia, which can lead to loss of joint space, juxta-articular osteoporosis, and soft-tissue swelling, which are early manifestations of RA but not the earliest manifestations of the disease in radiographs.

Option B: Articular erosion

  • Periarticular erosions result from excessive local bone resorption and inadequate bone formation, which is seen during the late stage of RA and secondary hyperparathyroidism.

Option D: Subchondral cyst

  • Subchondral cysts are fluid-filled sac that forms in the bone beneath the cartilage of a joint such as the hip, knee, or shoulder.
  • These are most commonly seen in patients with osteoarthritis but can be formed in the late stages of RA.

questions.text: G2P1L1, diabetic pregnant lady with 32 weeks of pregnancy comes with a USG showing fetal weight of 3.11 Kg. The previous pregnancy was terminated by emergency LSCS for fetal distress. The best plan of action is:
questions.solution: The patient is a case of previous LSCS with big baby (already the weight at 32 weeks is 3.1 Kg; the normal weight at 32 weeks is 1.5–1.8 Kg). Induction of labor in a case of previous LSCS is usually avoided (increased risk of scar rupture) and trial of scar in case of big baby also increases the risk of scar rupture. So LSCS is the preferred modality of delivery in a case of previous LSCS with a big baby and patient not in labor. Now the question is when to do the LSCS ? In babies of diabetic mother, the lung maturity is delayed and so LSCS cannot be done at 36 weeks. But babies of diabetic mothers have one more risk, which is that of sudden IUFD at term (40 weeks). So the babies of diabetic mothers should be delivered (by LSCS in this case) between 38 and 39 weeks of gestation. If she is a patient without any previous scar on uterus and if the pelvis is adequate, then labor should be induced at 38–39 weeks.

questions.text: A 28yrs old male patient presented with a history of two episodes of hematemesis over 48 hours. There was no history of the acid peptic disease, NSAID intake, or chronic liver disease. On examination, his heart rate was 110 beats/min & noted to be pallor. On upper GI endoscopy, findings revealed a persistent calibre artery. All of the following are true about persistent calibre artery except:

choices.text: Thermal coagulation is an effective option for the management

questions.solution:
Option D: Deep enteroscopy is useful

  • A persistent calibre artery is called Dieulafoy's lesion. It is a large calibre arteriole that runs beneath the gut mucosa and bleeds via pinpoint mucosal erosion.
  • For the management of bleeding in Dieulafoy's lesion, endoscopic therapy like thermal coagulation or band ligation is effective.
  • In case of failure to control bleeding with the above methods, angiographic embolization is used.
  • Deep enteroscopy is used in patients with diffuse small bowel pathology like vascular ectasia.

Option A: Thermal coagulation is an effective option for the management

  • Thermal coagulation is gaining popularity for treating cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) in cervical cancer screening programs in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) due to the unavailability of gas and high maintenance for cryotherapy.
  • Thermal coagulation is an alternative ablative technique using electricity to destroy the premalignant cervical lesions by heating.
  • The device is small and lightweight, making it practical in an outpatient setting with minimal complications.
  • These advantages are significant in rural and outreach settings.

Option B: Angiographic embolization is useful

  •  Angiographic embolization is an effective technique to control bleeding after blunt trauma to the liver or pelvis.
  • Its role in penetrating trauma to the abdomen has not been studied.
  • Embolization procedures stops blood flow to a specific blood vessel
  • Treatment works by placing a substance in the vessel to prevent blood from flowing through it.
  • The patient may need this procedure if the patient has excessive bleeding, a vascular malformation or a tumour.

Option C: Bleeds via pin point mucosal erosion

  • Erosive gastritis is gastric mucosal erosion caused by damage to mucosal defences.
  • It is typically acute, manifesting with bleeding, but may be subacute or chronic with few or no symptoms.
  • Diagnosis is by endoscopy.
  • Treatment is supportive, with removing the inciting cause and initiating acid-suppressant therapy.
  • Gastric erosive changes are a common cause of UGI bleeding, and hemorrhagic erosive gastritis is thought to be responsible for 10% to 20% of upper tract bleeding. Other causes that may result in gastric mucosal erosions include Crohn's disease and viral gastritis, such as cytomegalovirus or herpesvirus.

questions.text: A 61-year-old gentleman presented with a history of loose stools for 5 years, passing 3–4 semisolid stools/day. The stools were at times oily in nature without mucus or blood. There was no significant loss of weight or anorexia. He was a known case of diabetes mellitus for 15 years and also had chronic pulmonary obstructive disease for the past 5 years. He was a reformed smoker and a social drinker. There was no prior history of abdominal trauma or surgery. His clinical examination was unremarkable. Which of the following diagnostic test you will do next ?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is Pancreatic steatorrhea.

  • The fecal elastase-1 and small bowel biopsy are useful in the evaluation of patients with suspected pancreatic steatorrhea.
  • A decrease of fecal elastase level to <100 μg per gram of stool strongly suggests severe pancreatic exocrine insufficiency.
  • The diagnostic test with the best sensitivity and specificity in chronic pancreatitis is the hormone stimulation test utilizing secretin. It becomes abnormal when > 60% of the pancreatic exocrine function has been lost.
  • In contrast to acute pancreatitis, the serum amylase and lipase levels are usually not strikingly elevated in chronic pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 79-year-old man is brought to the casualty with sudden syncopal episode while walking on the road. He is currently alert and describes occasional substernal heaviness and shortness of breath. His lungs have bibasilar rales and BP is 120/80mmHg. Which is the classical finding expected in this patient?

choices.text: Ejection systolic murmur with soft S2
Ejection systolic murmur with wide split S2
Harsh holosystolic murmur with soft S2
Harsh pan systolic murmur with loud S2

questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of exertional syncope, angina equivalent and dyspnea in geriatric age group points to diagnosis of valvular Aortic stenosis.

In aortic stenosis

  • Soft S2( due to poor mobility of a stenosed valve)
  • REVERSE S2 SPLIT
  • S3, S4 in advanced cases
  • Ejection Click Ejection systolic murmur
  • Pulsus et tardus

so option A is correct

  • Choice B is wrong because in aortic stenosis, narrow split S2 or paradoxical split S2 is heard.
  • Choice C and D are wrong due to presence of Ejection systolic murmur in aortic stenosis.

Points to remember

  • Ejection systolic murmur = aortic stenosis / pulmonary stenosis
  • Pan systolic murmur = VSD, chronic MR, Chronic TR
  • Wide split S2 = VSD, MR, Pulmonary stenosis, RVF
  • Loud S2 = Pulmonary hypertension, systemic hypertension

questions.text: A boy of 3 years and 3 months of age was reported to have fallen from the front child seat of a bicycle. The boy’s mother reported no history of loss of consciousness or vomiting. A facial examination revealed no abnormalities with the exception of a small subcutaneous ecchymosis in the left lower eyelid. Orbital floor fracture was suspected and an X-ray of the orbital floor was requested. Which among the following would have been the X-ray view taken for this patient by the X-ray technician?
questions.solution:
X-Ray views for evaluating Orbit:

1. Rhese view is used for Optic Canal

2. Caldwell View is for Superior Orbital fissure

3. Townes View for Inferior Orbital Fissure

4. Waters View for Orbital Floor

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents to the emergency department due to a sudden loss of vision in the right eye. It is associated with pain on eye movement. She had a history of acute disseminated encephalomyelitis 2 months ago, for which she was treated with oral prednisolone. On examination, she can only count fingers when seeing from the right eye (visual acuity). A positive afferent pupillary defect is also present. The ophthalmologist suspects optic neuritis. Which of the following is least likely to diagnose optic neuritis?
questions.solution:
Option C: B-scan ultrasonography (USG)

  • Optic neuritis is a severe, painful visual impairment typically affecting young people.
  • Demyelinating disease, such as multiple sclerosis, is its most frequent cause.
  • Other causes include infections (measles, mumps,  tuberculosis, Lyme disease) and autoimmune disorders (sarcoidosis, systemic lupus erythematosus).
  • Common symptoms include unilateral progressive vision loss, impaired colour vision, pain in eye movement, the presence of relative afferent pupillary deficit (RAPD), and normal-appearing fundus with mild papilledema in ⅓ patients.
  • The investigations used to diagnose optic neuritis involve:
  • MRI
  • Blood tests (ESR, antibodies in neuromyelitis optica)
  • Optical coherence tomography (OCT)
  • Visual field test
  • Visual evoked response.
  • B-scan ultrasonography (USG) is used to diagnose conditions affecting the eyeball's posterior segment.
  • Common diseases in which a USG B scan is used are vitreous degeneration, retinal detachment, trauma, and retinoblastoma.
  • However, it is not useful for diagnosing optic neuritis.

Option A: MRI head and orbit

  • MRI head and orbit is the most important test that detects optic nerve inflammation.
  • It also reveals demyelination foci in the brain, especially in periventricular white matter regions, seen in a patient with multiple sclerosis.

 

Option B:  Erythrocyte sedimentation rate

  • ESR (erythrocyte sedimentation) rate help detect inflammation in the body.
  • It is a nonspecific marker that is increased in infectious causes of optic neuritis.

Option D: Visual field test

  • Checking the visual field is useful for evaluating the progression and extent of the disease and is also important for follow-up.

questions.text: A 29-year-old Indian woman presents with history of involuntary leakage of urine. The dribbling occurs all the time irrespective of position or activity and the patient passes only minimal urine while voiding. The most important history to elicit here is?
questions.solution:
History is suggestive of a genitourinary fistula (continuous involuntary leak with abnormal voiding)

Causes of vesico vaginal fistula:

  • Gynaecological Surgery: Most common cause in developed countries Obstetric injury/
  • Obstructed labour (leading to tissue necrosis): Most common cause in developing countries
  • Radiation
  • Malignancy
  • Foreign bodies: forgotten pessaries
  • Direct trauma
  • Infective: TB, schistosomiasis, syphilis, LGV
  • Endometriosis, perforating bladder calculi

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents to the ophthalmology OPD with complaints of floaters and painless vision loss in the left eye. The patient described the sensation that a curtain was coming up over his affected eye, and this curtain is now affecting his central vision. The patient stated that nine days prior, he was struck in the face by shrapnel from an explosion at his workplace, for which he did not seek medical attention at that time as there were no hospitals nearby. After a detailed evaluation by the ophthalmologist, he was diagnosed with rhegmatogenous retinal detachment. Which of the following is the risk factor for Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Aphakia

  • Aphakia can lead to the development of Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment.
  • Aphakia is when a person doesn't have a lens in one or both eyes. It can be congenital or acquired at any stage of life after surgery or injury. The complications are uncommon, but they can lead to RRD's development.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Blurred vision.
    • Farsightedness (hyperopia).
    • Difficult focusing on objects.
    • Decreasing focus when the distance from an object changes.
    • The colors seem faded.
  • A rhegmatogenous retinal detachment (RRD) occurs when a tear in the retina leads to fluid accumulation with a separation of the neurosensory retina from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium. This is the most common type of retinal detachment.
  • Features:
    • Visual field defect.
    • Floaters.
    • Loss of central vision.
  • Risk factors for RRD:
    • Myopia (especially high myopia).
    • Previous intra-ocular surgery.
    • Aphakia, Pseudophakia.
    • Family History of Retinal Detachment.
    • Trauma.
    • Inflammation.
    • Retinal Necrosis - Acute Retinal Necrosis, CMV Retinitis.
    • Drugs – Pilocarpine.

Option B: Toxaemia of pregnancy

  • Preeclampsia is defined as systolic blood pressure more than or equal to 140 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure more than or equal to 90 mm Hg or higher, on two occasions at least 4 hours apart in a previously normotensive patient. In addition to this criterion, proteinuria of more than 0.3 gms in a 24-hour urine specimen or a PCR ratio of 0.3 or greater is required to diagnose preeclampsia.
  • The patient may present with retinal involvement as well.
  • Exudative retinal detachment can be found in 1-2% of the cases with preeclampsia/eclampsia.

Option C: Malignant Hypertension

  • Hypertension is a risk factor for many systemic conditions that can progress to end-organ damage. Specifically, hypertension may lead to multiple adverse effects on the CNS, Heart, Kidneys and Eyes.
  • Hypertension predisposes patients to many retinal vascular diseases, including central or branch retinal artery occlusion, central or branches retinal vein occlusion and retinal arterial macro aneurysms.
  • Ischemia secondary to vascular occlusions can cause neovascularization, vitreous hemorrhage, epiretinal membrane formation, and exudative retinal detachment.

Option D: Posterior scleritis

  • It's a painful inflammation of the sclera posterior to the ora Serrata.
  • Posterior scleritis represents approximately 10 percent of all cases of scleritis, half of which can be associated with Rheumatoid Arthritis but sometimes with systemic lupus erythematous and granulomatous polyangiitis as well.
  • The main presenting symptom of posterior scleritis is moderate to severe pain. It can manifest as rarely exudative retinal detachment, choroidal folds, or both.

questions.text: A primigravida presents for a routine check-up at 36 weeks. Her antenatal ultrasound doppler suggests umbilical cord vessels overlying internal os just prior to their insertion into the placenta at its margin. All of the following are true regarding this condition, EXCEPT?

choices.text: APT test is the investigation of choice for diagnosing Vasa previa
Very high perinatal mortality as blood loss is exclusively fetal
An urgent cesarean is usually the best option to save the fetus

questions.solution:
Vasa previa:

This finding is associated with velamentous insertion when some of the fetal vessels in the membranes cross the region of the cervical os below the presenting fetal part. Marginal cord insertions and bilobed or succenturiate-lobed placentas are also associated with vasa previa.

Color Doppler is the investigation of choice.

With vasa previa, there is considerable potential fetal danger because membrane rupture may be accompanied by tearing of a fetal vessel. This is a/w very high perinatal mortality as there is exclusive fetal blood loss. Low-lying placenta is a risk factor in 80% of cases.

Patients of vasa previa should be delivered by elective LSCS.

The Apt test is a medical test used to differentiate maternal and fetal blood.

A positive test would indicate that blood is of fetal origin, and could be due to vasa previa. A negative test indicates that the blood is of maternal origin. In practice, the Apt test is almost never done when there is bleeding PV and a suspicion of vasa previa, because the time to fetal collapse with bleeding from vasa previa is often very short.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician's office by her parents for the complaint of hoarseness of voice for the past few weeks. Which of the following treatment is done for Juvenile onset recurrent respiratory papillomatosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Bevacizumab

Juvenile onset Respiratory Papilloma:

  • Most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children.
  • Causative organism: Human papilloma virus 6 and 11.
  • HPV 6 is more common, HPV 11 is more aggressive
  • Mostly affects supraglottic and glottic regions of the larynx.
  • Affect the boys and girls equally
  • The patient presents at the age of 4 months to 13 years.
  • Treatment
    • Preferred method: Excision with microdebrider under microscopic view. The therapy aims to maintain the airway, preserve voice and avoid recurrence.
    • Carbon dioxide (CO2) laser excision is not preferred nowadays as fumes emitted during surgery contain the HPV virus, which can infect the operating surgeon and the operation theatre personnel.
    • Coblation & photodynamic therapy (PDT) are also being tried to decrease the recurrence rate

⇒ Medical Therapy is mainly used as adjuvant therapy to prevent a recurrence. They act by 3 actions:

  • Antiviral
  • Antiproliferative
  • Immunomodulatory

Examples:

S. No Drug Name Action
1 Interferon-α

(Interferon-alpha)

 a. Interferes with normal host cell translation mechanisms and induces synthesis of intracellular enzymes that act to control viral growth

b. Depletes essential metabolites in papilloma cells and increases the length of their multiplication cycle

c. Facilitates recognition of papilloma cells by circulating leucocytes by enhancing expression of cell surface antigens
2. Bevacizumab Recombinant monoclonal antibody: inhibits angiogenesis (VEGF-A), thereby inhibiting the blood supply of the tumor cells.
3. Cidofovir

(Intralesional)

 Acyclic nucleoside phosphonate: inhibition of viral DNA polymerases
4. Ribarvarin

(aerosol)

 Synthetic nucleoside (broad spectrum antiviral)
5. Acyclovir Nucleoside analog, which inhibits thymidine kinase
6. Indole-3-Carbinol Affects estrogen metabolism shifting production to antiproliferative estrogen
7. Cimetidine Histamine receptor type 2 (H2) antagonist

Option B: Aerosol Cidofovir.

  • It is an acyclic nucleoside phosphonate that works by inhibiting the viral DNA polymerases.

Option C: Interferon beta.

  • Used mainly for multiple sclerosis. Interferon alpha is used as adjunctive therapy for JORRP.

Option D: Steroids.

  • Contact ulcer or granuloma occurs due to faulty voice production in which vocal processes of arytenoids hammer against each other, resulting in ulceration and granuloma formation.
  • Chief complaints include hoarseness of voice, desire to clear throat, and pain in the throat that is worse on phonation.
  • Inhaled or intralesional steroids are used to correct the inflammation and size of a granuloma.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents to your clinic with the chief compliant of dark colour urine and intermittent flank pain. His family history is remarkable for hemorrhagic stroke in his father. His temperature is (36.4°C), BP 180/110 mmHg, PR 82/min, RR 16/min. On physical examination you noted bilateral palpable flank masses and discomfort to percussion of the costovertebral angle. Lab investigations done. Urinalysis shows red blood cells without any bacteria or nitrites. Which of the following diagnostic modalities can be used ?
questions.solution: Ultrasonography reveals large, echogenic kidneys with poor corticomedullary differentiation.The diagnosis can be made in utero after 24 weeks of gestation in severe case. The absence of renal cysts in either parent, particularly if they are >40 years of age on ultrasonography helps distinguish autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) from ADPKD in older patients. The lack of mutational hot spots and the large and complex genomic structure of PKHD1 make molecular diagnosis difficult

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman came to the Medical outpatient department complaining of blurry vision; on inquiring, she told me she had been a patient of diabetes for 10 years. Moreover, have uncontrollable Blood pressure and kidney disease. She told the doctor that she had been diagnosed with proliferative diabetic retinopathy a few months ago. Now she complains of floaters and painless loss of vision. The doctor thinks of retinal detachment. Which type of retinal detachment is most commonly seen in proliferative diabetic retinopathy?
questions.solution:
Option B: Tractional

  • The most severe type of diabetic retinal illness is called tractional retinal detachment.
  • Tractional refers to tugging on the retinal surface, but "retinal detachment" denotes pulling powerful enough to pull the light-sensing retina away from the back of the eye. 
  • Damaged retinal blood vessels give rise to abnormal blood vessels that eventually form the vitreous, the jelly inside the eye.
  • These blood arteries densify and develop into membranes of fibrous scar tissue as they expand into jelly.
  • When the scar tissue eventually contracts, the retina is pulled away.
  • There are occasions when the retina is under such a lot of strain that tears or holes develop.
  • Diabetic tractional retinal detachment is the most advanced form of diabetic retinal disease. "Tractional" means that there is pulling on the retinal surface, and "retinal detachment" means that the pulling is strong enough to separate the light-sensing retina from the back of the eye.

Pathophysiology

  • Contractile vitreoretinal, epiretinal, intraretinal (rarely), or subretinal membranes pull the neurosensory retina away from the RPE in TRD related to proliferative vitreoretinopathy (PVR) and penetrating trauma. 
  • PVR might be viewed as an improper or uncontrolled response to the healing process. The cellular makeup of these membranes was discovered through microscopic analysis.
  • These membranes contain RPE cells, glial cells, fibrocytes, macrophages, and collagen fibrils, among other critical components. 
  • The main participants in these membranes are RPE cells.
  • When the retina breaks form, they can enter the vitreous cavity.
  • It has been demonstrated that the magnitude of the retinal fractures correlates with the number of RPE cells in the vitreous cavity.
  • There are more RPE cells intravitreally when the break is greater.
  • Additionally, severe cryotherapy, cryotherapy applied to bare RPE, and scleral indentation after cryotherapy can all cause RPE cells to disseminate into the vitreous cavity.
  • The RPE cells undergo morphological changes once they are inside the vitreous cavity, where they have fibroblast-like activity and secrete growth factors that encourage collagen synthesis.
  • Causes:
    • Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy
    • Penetrating trauma
    • Proliferative sickle retinopathy
    • Retinal venous occlusions

Option A: Rhegmatogenous

  • The most typical form of retinal detachment is Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment. If your retina has a little tear or crack, it may occur. 
  • If the retina tears or fractures, the gel-like fluid in the center of your eye, known as the vitreous, may get behind your retina. The vitreous then pushes the retina away from the rear of the eye, causing it to split. 
  • The commonest cause of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment is aging. As you age, the vitreous tissue in your eye may shrink and change in texture. Your retina may occasionally injure if the vitreous shrinks and pulls on it.
  • Nearsightedness, eye injury, and rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.

Option B: Exudative

  • Exudative retinal detachment occurs when fluid accumulates behind the retina, but the retina is neither torn nor broken. Your retina may be pushed away from the back of your eye and detached if enough fluid becomes trapped behind it.
  • The most common causes of exudative retinal detachment are leaking blood vessels or swelling in the back of the eye.
  • Several things can cause swelling in your eye:
    • Injury or trauma to your eye
    • Tumors in your eye
    • Diseases that cause inflammation inside the eye
    • Coats disease, a rare eye disorder

Option D: Retinoschisis

  • A disorder known as retinoschisis occurs when a portion of the retina, which lines the interior of the back of the eye and transmits visual information to the brain and optic nerve, has split into two layers.
  • There will be poor vision in the area of the retina that is afflicted by retinoschisis.
  • This can happen in various retinal layers and for various reasons.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents to the emergency department with the chief compliant of penile pain after engaging in intercourse with his girlfriend. He states that his penis appears swollen and is painful. He rated the pain scale to be 9/10. His vitals are T- 37.0°C, BP-120/80mmHg, PR-92/min, RR- 11/min and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical examination tip of the penis is dark red or blue in color and he was not able to pull the foreskin back over the tip of the penis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: This patient is dealing with paraphimosis. It results when the tight foreskin once retracted may be difficult to return . In this condition, the venous and lymphatic return from the glans and distal foreskin is obstructed and these structures swell, causing even more pressure within the obstructing ring of prepuce. Icebags, gentle manual compression and injection of a solution of hyaluronidase in normal saline may help to reduce the swelling. Such patients can be treated by circumcision if careful manipulation fails. A dorsal slit of the prepuce under local anaesthetic may be enough in an emergency

questions.text: A 35 years old patient reported to the hospital with skin lesions of 1-month duration. Lesions were papules to begin with, which first started from the tip of the nose then spreading to the rest of the body. Later they turned into crusted plaques and nodules of varying size. He gave a history of insect bites before 1 month when he went trekking in the mountainside. On examination, there were multiple crusted plaques and nodular lesions which were chiefly asymptomatic. Many of them were accompanied by satellite lesions. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
H/o insect bite followed by the events leading to ulceration in a resident or traveler to an endemic focus strongly suggests cutaneous Leishmaniasis (CL).

Cutaneous Leishmaniasis

  • Leishmaniasis is a group of infections caused by intracellular protozoan parasites belonging to the genus Leishmania, family Trypanosomatidae, order Kinetoplastida.
  • Depending on the extent and severity of involvement, infections in the human host can be classified as
    • Cutaneous leishmaniasis - New world – L.braziliensis, L.mexicana and Old world – L.major, L.tropica, L.aethiopica, L.infantum
    • Diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis – L.mexicana, L.aethiopica
    • Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis – L.braziliensis, L.aethiopica
    • Visceral leishmaniasis – L.donovani, L.infantum
  • Most commonly present as papules or nodules at the site of insect bite enlarge progressively to form plaques that show central ulceration and crusting and heal with scarring.
  • Post-Kala Azar dermal Leishmaniasis: Hypopigmented lesions over trunk & Nodular lesions over the face in cases of treated or healed visceral leishmaniasis.
  • The demonstration of amastigotes in material obtained from a lesion remains the diagnostic gold standard.
Leprosy Hypopigmented hypo aesthetic plaques with surface showing loss of appendages, dryness and thickened peripheral nerves.
Chronic Fungal infection Varied morphologies with swelling, induration, pus discharge, nasal architectural disruption. Agents like - rhinosporidiosis, mucormycosis, actinomycosis.
Cutaneous tuberculosis Slowly enlarging infiltrated plaque with expanding edge and healing with scarring at other ends.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old male presents to the clinic with a history of nasal discharge for the past three weeks. The attending doctor orders nasal endoscopy to evaluate internal nasal structures. While doing endoscopy, he comes across the structures known as turbinates. Which of the following statements is correct regarding turbinates of the nose?


	The superior turbinate is a part of the ethmoid bone
	The middle turbinate is a part of the ethmoid bone
	The inferior turbinate is a part of the ethmoid bone
	The Inferior turbinate is a separate bone
questions.solution:
Option B: 1,2,4 are correct

  • The superior and middle turbinates are parts of the ethmoid bone, whereas the inferior turbinate is a separate independent bone.
  • Inferior Turbinate: It is a separate bone, and below it, into the inferior meatus, opens the nasolacrimal duct guarded at its terminal end by a mucosal valve called Hasner's valve.
  • Middle Turbinate:
    • It is an ethmoturbinal-a part of the ethmoid bone.
    • It is attached to the lateral wall by a bony lamella called ground or basal lamella.
    • Its attachment is not straight but in an S-shaped manner.
    • The Ostia of various sinuses draining anterior to basal lamella form the anterior group of paranasal sinuses, while those which open posterior and superior to it form the posterior group

Option A: 1, 2, 3 are correct

  • The superior turbinate and middle turbinate are a part of the ethmoid bone while inferior turbinate is an independent bone.

Option C: All are correct

  • The superior is a part of the ethmoid bone contains superior and middle turbinate
  • Inferior turbinate is not a part of any bone rather it is considered as a separate bone.

Option D: All are incorrect

  • Although superior and middle turbinates are the part of the ethmoid bone, inferior turbinate is not a part of any bone.

questions.text: A newborn baby boy is brought to your clinic by his mother, who reports that the infant is constantly crying and that his scrotum seems much bigger than it was at birth just 2 days ago. A mass that does not transilluminate is seen in one of the testicles when the physician shines a light next to it. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• This infant is irritable and has scrotal mass.
  • Although these symptoms may be caused by a variety of pathologies in a newborn, the additional finding of a testicle that does not transilluminate points towards an Indirect inguinal hernia.
  • Indirect inguinal hernias occur most frequently in newborn male infants. ( Fewer than 1% of cases are seen in female infants)
  • In this case, the peritoneum goes through the deep inguinal ring and enters the scrotum because the processus vaginalis has failed to close.
  • An indirect inguinal hernia passes lateral to the inferior epigastric artery.
  • Indirect inguinal hernia typically present as scrotal swelling that does not transilluminate when light is pressed against the scrotum.
  • Babies affected by this condition are frequently irritable owing to associated pain.

questions.text: IVU of the patient is diagnostic of:
questions.solution:
• The image shows clubbing of calyces and dilatation of the pelvis diagnostic of Hydronephrosis
  • In a duplication of the renal system, the drooping lily sign will have an inferior displacement of the ureter.
  • Papillary necrosis will show ring sign due to sloughed papillae.
  • VUR is ruled out since no reflux is seen from the bladder retrogradely on either side.

questions.text: An 88-year-old farmer was brought to your dermatology clinic with the complaint of a growth/lesion as shown in the image below. What would be the most appropriate treatment that you can advise for this patient?
questions.solution:
Cutaneous horn (cornu cutaneum)

  • Conical, hyperkeratotic, protuberant mass composed of compact keratin caused by increased adhesiveness of the keratinized material..
  • Present as a hard, yellowish-brown protrusion, often curved and have circumferential ridges, which are surrounded by either a normal-appearing epidermis or an acanthotic collarette
  • Most frequently occur in sun-exposed parts and are typically found on the face and scalp,
  • May overlie a wide variety of benign, premalignant and malignant conditions such as seborrheic keratoses, nevus, wart, molluscum contagiosum, rhinosporidiosis, psoriasis, lichen planus, porokeratosis, actinic keratosis, histiocytoma, follicular infundibulum tumor, keratoacanthoma, basal cell carcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma.
  • Should be excised fully including the base to allow the histological exclusion of an underlying squamous cell carcinoma.
  • Cryotherapy will not provide a tissue for histology and
  • Curettage or shave biopsy may yield insufficient depth for diagnosis.

questions.text:
True/False
1. Most common cause of blepharoconjunctivitis is staph aureus
2.Most common cause of pseudo membranous conjunctivitis is staphylococcus
3. Staph epidermidis is most common cause of angular conjunctivitis and angular blepharoconjunctivitis.
4.Corynebacterium diphtheriae causes acute membranous conjunctivitis
questions.solution:
The most common cause of blepharoconjuctivitis is staph aureus

Staphylococcus epidermidis is an innocuous flora of lid and conjunctiva. It can also produce blepharoconjunctivitis.

Moraxella lacunata is most common cause of angular conjunctivitis and angular blepharoconjunctivitis.

Corynebacterium diphtheriae causes acute membranous conjunctivitis

Most common cause of pseudo membranous conjunctivitis is staph aureus

questions.text: Aron is a 57-year-old man. He works as a business consultant in a private company. Recently he feels restless all the time and is unable to finish his work on time. He presented to the clinic today morning with fever, tachycardia, confusion, and vomiting. On investigation, he had a markedly elevated level of T3 and T4 levels. He is suffering from a thyroid storm. Which among the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Administration of fluid, antithyroid drugs, β-blockers, iodine solution, and steroids

questions.solution: A thyroid storm is dangerous if it is not appropriately managed in an intensive care unit setting. Treatment is done with rapid fluid replacement, antithyroid medication such as propylthiouracil (PTU), β-blockers, iodine solutions, and steroids. Β-Blockers are used to reduce peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 and decrease the hyperthyroid symptoms. Lugol iodine helps in decreasing iodine uptake and thyroid hormone secretion. PTU is used to block the formation of new thyroid hormones and reduce peripheral conversion of T4 to T3.

questions.text: A 2 months old child who was born by normal delivery to primigravida lady presented with below hoarseness and below finding on laryngoscopy what could be possible diagnosis?
A 3-year-old girl with the physical examination finding as shown below in the image. There is no significant past history. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Referral to social services for possible sexual abuse
Topical estrogen cream daily for a week
Topical steroid cream for a week

questions.solution:
• The patient in the picture has labial adhesions, a usually benign condition in which the labia minora are fused.
  • It can be treated with application of topical estrogen.
  • Rest of the options are not the best choices.
  • The fusion ranges from a small area to the entire area between the clitoris and the fourchette.
  • It is most common in young girls who are in the low estrogen state of preadolescence.
  • Sometimes urine pooling can cause an increased risk of urinary tract infection.
  • Treatment can be merely observation, as the condition should resolve with the estrogenization that occurs with puberty.
  • Nightly application of an estrogen cream for a week resolves this condition in the majority of patients.
  • However, as recurrence is common, patients must be instructed to apply daily petrolatum for a month or two after separation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old Lorry driver who was driving for a long distance decided to take a nap, parked his vehicle on the side of the road, and was sleeping under the lorry. Unfortunately, another lorry driver who was driving under the influence of alcohol lost control and hit this lorry on the backside. The patient was brought to the ER after 2 hours of the incident. Proximal limb amputation is planned for this patient. The Sequence of reimplantation is?

choices.text: Extensor tendon - Flexor tendon - Bone - Nerves - Veins - Arteries - Skin
Bone - Extensor tendon - Flexor tendon - Arteries - Nerves - Veins - Skin
Bone - Flexor tendon - Extensor tendon - Arteries - Veins - Nerves - Skin
Bone - Arteries - Nerves - Veins - Extensor tendon - Flexor tendon - Skin

questions.solution:
• Irreversible necrotic changes begin in muscles after 6 hours of ischemia (warm ischemia time), it is preferable to begin the replantation of parts with good muscular bulk (viz. parts proximal to palms and foot) within this time.
  • With cooling (to 4°C), this time may be extended to 12 hours (cold ischemia time).
Sequence of reimplantation (Mnemonic: BE FAN VS )
  • B - Bone (first to be implanted)
  • E - Extensor tendon
  • F - Flexor tendon
  • A - Arteries
  • N - Nerves
  • V - Veins
  • S - Skin (preserved first implanted last)

questions.text: A young female with a long history of sinusitis presents with frequent episodes of fever, headache of recent onset along with personality changes. Fundus examination revealed papilloedema. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Long history of sinusitis and personality changes, fundus showing papilloedema favours the diagnosis of frontal lobe abscess.

questions.text: A 15-month-old boy is brought to the hospital for a burn injury. Baby fell into a tub of hot water, father pulled him out and poured water at room temparture over affected areas of lower extremities, abdomen and torso. The burns were initially described as not too bad but later developed into blisters. The best method to assess burns caused by boiling water in a child is?
questions.solution:
Option C: Lund and Browder chart

LUND AND BROWDER CHART

  • It was created by Dr Charles Lund and Dr Newton Browder based on their experiences in treating over 300 burn victims injured at the Cocoanut Grove fire in Boston in 1942.
  • Takes into account different proportional body surface areas in children according to age.
  • Different percentages are used as the ratio of head and neck surface to the body surface is greater in children than in adults.

Option A: Palm method

  • In the case of smaller burns or patches of burn
  • The palmar surface of the hand of the person who is burned (not the fingers or wrist area) accounts for 1 % of total body surface area (TBSA) and is useful for calculating the percentage of burns

Option B: Rule of 9

  • It is not the most accurate method for the calculation of TBSA.
  • It is a crude but quick and effective method of estimating burn size.

Option D: None of the above

  • Lund and Browder chart is the most efficient method to calculate burn in children.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to your clinic by his mother for pain with burning sensation on urination for the past 3 days. His mother says that the patient had an episode of enuresis and he hasn’t passed stools for past 3 days. The patient also reports that he feels the urge to urinate. His diet consists mainly of store-bought food, milk, and dairy products. On examination he has suprapubic pain and mild abdominal distension. As a physician what advice will you give to your patient to prevent the future episodes of the current scenario?

choices.text: Avoid cow’s milk and dairy products

questions.solution: This patient has UTI which was evident by dysuria, urgency, suprapubic pain with palpation, and enuresis. Urinary tract infection (UTI) denotes infection of the bladder (cystitis), he urethra or ureter, the kidneys (pyelonephritis), or all of these. The most common organisms are the normal Gram-negative bacilli inhabitants of the gastrointestinal tract. In either gender, pyelonephritis is most commonly the result of ascending infection from the bladder. Thus, the term urinary tract infection encompasses a variety of clinical entities, including asymptomatic bacteriuria (ASB), cystitis,prostatitis, and pyelonephritis. The distinction between symptomatic UTI and asymtomatic UTI has major clinical implications. Except among infants and the elderly, UTI occurs far more commonly in females than in males. During the neonatal period, the incidence of UTI is slightly higher among males than among females because male infants more commonly have congenital urinary tract anomalies. Other risk factors include lack of circumcision, urinary obstruction (e.g., constipation), vesicoureteral reflux (VUR), and possibly genetic factors. Constipation is especially a common risk factor in children as a large stool burden can compress and therefore obstruct the urinary tract, leading to UTIs. Cessation of cow’s milk, which is a common cause of constipation, can help to prevent future episodes of urinary tract infections in children.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman at 10 weeks of gestation has a son of 2 years of age with Down's syndrome. She is anxious about risk of having another baby with Down's syndrome in this pregnancy. What can be adviced at this gestation?

choices.text: No need to do any investigation as there is minimal risk since her age is <35 years

questions.solution:
• Dual or Triple marker test (maternal blood examination) is a screening test and cannot diagnose Down syndrome.
  • Similarly, a detailed anomaly scan at 18–20 weeks would pick up soft tissue markers of Down syndrome, but again, this is not confirmatory as USG can be normal in a fetus with Down syndrome.
  • The only 100% confirmatory test for Down syndrome is karyotyping, the sample for which can be obtained by chorionic villus sampling (CVS) or amniocentesis. Hence, in a patient who has a past history of a fetus with Down syndrome, fetal karyotyping has to be done in current pregnancy.
  • Here, Chorionic villus sampling and karyotyping should be done for this patient after 10 weeks of gestation
  • Amniocentesis is generally done around 14–18 weeks and also gives confirmatory results.

questions.text: 43-year-old male with no significant past medical history presented to the emergency room with shortness of breath, cough, fever, and headache for about one week. He was taking doxycycline for pneumonia before presentation; however, his symptoms did not resolve. Which of the following cylinder with pin index numbers to be used to connect the facemask?
questions.solution:
• Machines are usually equipped with one or two E type cylinders that hang on specific hanger yokes.
  • The medical gas pin-index safety system ensures that the correct medical gas cylinder is hung in the correct yoke.

The pin index safety system consists of holes on the cylinder valve positioned in an arc below the outlet port. Pins on the yokeor pressure regulator are positioned to fit into these holes. This is one of the safety features of Anaesthesia machines to prevent misconnection of the particular gas cylinder to the machine.

Gas Index Pins
Oxygen 2,5
Nitrous oxide 3,5
Cyclopropane 3,6
O2-CO2 (CO2<7.5%) 2,6
O2-CO2 (CO2>7.5%) 1,6
O2-he(He>80.5%) 4,6
O2-he (He<80.5%) 2,4
Air 1,5
Nitrogen 1,4
Entonox(N2O-O) 7

questions.text: A 53 years male presented to opd with complaint of difficulty in swallowing. The dysphagia was more for solids than liquids. Barium swallow revealed Schatzki ring. The most common location of Schatzki ring is ?

choices.text: Junction of cervical esophagus and cricopharyngeus
Junction of upper 1/3rd and middle 1/3rd of esophagus
Junction of cricopharyngeus and upper 1/3rd of esophagus

questions.solution:
B- ring → Schatzki ring

  • Lower 1/3rd esophageal mostly at the Gastro – esophageal junction
  • LE Ring < 13mm
  • Aphagia/ Food impaction

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with complains of acute abdominal pain and vaginal spotting. She is P3L3, has a history of intake of abortifacient pills 4 days ago which was not followed by bleeding or passage of any products. On examination she is pale, PR is 140/min, BP is 70/40 mmHg, temp 98’F, abdomen is distended with rebound tenderness. Bimanual examination shows normal sized uterus with cervical motion tenderness and adnexal tenderness. Which of the following is most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
This patient has presented in early pregnancy with hemodynamic instability and pain abdomen which is most likely due to ruptured ectopic pregnancy. The patient attempted medical termination of pregnancy , which failed because the pregnancy was not intrauterine and MTP drugs act only by expelling intrauterine products. Management of ruptured ectopic pregnancy is surgical exploration followed by salpingectomy.

Indications for surgical management in a case of ectopic pregnancy are:

  • Size of ectopic more than or equal to 4 cm
  • Presence of cardiac activity
  • Beta HCG > 5000 mIU/mL
  • Evidence of rupture or a hemodynamically unstable patient

Types of surgical management

  • Salpingectomy: most ommonly performed surgery. It can be done for ruptured or unruptured ectopic. Part of the tube containing the sac is excised and ligated.
  • Salpingostomy: used to remove a small unruptured pregnancy. A 10 to 15 mm linear incision is made on the antimesenteric border over the pregnancy and products re removed or flushed out. The incision is left unsutured to heal by secondary intention after securing hemostasis
  • Salpingotomy is the procedure where the incision (similar to that made in salpingostomy) is sutured after the removal of the products.

Salpingostomy and salpingotomy are used in cases of unruptured ectopic pregnancies with smaller sacs, especially in young patients with incomplete family, desirous of tubal conservation for future pregnancies.

questions.text: A 32-year-old driver is brought to the ER after being involved in a motor vehicle accident. Paramedics intubated him. The patient's BP was 70/30 mm Hg and pulse is 110/min. On physical examination, the patient's pupils are equal and reactive. The Chest examination is significant for bruises .The trachea is midline. A Swan-Ganz catheter inserted which revealed pulmonary capillary wedge pressure of 14 mm Hg (normal2-14 mm Hg). Rapid infusion of one liter of normal saline increases the pulmonary capillary wedge pressure to 22 mm Hg, with a systemic BP of 70/30 mm Hg and pulse of 138/min. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Myocardial contusion is one of the various cardiac injuries caused by blunt trauma to the chest, which also may include asymptomatic cardiac arrhythmias; valvular, septal, or ventricular wall injuries; ventricular free wall rupture; pericardia! tamponade; and death.

An urgent echocardiogram needs to be obtained in patients with blunt chest trauma and signs of acute heart failure or shock.

This clinical presentation in the question is consistent with shock following a motor vehicle accident (MVA). The pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) is slightly elevated at baseline and increases significantly after infusion of saline without an appreciable change in systemic blood pressure. This is suggestive of elevated intracardiac filling pressures due to left ventricular dysfunction, which is most likely caused by myocardial contusion (injury to the myocardium) sustained during the accident.

Option A: The PCWP in patients with anaphylaxis is typically low or normal and improves slightly toward normal with aggressive fluid resuscitation. Anaphylaxis is a type of distributive (or vasodilatory) shock due to severely decreased systemic vascular resistance.

Option B: Patients with hypovolemic shock typically have a decreased PCWP at baseline that improves toward normal with saline infusion.

Option D: PCWP is usually low or normal and changes only slightly with saline infusion with tension pneumothorax after an MVA. It can clinically present with hypotension and shock due to direct extracardiac compression of the left and/or right ventricles. Tension pneumothorax also causes deviation of the trachea to the opposite side.

questions.text: A 72-year-old retired miner complains of progressive dyspnea, chest pain, and a 20-lb weight loss. He is a nonsmoker. Examination reveals clubbing of the fingers. CT scan shows a pleural effusion and nodular, irregular thickening of the right lung and involvement of the celiac lymph nodes. Cytology, repeated on several occasions, is not helpful. Which test will most likely establish the diagnosis?
questions.solution: The most likely diagnosis, malignantepithelioma, commonly occurs following chronic exposure (>20–40 years) to asbestos. We need to consider this diagnosis in those employed in milling and construction, as well as in workers in pipe, textiles, gaskets, and other industries in which asbestos (especially crocidolite form) is used. In 75%, the diffuse (malignant) form occurs; less than 25% will survive more than 1 year after the diagnosis is established. In advanced disease, lesions below the diaphragm are frequently encountered

questions.text: A 39-year-old man presents to his physician with the complaint of loss of peripheral vision. Which of the following findings are demonstrated by the subsequent magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan, shown here?
questions.solution: This T1-weighted sagittal MRI scan shows a dumbbell-shaped homogeneous mass involving the sella turcica and the suprasellar region. This lesion is most consistent with a pituitary adenoma, a benign tumor arising from the adenohypophysis. Pituitary adenomas are the most common sellar lesion and constitute 10% to 15% of all intracranial neoplasms. Macroadenomas are greater than 1 cm in size and microadenomas less than 1 cm. Pituitary adenomas may be functional, resulting in endocrinopathies from excessive hormone secretion, such as prolactin (amenorrhea or galactorrhea), growth hormone (gigantism or acromegaly), or adrenocorticotrophic hormone (ACTH) (Cushing syndrome). The tumor pictured is a macroadenoma; these larger tumors may cause symptoms secondary to mass effect; for example, a bitemporal visual field defect can result from compression of the optic chiasm. This tumor’s dumbbell shape results from impingement on the adenoma by the diaphragm of the sella turcica. The suprasellar extension seen here makes a frontal craniotomy rather than the more commonly utilized transsphenoidal approach more appropriate.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents to OPD with complaints of generalised fatigue & difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, getting up from chair. She is a known case of ovarian cancer. Heliotrope rash is seen on Physical examination. Mark the incorrect statement about cutaneous mainifestation of the given condition.

choices.text: Gottron’s papules: erythema seen over elbows and knees
Heliotrope rash - erythematous to violaceous eruption on the upper eyelids
Shawl sign - violaceous erythema rash on deltoids, posterior shoulder, nape of the neck, V area of neck, Upper chest

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is Dermatomyositis.

  • Heliotrope rashischaracteristic of Dermatomyositis
  • Cutaneous manifestations of dermatomyositis
    • Heliotrope rash- An erythematous to violaceous eruption on the upper eyelids

    • Gottron’s papules –violaceous flat topped papules on the interphalangeal joints and knuckles.

    • Gottron’s sign: Symmetric macular violaceous erythema with or without edema in the above mentioned sites.
    • Macular violaceous erythema overlying the dorsal hands,extensor forearms and arms,deltoids,posterior shoulder,nape of the neck,v area of neck,upper chest and forehead.(Shawl sign and V sign)

    • Palmarhyperkeratosis (or “mechanic’s hands”)
    • Priapism may occur
    • Poikilodermaatrophicansvasculare
    • Nail changes:

- Telangiectasia

- Periungual erythema and ragged cuticles

Note :

  • Specific Autoantibodies are Anti- mi2 antibody.
  • Proximal muscle weakness is seen in all diseases involving Muscles except Myotonic Dystrophy.

questions.text: A mother brings her 3-month-old to the dermatologist; she notices a dramatic color change longitudinally into a pale upper half and a deep red dependent half; she lays down the child on one side, which causes the fading of demarcation. Sucking, Moro, and Grasping reflexes are present in the child, and the rest of the examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is a correct statement about this color change?

choices.text: The skin of the entire body is typically reddish
Probably reflects an imbalance in the autonomic vascular regulatory mechanism

questions.solution:
Option D: Probably reflects an imbalance in the autonomic vascular regulatory mechanism

  • Harlequin colour change: reflects an imbalance in the autonomic vascular regulatory mechanism, a temporary imbalance of the tone of cutaneous blood vessels secondary to hypothalamic immaturity.
  • When the infant is placed on the side, the body is bisected longitudinally into a pale upper half and a deep red dependent half.
  • The condition lasts from 30 seconds to 20 minutes. It Needs no treatment.
  • The dark red colour side represents polycythaemia. It is common in healthy neonates, but associations include:
    • Prematurity
    • Low birth weight
    • Hypoxia
    • Systemic use of prostaglandins E1
    • Meningitis
    • Intracranial injury
  • Differential diagnoses include Port wine stain or nascent haemangioma of infancy. These both are differentiated based on transient appearance.

    • NOTE: Do not confuse it with Harlequin ichthyosis.

​​​​​​​

  • The newborn is covered with thick patches of skin that crack and split. Thick plaques can pull and distort facial features and restrict breathing and food intake—mutations in the ABCA12 gene.

Option A: The skin of the entire body is typically reddish

  • Many newborns develop a blotchy red skin reaction called Erythema Toxicum involving the whole skin.
  • It appears between 2 days and 2 weeks after birth with flat red patches or small bumps.
  • First appears on the face and then spreads to the body and limbs.
  • The rash is not contagious and clears within a few weeks.

Option B: Needs immediate hospitalization

  • Harlequin Colour Change represents a benign, idiopathic, and rapidly autoresolutive phenomenon with no need for treatment.
  • Some drugs (Anaesthetics and prostaglandin E) cause HCC, so drug withdrawal is sometimes necessary.
  • In rare circumstances, when HCC is caused by serious central nervous system or systemic disorders (meningitis, hypothalamic brain stem, sympathetic nervous system lesions)  in that case the treatment of the cause is important.

Option C: A complication of epidermolysis bullosa

  • Epidermolysis bullosa is a group 
  • The clinical spectrum ranges from localized involvement to life-threatening disabling disease.
  • It has four subtypes:
    • Epidermolysis bullosa simplex
    • Junctions EB
    • Dystrophic EB
    • Kindler Syndrome
  • Diagnosis is made by skin biopsy for immunofluorescence mapping.
  • There is no treatment except gene therapy for now.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents to the clinic complaining of a lesion in his oral cavity, which looks like a frog’s belly. He is scheduled for elective surgery. During the surgery, the surgeon employs the following instrument. What is the name of this instrument?
questions.solution:
Option C: Doyen’s mouth gag

  • The patient has an intra-oral ranula and is being planned for marsupialization.
  • The above-given image shows a Doyen’s mouth gag.
  • It has blades that are semi-circular and curved at the tip.
  • It is used to keep the mouth open during intra-oral surgeries like
    • Glossectomy
    • Cleft palate
    • Intra-oral ranula

    • To acquire a biopsy from a suspicious lesion

Option A: Joll’s thyroid retractor

  • The Joll’s self-retaining retractor is a speciality surgical tool used for challenging incision sites.
  • It is commonly used for thyroid and vaginal procedures due to its unusual form, which allows it to access these anatomical locations more effectively.

Option B: Morris retractor

  • The Morris Retractor is used to retract the abdominal wall, loin, and subcostal incisions.
  • It can fit a wide range of wounds at any depth.
  • The handle has an oval ring that provides an improved grip for an assistant's fingertips.

Option D: Beckman Weitlaner retractor

  • The Beckman Weitlaner retractor is a surgical instrument used in veterinary surgery to retract tissues and skin.
  • It is most typically utilized in spinal and intracranial procedures.
  • The instrument is equipped with finger ring grips and a self-locking mechanism.
